DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Invitees Hope To Discuss Trade, Technology, Sports _ and Spam
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has discussed chemical weapons, nuclear arms and trade. Now it's time to talk about something really important _ Spam. Among the 145 business and farm leaders invited to meet with Gorbachev in Minneapolis on Sunday is Richard L. Knowlton, chief executive officer of Geo. A. Hormel & Co., which makes the spiced luncheon meat in a can. ``We'll talk about Spam,'' Knowlton said Friday. ``I will be taking a can of Spam along for him. ``Khrushchev's memoirs give a lot of credit to Spam for helping the Russians get through World War II,'' the executive noted. Knowlton and the others on the list hope to scout new markets for their products and to offer advice for the Soviet Union's transition to a market economy. The list, originally planned to include about 50 people, tripled so that a wider variety of businesses could be included, said Ray Bohn, a spokesman for Gov. Rudy Perpich. The list includes such nationally known executives as Chrysler Corp.'s Lee Iacocca, as well as small-town Minnesotans like William Marvin of Warroad, population 1,000. ``I have no idea why I was included,'' said Marvin, chairman and CEO of Marvin Windows in the northern Minnesota town. ``I thought somebody had made a mistake.'' Another invitee, Minnesota Vikings General Manager Mike Lynn, wants to seek Gorbachev's help in taking football to the Soviet Union. Said Lynn: ``We would like to be the first team to play in Russia.''

DOC.HEAD: Ballet Will Complete National Tour
DOC.TEXT: The Joffrey Ballet, which had canceled a national tour because of money problems, announced Friday that donors had stepped forward to fund the planned performances. The company will perform at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., Charleston, S.C., June 7 to 9; Wolf Trap Farm Park, Vienna, Va., June 19 to 21, and Artpark, Lewiston, N.Y., June 26 to June 1. Joffrey dancers also will appear on the June 18 opening night of the International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss., in a tribute to Robert Joffrey. The announcement reverses a decision this week by the ballet company's board to cancel the tour because of a lack of funds. Nigel Redden, Spoleto's general manager, said that the festival has offered the Joffrey more money than was contracted plus free assistance in lighting and wardrobe. Philip Morris Companies Inc. and the Harkness Foundation for Dance have contributed an undisclosed sum of money. The College of Charleston has arranged free dormitory rooms for the troupe. Helping financially with the other engagements are the Charles and Ruth Levy Foundation, Barbara and David Kipper and Mrs. Jouett Shouse.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Talks Turn Informal After Major Accords Signed
Bush-Gorbachev depart for Camp David at 10 a.m. EDT. Will be led
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev anticipated a more relaxed round of summit talks at the Camp David presidential retreat today after sealing an array of superpower agreements on long-range nuclear weapons, chemical arms and - surprisingly - trade. ``The world has waited long enough, the Cold War must end,'' declared Bush at an elaborate signing ceremony Friday in the ornate East Room of the White House. At a mid-summit scene framed by Soviet and American flags, Gorbachev said the achievements represent ``an event of momentous importance not only for our two countries but for the world.'' Agreements aside, the two men laid out an ambitious negotiating agenda for the balance of the year, and success could mean another summit or perhaps two. They expressed the hope they could seal the formal treaty on long-range nuclear weapons, and agree to a reduction in conventional forces in Europe. Secretary of State James A. Baker III also said both sides had made a commitment to a follow-up round of arms control talks to cover cuts in heavy missiles with multiple warheads. Summit disagreements persisted over German unification and Lithuania, although Baker said talks had produced an ``understanding of each other's concerns.'' Bush and Gorbachev, with one more full day of bargaining on their summit agenda, were heading for the Camp David compound in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. Said Gorbachev: ``There's a lot of fresh air there and I think we'll work and complete our discussions.'' Baker said the two presidents would discuss regional conflicts during the day, presumably including Afghanistan, and well as talk about Perestroika and the ``prospects for improved economic'' ties between the United States and Soviet Union. The summit ends on Sunday with a joint news conference. Gorbachev is making stops in Minnesota and California on his way home. He is expected to meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo while on the West Coast in an apparent bid to improve relations with a key potential trading partner. Bush and Gorbachev did their work as their wives flew to Boston for the day. Together, Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev attended commencement ceremonies at Wellesley College before taking front-row seats at the White House signing ceremony and then joining their husbands and aides for dinner at the Soviet embassy. In his toast, Bush said ``Because Americans are so free to dream, we feel a special kinship with those who dream of being free. And today that kinship is quickly becoming a shared spirit, a spirit that inspires millions here in our nation, in your own and around the world.' Gorbachev, for his part, paid a special salute to Bush for signing the trade agreement. He said it ``takes on special relevance since it has been concluded at a time of a dramatic change of direction in the Soviet economy which is crucial for the future of perestroika.'' Roast duck, suckling pig and apple puff pastry were on the menu. The trade pact was the surprise of Friday's summitry - a day of intense behind the scenes negotiations. At one point, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said snags had developed in the framework to cut long-range nuclear weapons by up to 35 percent, but Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze went back to work and nailed down the framework expected to form the basis for a formal treaty in the future. Gorbachev pressed his case for a trade agreement forcefully, and told congressional leaders he was hoping for a gesture that would bolster his troubled drive to institute a free-market economy back home. ``I think he feels if he doesn't get it he's going home empty handed,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, one of several congressional officials who heard Gorbachev's request. The Soviets also balked at signing an agreement to purchase U.S. grain _ a deal favored by American farmers _ unless the broader trade pact was approved. In the end, it, too, received signatures. The deal commits the Soviets to buy at least 10 million tons annually, starting next year, of U.S. wheat, feed grains and soybeans. That is an increase of one million tons annually from the current agreement. Gorbachev wanted the broader treaty pact because it will facilitate investment in the Soviet Union by American companies. The trade agreement also is a step toward granting most-favored-nation status to Moscow, providing the lowest possible tariffs on Soviet goods. Baker said the pact would not be sent to Congress until the Soviets approved liberalized emigration legislation. There was no mention at the signing ceremony of any condition that the Kremlin lessen its economic restrictions on the breakaway Soviet Republic of Lithuania. That dismayed Lithuanian Americans demonstrating across the street. Arunas Martinonis of Boston said Bush ``is letting democracy and independence down.'' Also unmentioned at the signing ceremony was Germany. The two presidents agreed on Thursday they would be unable for the duration of the summit to resolve their disputes over the military shape of a unified Germany, but Baker and Shevardnadze will go back to work on that issue next week. Heralding the pact to cut stockpiles of poison gas, Bush said, ``Let this landmark agreement quickly lead to a global ban on chemical weapons.'' Negotiations are under way among 40 nations for a worldwide treaty. Other agreements signed by the two sides covered verification of nuclear test limits signed in the 1970s, a pact on atomic energy cooperation and one covering maritime transportation. Other topics covered include reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow and the first government-to-government agreement to increase student exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gets the Trophy He Wanted _ Maybe
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev the economic prize he sought from the summit _ a signed trade agreement _ but whether the accord will ever take effect is far from certain. For one thing, Bush set conditions on whether he will even submit the document to Congress for ratification. And once that hurdle is cleared, members of Congress were warning that they are in no mood to approve the accord unless Gorbachev eases his economic blockade of independence-minded Lithuania. ``The United States will not give new trade benefits while the Soviet noose continues to strangle Lithuania,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., an outspoken backer of the breakaway Baltic republic. The administration had tried on its own to pressure Gorbachev to make concessions on Lithuania before it signed the trade agreement, but in the end Bush decided not to send Gorbachev back to Moscow empty-handed. Gorbachev, struggling at home with empty store shelves and a variety of economic ills, had made the trade agreement an important symbol of his ability to improve economic relations with the West. The trade agreement is a necessary condition for lowering tariffs on Soviet products sold in the United States, levies that are currently as high as 10 times the rate imposed on goods from nations which enjoy the most-favored-nation trade status. American business groups had lobbied for approval of the trade agreement because the pact contains a variety of provisions aimed at expanding opportunities for U.S. companies in the Soviet Union. These provisions would make it easier for American companies to establish joint ventures with Soviet companies, a key goal of Gorbachev's efforts to attract Western expertise. The outcome of the trade treaty was in doubt throughout a lengthy day of bargaining Friday. Also signed was a five-year grain agreement which had become a bargaining chip in the battle over trade. An administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that intense debate was taking place on the grain and trade proposals with the Soviets threatening to block the grain agreement _ advantageous to U.S. farmers _ if they didn't get the trade pact they sought. Referring to American reaction to the Soviet crackdown on Lithuanian independence efforts, Gorbachev told the White House audience, ``I am pleased to note that the turbulent developments in recent months after (the summit at) Malta have not led us astray from the goals that we set together.'' But Secretary of State James A. Baker III, briefing reporters later, acknowledged that the required passage of the trade agreement by Congress will be difficult unless Gorbachev starts a new dialogue with Lithuanian leaders. Baker also said that the trade agreement will not be sent to Congress for ratification until the Soviet legislature passes an emigration law allowing more liberal travel abroad. Soviet officials said approval of the emigration measure will not be a problem although its final passage by the Supreme Soviet has been delayed several times. Once the Soviet legislature acts, the administration said that it will send the trade agreement to Congress and will also submit a presidential certification that the Soviets are eligible for the most-favored-nation status. Both the trade agreement and the presidential declaration must be approved by Congress for the lower tariffs to go into effect. Signaling a fight unless Gorbachev relents on Lithuania, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said, ``The granting of MFN status, in my mind, is in Mr. Gorbachev's hands. He can achieve it with some rather modest changes in his policy toward the Baltic states.'' Lithuanian-American demonstrators massed outside the Soviet embassy in Washington were clearly disappointed with Bush's decision. ``I think he's letting democracy and independence down,'' said Arunas Martinonis of Boston. ``It really upsets me.'' ``Bush should be stronger about Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia,'' said Helen Zimavicus Carter, who drove 15 hours from her Chicago home to join the protest. ``We're really shocked he doesn't stand up for their rights.'' In addition to the trade agreement, several other accords were signed on Friday. These included: _Expanding commercial air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union by adding four American and six Soviet cities to current airliner routes. _A new 5-year atomic energy agreement to provide closer cooperation in nuclear reactor safety, fusion energy and basic atomic science. _A maritime transportation pact to make it easier for U.S. and Soviet commercial vessels to deliver goods to ports in one another's country. _Opening reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow. _The first government-to-government agreement to increase student exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.BYLINE: Over Suckling Pig, Gorbachev Gives Thanks for Trade Pact ^By RITA BEAMISH
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev topped an embassy dinner of suckling pig and apple puff pastry with special thanks to President Bush for a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement he said would hearten his hard-pressed countrymen. ``This agreement takes on special relevance since it has been concluded at a time of a dramatic change of direction in the Soviet economy which is crucial for the future of perestroika,'' Gorbachev said at the dinner Friday night for Bush and his wife Barbara. ``I am convinced that the Soviet people will appreciate the fact that the United States -- the President of the United States -- is signing this agreement to normalize Soviet-American commercial relations at this moment of special importance for our country,'' Gorbachev said, raising a glass of golden champagne in an toast to his guest of honor. The dinner at the Soviet Embassy capped a second day of negotiations, ending with the signing of several agreements between the two countries. Included was the broad outline of a pact to slash stockpiles of long-range nuclear missiles. Bush, in his toast, said he had learned that Gorbachev's home town in the northern Caucasus was called Privolnoe, which he said means spacious or free. That prompted a smile from the Soviet president, and Bush apologized for his pronunciation. ``It reminded me of the new breeze, the new spirit of freedom that we've seen sweep across Europe and around the globe,'' Bush said. ``Because Americans are so free to dream, we feel a special kinship with those who dream of being free. And today that kinship is quickly becoming a shared spirit, a spirit that inspires millions here in our nation, in your own and around the world.'' The stately but fraying embassy, a few blocks from the White House, was so wrapped in security that bulletproof frames of glass were placed outside the street-side windows. Legions of security men inside shoved reporters and photographers back into place when they took a step beyond their assigned area or lingered for a backward glance at the dinner hall. In deference to Soviet custom, Bush and the other Americans wore dark business suits, rather than the tuxedos customary at such formal dinners, and the women wore normal-length dresses. Mrs. Bush, seated at the head table between Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, wore a fuchsia knee-length dress with a flouncy skirt. Raisa Gorbachev, seated between Vice President Dan Quayle and Bush, was in black velvet. The menu included consomme with dumplings and mushroom cream, roast duck, suckling pig, and baked sevruga-fish. Dessert was strawberry parfait, fruit and apple puff pastry. The Soviets served some of their country's best wine _ Tsinandali Georgian white dry 1987 and Mookoozani Georgian red dry 1987, along with the Soviets' golden champagne Zolotoye. On tap to entertain the 80 American and Soviet guests were Soviet opera singer Zurab Sotkilava and pianist Mikhail Pletnev. Among those attending: Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas and his wife Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole; industrialist Armand Hammer; Katharine Graham, chairman of the board of The Washington Post Co.; Duayne Andreas, the Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. chairman; and Pepsico Inc. chairman Donald Kendall.

DOC.HEAD: Wearing Seat Belts Brings A Bonus _ Stereo Equipment
DOC.TEXT: Buckling up will soon bring an unexpected bonus in the Netherlands, where police and a road safety group plan to hand out compact disc players to drivers who obey the seat belt law. The scheme to distribute 100 of the disc players among law-abiding drivers has already come under fire. ``Wearing seat belts is the law and it's the police's job to see the law is obeyed,'' the Rotterdam newspaper Algemeen Dagblad said Friday. ``What's next? A pocket calculator for those who obey the speed limit?'' Volunteers of the government-subsidized Road Safety Foundation will join police patrols in this northern province next month and present disc players at random to those found wearing seat belts, foundation spokesman Anne van Schepen said. ``CD players are the `in' thing these days, so people will wear their safety belts if that's what it takes to win one,'' van Schepen said in an interview. Seat belts have been obligatory for all drivers and front-seat passengers since 1971. But according to the foundation's statistics, only 77 percent of Dutch drivers wear them on highways, and the figure drops to 63 percent in built-up areas. ``Every percentage point increase (in seat belt use) translates into two to three fewer deaths each year,'' van Schepen said. Auto accidents claim 1,400 lives each year in this nation of 14.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Outlook For START Treaty Brightens
DOC.TEXT: Successful negotiations at the summit have carried the United States and the Soviet Union closer to concluding a treaty this year to reduce their strategic nuclear weapons arsenals. But they remain far apart on another accord to withdraw tens of thousands of troops and tanks in Europe. ``Serious substantive differences remain,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday night. But he added that both sides are committed to resolving them by the end of the year. The key unsettled issue is the kind of aircraft to restrict. Also, the Soviets are still reluctant to approve the reductions without limits on German forces. A senior U.S. official, who declined identification, offered no prediction of success, and said the United States would not yield on its insistence on NATO membership for a unified Germany. The success in the strategic nuclear weapons field resulted from six days of negotiations that began last Sunday at the State Department. The U.S. and Soviet teams, headed by Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew and Deputy Prime Minister Viktor P. Karpov, began with six key issues and settled two of them. As a result, the Soviets will be banned from putting their heavy, ground-based SS-18 missiles on mobile launchers and the two sides will be limited to 1,100 warheads on their mobile missiles. The ban will not affect the U.S. MX missile because it is not considered a heavy missile, the U.S. official told reporters at a briefing under rules that bars identifying him. Second, to ensure the treaty is carried out, each side will conduct 12 kinds of on-site inspections, some of them on short notice. Left unsettled _ and to be taken up by U.S. and Soviet negotiators in Geneva _ are whether to limit flight tests of the Soviet SS-18 missiles or to limit the Soviet Backfire bomber, and the restrictions to be imposed on diverting banned weapons to third countries. The sixth issue _ whether to ban intercontinental ballistic missiles with multiple warheads _ will be considered in follow-on negotiations after the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty is concluded. ``The objectives of these negotiations will be to reduce further the risk of outbreak of war, particularly nuclear war,'' the two sides said in a joint statement. The new talks will begin ``without delay'' once the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) is signed, the statement said. Baker, who joined the negotiations on Friday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said ``we made workmanlike progress over the full spectrum'' of arms issues. He referred also to completion of an agreement to end the production of U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons. A senior American official disclosed, meanwhile, that earlier in the week the Soviets had renewed their long-abandoned effort to require limits on the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as Star Wars, in conjunction with cuts in offensive weapons. ``It was clearly an effort to change the status quo,' the official said. ``It sort of slowed us up and we had to push them back,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Uphold's State's Right to Regulate Disposal
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Friday abandoned an effort to revoke North Carolina's authority to regulate hazardous waste, in a move some participants said could have nationwide implications. The decision by Daniel W. McGovern, the EPA's regional administrator in San Francisco, upholds the state's right to adopt environmental laws that are more stringent than federal standards. It also could scuttle plans by Laidlaw Environmental Services Co., formerly GSX Chemical Services Co., to build a massive, regional hazardous-waste treatment facility near Laurinburg in Scotland County. At issue in the case was whether a state law prevented hazardous-waste treatment plants from operating in the state. In essence, the law requires such plants to dilute each gallon of treated wastewater with at least 1,000 gallons of water before discharging into rivers and streams. GSX and the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, an industry trade group, asked the EPA to revoke the state's authority to manage hazardous wastes after the General Assembly passed the law in 1987. GSX contended that the law was arbitrary and was primarily aimed at preventing the company from building its treatment plant in Scotland County. State and local officials said the law was designed to protect drinking water. The proposed GSX plant would have discharged as much as 500,000 gallons of treated waste daily into the Lumber River, the main water supply for Lumberton and much of Robeson County. The EPA held a series of hearings last year on issue. The final decision was left to the EPA official in San Francisco because Greer C. Tidwell, the EPA's Southeastern regional administrator in Atlanta, requested an independent decision-maker. He was criticized as partial to the industries involved in the case. ``Hopefully, this will spell the end to the GSX proposal,'' said the Rev. F. Mac Legerton, executive director of the Center for Community Action, a Lumberton-based group that has fought the proposed plant for six years. ``This was not just a not-in-my-own-backyard campaign,'' he said. ``The GSX proposal raised serious questions about massive discharges into a very small river that remains a public drinking water source.'' The EPA decision has far-reaching implications, he said, because it reaffirms a state's right to pass laws that are more stringent than federal ones. The company has yet to decide if it will appeal, said spokesman Roger E. Davis from Laidlaw's headquarters in Columbia, S.C. The decision doesn't rule out the plant, he said, but it would force the company to build a much smaller version that might not be economically feasible. ``If we can't get permits to build these facilities, there is insufficient and inadequate treatment of the waste,'' he said. ``Since we're not going to shut off the production of hazardous waste totally ... the environment is going to suffer.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Agency Continues Search for Cause of Columbia Leak
With PM-Delta Launch
DOC.TEXT: NASA officials fear shuttle Columbia's astronomy mission, already delayed until mid-June, may not get off the ground until July because of a hydrogen leak. The agency plans to pump super-cold liquid hydrogen into Columbia's external tank next Wednesday to duplicate temperature and pressure conditions under which hydrogen leaked during fueling six hours before the scheduled launch last Wednesday. ``That looks like the only way we can find it,'' Brewster Shaw, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's deputy director of shuttle operations, said Friday. But the agency was not ``terribly optimistic'' that the new test will pinpoint a cause that can be fixed easily while the shuttle remains at the launch pad, Shaw said. ``It's worth our while to do the test and find the leak. It's not good to roll back (to the hangar) not knowing where the leak is,'' he said. The 36th shuttle mission already was two weeks behind schedule because of cooling system repairs when the latest snag arose. Returning Columbia to the hangar would push the mission into July. NASA spent Thursday and Friday searching Columbia's engine compartment for the hydrogen leak. Columbia's external tank was drained of fuel and filled with non-flammable helium, but no leak was found. Engineers are fairly certain the leak is in or near a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen from the external tank to the shuttle's main engines, NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said. Traces of helium were found Friday in a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the shuttle and its external tank. The valve and pipe run through both plates. NASA planned today to circulate helium through the shuttle's entire fuel system in preparation of Wednesday's tanking test. Shaw said Columbia's seven astronauts are ``anxious to go fly their mission, but you can't go until your ride's ready. So they'll just keep training and try and keep their spirits up.'' Columbia's payload is a $150 million observatory called Astro that will examine ultraviolet light and X-rays from extremely hot stars, galaxies and other objects. Ten miles from where Columbia stood silent, NASA launched the unmanned Delta rocket Friday. The rocket boosted into orbit a West German observatory with a powerful X-ray telescope and a wide-field camera capable of detecting extreme ultraviolet light.

DOC.HEAD: Mineral Water Prices Soar Due to Water Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Naples shopowners agreed to hold down prices on mineral water and the government rushed 50,000 bottles to the city following a run on the product caused by contamination of the local water supply. Tap water in several neighborhoods of Italy's third-largest city has been brown and smelly since Tuesday, when a pipe broke and sediment entered the water supply. The situation prompted an angry demonstration Thursday by about 200,000 people, who complained of poor water quality and shortages even before the pipe break. Organizations of shopowners and distributors met Friday and agreed to post a table of prices for mineral water in stores. The price tripled to $2 a quart in some stores because of the run on mineral water, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. The Ministry of Health sent 50,000 bottles of mineral water to Naples as well as two machines capable of purifying a total of about 26,000 a day of tap water, officials said. The Red Cross is to distribute the water for free.

DOC.HEAD: Tribute Planned To Mohandas Gandhi
DOC.TEXT: Mohandas Gandhi is to be honored by the town where he was thrown off a train nearly 100 years ago because he wasn't white, a news report said. The Pietermaritzburg City Council in the eastern province of Natal has approved in principle a plan to erect a plaque or statue to honor Gandhi, the independent South African Press Association said Friday. Gandhi, who came to South Africa as a 24-year-old lawyer in 1894, led passive resistance actions against racist laws. He returned to India in 1914, where he became a leader of the anti-British independence movement. The proposed monument will say: ``During the night of 7th June 1893, a young Indian lawyer, Mohandas Gandhi, was put off a train at Pietermartizburg Station because he had refused to move out of a `European' coach.'' The wording continues: ``Gandhi later described his feelings: `What was my duty? I asked myself. Should I go back to India or should I go forward with God as my helper and face what was in store for me? I decided to stay and suffer. My active non-violence began from that date.'''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Court Recognizes Five Opposition Parties
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Supreme Court has legalized all five opposition parties formed since activists began demonstrating last year for an end to the Communist monopoly on power, China's news agency reported. Three of the five _ the Mongolian Democratic Party, the Social Democrats and the National Progressive Party _ already had agreed to join forces in fighting the ruling Communists in legislative elections in July. The elections will be the first multi-party vote in Mongolian history. The new legislature, or Great People's Hural, will in turn elect a small standing legislature, and also will elect a new president. The other two new parties are the Party of Free Labor, formed by co-operative workers and owners, and the Green Party, concerned with environmental issues. In a report Friday from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, China's official Xinhua News Agency said the Supreme Court warned the parties they may be dissolved if they do not strictly abide by the constitution and other laws. The opposition groups and the Communist Party, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, registered under a new law approved in May that provides for the first time for the existence of more than one party. The law requires each party to have at least 801 members. The Communists, who have ruled for nearly seven decades, have about 90,000 members. The Mongolian Democratic Party, the second largest group, said it has 7,200 members. The new law also bars parties from receiving state funds, but set no deadline for the ruling party to stop receiving its state support.

DOC.HEAD: X-Ray Observatory Takes Ride on Unmanned Delta Rocket
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: An observatory intended to probe cosmic X-rays orbited 360 miles above Earth today after a trip into space on an unmanned rocket. NASA launched the Delta rocket Friday as space shuttle Columbia stood nearby, grounded until at least mid-June by an engine leak that aborted an astronomy mission Wednesday. The space agency's Arthur Mackey said the Delta launch went off without a glitch. ``They did a beautiful job, put it right where it was supposed to be,'' he said after the spacecraft separated from its booster 43 minutes into the flight. The Delta rocket blasted into a partly cloudy sky at 5:47 p.m. EDT from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. Liftoff was delayed about 12 minutes so a commercial airliner could move out of the launch danger area. Confirmation that the spacecraft had separated and was safe in its orbit was delayed by a brief loss of radio contact. The $273 million West German observatory, called Rosat, originally was to have flown on a shuttle in 1987. It was redesigned to fit into the Delta after the 1986 Challenger explosion meant waiting until the mid-1990s for a shuttle ride. Astronomers expect Rosat to identify 100,000 sources of cosmic X-rays, which cannot penetrate the Earth's atmosphere and thus are invisible from the ground. Only about 1,000 sources currently are known to exist. ``This will be the fodder that scientists will use for years to come to identify targets for future study,'' said NASA program scientist Alan N. Bunner. The satellite consists of a powerful X-ray telescope and a wide-field camera capable of detecting extreme ultraviolet light. After two months of instrument calibration, Rosat will begin a six-month survey of celestial bodies that emit X-rays. It will be the first full-sky survey by an imaging X-ray telescope. Following the survey, the observatory will spend the next year or more making detailed observations of extremely hot stars, black holes and remnants of supernovas, hot clouds produced by exploding stars at the end of their lives. There will be 1,457 targets during the first six months alone, said Joachim Truemper, Rosat program scientist for West Germany's Federal Ministry for Research and Technology. Information will be transmitted to a ground station near Munich, West Germany, then sent for analysis to centers in that country, the United States and Britain. Rosat is 100 times more sensitive than the best X-ray observatory to date, the so-called Einstein Observatory, which was placed in orbit in 1978, Bunner said. Rosat will complement the work of the X-ray telescope that is part of the Astro observatory waiting to be launched from Columbia. NASA is picking up the $63 million cost of the McDonnell Douglas Delta II rocket and related launch expenses. The United States also has contributed $18 million toward the $273 million cost of Rosat. Great Britain has chipped in $35 million. Rosat is short for Roentgen Satellite, named after German scientist Wilhelm Conrad Rontgen, who discovered X-rays in 1895.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A towel used to mop the brow of George Harrison during his 1975 ``Dark Horse'' concert tour will be auctioned to raise funds for abused children. The towel, signed by the former Beatle, is to be sold Wednesday at an auction to benefit Try Angle House in Nashville for abused and neglected girls, auction spokeswoman Patsi Cox said Friday. The towel was donated by an unidentified local musician who has worked with Harrison. About 100 items once owned or used by celebrities will be auctioned.

Cyclist Greg LeMond will display his speed in the saddle in a $12-million advertising campaign for fast-food tacos. A commercial scheduled to begin airing Monday features LeMond making a ``Run to the Border'' for six-pack boxes of Taco Bell tacos, said Tim Ryan, the restaurant chain's senior vice president of marketing. LeMond signed last year with Taco Bell Corp. after winning the Tour de France, cycling's premier event.

Katie Kelly, who quit her job as a movie critic on ``Entertainment Tonight'' to teach English to children in Vietnam, is a hit in her hometown. Today was Katie Kelly Day in Albion, a town of 2,000 about 140 miles northwest of Omaha. Ms. Kelly has been tutoring Amerasians in Vietnam since March. She described her work as ``an experience of a lifetime; I wouldn't have passed it up.'' Vietnam, she said, ``has grabbed me by the heart. The people are absolutely incredible _ friendly, social, generous. They have nothing, but they'd give you the shirt off their back.'' Ms. Kelly's works in the Amerasian Transient Center, recently constructed by the U.S. government in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. Her students have ranged in age from 5 to 51.

A handful of Baptist ministers complained that Pat Conroy's use of profanity in some of his best-selling novels made him unsuitable as Furman University's commencement speaker. Conroy, whose books include ``The Lords of Discipline,'' ``The Prince of Tides'' and ``The Great Santini,'' was to give Furman's commencement address today. The clergymen sent protest letters to John E. Johns, president of the private college of 2,500 students founded by Baptists and supported by the South Carolina Baptist Convention. ``I have nothing against Pat Conroy, but with Furman supposedly being a Christian and a Southern Baptist school, I don't think he should be receiving an honorary degree,'' said David Satterwhite, a minister at Roebuck Baptist Church in Spartanburg. Johns said the college was honoring Conroy ``as an outstanding novelist and script writer'' and would not withdraw the invitation. Conroy on Friday welcomed the ministers to his speech. ``It will probably be a far more interesting speech than the sermons they give on Sunday,'' he said.

A judge allowed actor Todd Bridges to remain free on $25,000 bail pending his trial on an assault charge but warned he would be sent to jail if he shows up in court under the influence of drugs. ``There were two appearances when I suspected you were under the influence of narcotics,'' Superior Court Judge Florence Cooper said Friday. ``But on this and another occasion, you gave the impression your conduct has improved.'' On April 9, Bridges told the judge he failed to make a previous appearance because he was involved in a car accident on his way to the courthouse. Bridges, the former child star of television's ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' is to go on trial July 30 on a felony assault charge stemming from the Feb. 2 shooting of an unarmed man in a Los Angeles house where drugs were on sale. Bridges was acquitted of attempted murder and involuntary manslaughter in the shooting of Kenneth ``Tex'' Clay. Bridges testified he was too high on cocaine to remember what happened. Jurors could not reach a verdict on the charge of assault with a deadly weapon, and prosecutors refiled that charge.

Bob Marley's widow, Alfarita, has been sued for $10 million for allegedly reneging on promises to perform in Hawaii. Anthony Spence, owner of Premiere Productions, filed the lawsuit Friday in U.S. District Court alleging that the late reggae star's widow agreed to perform three concerts in Hawaii in the summer of 1988 and also promised Premiere future concert dates with her son, Ziggy. According to the lawsuit, Premiere advanced Mrs. Marley $22,500 and sent her 15 airplane tickets worth $15,126. The day she was scheduled to arrive in Hawaii, she canceled, saying bronchitis prevented her from making the trip, the lawsuit says. Spence says she returned only $10,000 of the advance and five tickets. A woman who answered the telephone at the number listed for Marley's home in Kingston, Jamaica, said the performer was out of the country and could not be reached for comment. Spence is asking for all of the money to be returned plus $10 million in damages for breach of contract and fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Wyoming Prisoners Do Their Time Breaking Wild Horses
DOC.TEXT: Prisoners in other states whittle away the hours stamping out license plates. Inmates in a Wyoming program do their time in the saddle _ or trying to stay in the saddle _ as they break wild horses. Gary Starbuck, superintendent of the Wyoming Honor Farm, said the 2-year-old horse-breaking program molds inmates into more productive citizens than do prison cells. ``Some say they've got it too easy. It's a country club. They want to see them do hard time,'' Starbuck said as he kept an eye on the bronco-busting recently at the sprawling, tree-studded corrections ranch. ``But what you end up with is someone bitter, probably harder on drugs than when he got there. That's been the problem with corrections for 200 years. It's punishment-oriented,'' he said. The prison horse-breaking program is one of four in the United States, but the only one that breaks horses enough that they can be ridden, not just led by a halter. The horses then are offered for adoption by the public for $125 each. The program is so popular among inmates that ``the first thing they want when they get here is boots and a cowboy hat,'' said honor farm staff supervisor Billy Eppler. In Wyoming, one might presume there would be an abundance of incarcerated cowboys bucking for a chance to get back to their life's work breaking horses. Not so. There is a shortage of qualified ranch hands in Wyoming, and most of the eight inmates now breaking horses knew nothing about the animals before they were convicted. They learned fast. ``He kicked me in the head today,'' inmate Joe Trotter, a Chicago cabinetmaker convicted of a drug charge, said of Blade, one of the wild horses the Bureau of Land Management rounds up from Wyoming's open ranges. ``It makes me all the more determined to ride him. It's just a little bit dangerous. That's all,'' he said. ``Ever since I was a little kid, I thought of being like a cowboy of the Old West. I've got it here,'' said inmate Jim Wiggins, who is doing time for burglary. ``I never picked up a horse's foot before I got here. When I get out I want to keep working with horses.'' Each inmate in the program produces four to six rideable horses a month. The horse taming is one of several agriculture programs at the central Wyoming corrections farm. The other 100 or so inmates herd cattle and raise pigs or work in the dairy or butcher shop. But the wild horse program is considered the most prestigious assignment among prisoners. It also is lauded by state corrections officials as a productive method of instilling a sense of accomplishment, self-confidence and pride. ``If they haven't accomplished anything in their life, if they break a horse, that's a real accomplishment,'' Eppler said. The inmates, some serving time for rape and murder, are considered a low risk for escape from the minimum-security prison. The only obstacle to freedom at the scenic ranch in the Wind River Basin is a split rail fence and a row of cottonwood trees. Trotter believes he's a better man for his newfound skill of breaking horses. But he can't help but desire freedom. ``You get to thinking, sitting up there on my horse _ the mountains are looking pretty good, I could just take off,'' he said. ``But it's not like you can ride off into the sunset and forget about it. They'll catch up to you. You might as well stay put.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Investigates Seat Collapse in Chrysler Minivans
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy's death in a Pennsylvania crash has prompted an investigation into possible rear-seat defects in some Chrysler minivans, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said the company is cooperating but does not believe the seats are defective. ``We have 2 million-plus minivans out there, and we know of no specific problems with the rear seats,'' Jakobowski said Friday. The investigation will focus on Dodge Caravans and Plymouth Voyagers manufactured in the 1986-89 model years, agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. It is classified as a preliminary evaluation, which consists mostly of paperwork. If evidence of a widespread problem is found, the investigation will be upgraded and government engineers will study the possibly defective parts. Eventually, a recall could be ordered. Chrysler manufactures more than half the minivans sold in the United States. Introduced in the 1984 model year, they are marketed as the Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town & Country. The government has received six complaints about the minivans involving three accidents, four injuries and one death, Hurd said. Noah Z. George of Washington County, Pa., died Feb. 11 after the 1987 Voyager in which he was riding crashed. He was strapped in a booster seat secured to the rear seat by a seat belt. The impact tore open the van's rear lift gate and the back seat collapsed. Noah was thrown about 35 feet into a stream, where he died of exposure. A coroner's jury ruled the seat was ``flimsy and poorly constructed and is unsafe for public use,'' Farrell Jackson, coroner of Washington County, said in a letter to consumer activist Ralph Nader. Jackson called the minivans a ``potential death trap.'' Jakobowski said the minivans exceed federal standards for rear-seat construction. But Mike Johnson, spokesman for the Nader-founded Center for Auto Safety, said the federal standards were inadequate. The minivans should be recalled and the seats reinforced, he said.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Says Companies Not Following the Rules
DOC.TEXT: Many small ``alternative operator service'' companies are not following federal rules designed to protect the traveling public from misrepresentations and overcharges, government regulators say. The companies provide telephone operators and long-distance services for many pay phones in public places as well as phones in hotels, airports, hospitals, schools and other places. ``Significant problems continue in the operator services market,'' the Federal Communications Commission said, despite its February 1989 order establishing minimum disclosure requirements for five of the companies. The commission said Friday it would use findings of an audit April 10 and 11 of 971 phones at 351 public places to prepare an investigation of the operator services industry. Congress also is considering restrictions, including price controls, on the operator companies, which have flourished since the AT&T breakup opened competition in the $12 billion market for assisted phone calls. The operator services companies contract with businesses to handle their ``dial 0'' long-distance service for telephones used by their customers. The operator companies then lease circuits from long-distance carriers such as AT&T, US Sprint and MCI, and pay a commission to their partners who own the phones. Critics claim this arrangement invites inflated charges. Before it acted last year, the commission had received thousands of complaints from travelers who said they sometimes were overcharged two or three times what their regular long-distance company would charge. They also said they weren't informed of who was handling their calls and that they got bills from places they never visited. In its 1989 order, the FCC required that the operator companies identify themselves to callers orally and that they place written notices with their names and addresses on or near the telephones they served. The companies also were prohibited from ``blocking'' callers from reaching their own long-distance companies and from billing customers' calls from cities other than the one where the call originated. Operator services officials in February told a Senate subcommittee that the industry was beginning to police itself and follow the FCC rules. But in its April 10-11 survey, the FCC said it found: _Operators identified their companies orally 87 percent of the time, but only 20 out of 971 phones fully complied with the requirement for written notices. More than 30 percent of the phones failed to identify the operator services provider, and in more than 200 cases the name on the written material was not that of the company providing the service. _Blocking of access to the customer's long-distance service occurred 40 percent of the time. ``The audit indicates that the phones surveyed vary widely in their compliance with the federal requirements and confirms the commission's assessment, based on complaints received ... that significant problems continue in the operator services market,'' the commission said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Insurance Companies Must Pay Surcharges
DOC.TEXT: A judge refused to stop the collection of about $50 million in surcharges from auto insurance companies under the state's new insurance-reform law. But state Supreme Court Justice Daniel J. O'Hern left the door open Friday for an appeal to be reviewed by the full Supreme Court next week. Under the law, the state plans to collect $1.4 billion in surcharges during the next seven years. The surcharges are intended to help reduce a $3 billion debt incurred by the Joint Underwriting Association pool for high-risk drivers. Insurance companies say the surcharges are unconstitutional because they can't charge higher premiums to cover the additional cost. Attorneys for the state say the new law does not prevent insurance companies from making a reasonable profit. But they say the insurance companies must help pay for the large high-risk-pool debt, which Gov. Jim Florio maintains the insurance industry helped create. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. initiated the appeal to block the first surcharge payment, which was due Friday. State Farm, the state's third largest insurer, was to pay $6.5 million. Florio, who advocated the reform law, praised O'Hern's ruling. ``The decision reinforces my confidence that the constitutionality of the law will be upheld,'' the governor said. ``I am pleased that we can move on with the task of bringing real relief to the state's drivers.'' David F. Snyder, an attorney for the American Insurance Association, also saw reason for optimism in the ruling. ``We are encouraged by the serious review the state Supreme Court is giving to our concerns,'' said Snyder. ``We believe the law will ultimately be determined unconstitutional.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Outfaxed Their Foes
DOC.TEXT: Investigators took on an alleged mob-led gambling operation that relied on computers and displayed a little sophistication of their own _ they tapped a fax machine. ``When they get a copy, we get a copy,'' Queens District Attorney John Santucci said Thursday after authorities claimed to have broken up a $50 million gambling ring in Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island. ``Technology is available to the criminal element,'' he said. ``We have to stay abreast of the new technology.'' Until recently, criminals were succeeding in hiding many of their transactions with computers and fax machines. But then investigators learned how to tap the fax phone line, Santucci said. In raids Wednesday and Thursday, city police and prosecutors arrested 40 men and women at 17 fake storefronts and two apartments, seized $50,000 in cash and 80 slot machines, computers and phones. ``There was a time when the work was carried in brown paper bags,'' said police Inspector Frank Biehler. ``These vast amounts of money are beyond manual means. Fax machines eliminate people having to carry gambling records through the streets.'' Infiltrating the operation was difficult because ``this is basically the first time we've found such sophisticated computer equipment in a numbers operation,'' Biehler said. Among those arrested were alleged associates of the Gambino organized crime family, including Carmelo Amato, 35, of Valley Stream, N.Y., Santucci said. The raids ``made a serious dent in the Gambino crime family,'' he said. But authorities said the raids would do little to curb the public's appetite for the illegal business. ``There's still a part of the public that insists on doing business with the illegal bookmakers,'' Santucci said. ``We close them today and unless we get really successful, they're open again tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Sheriff Gets Three Years
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced a county sheriff to three years in prison for extortion and tax evasion. Richard B. Lankford, who has been suspended as Fulton County's sheriff, maintained his innocence as U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman sentenced him Friday. Lankford apologized ``for not being better able to prove my innocence.'' Lankford must serve 27 months behind bars. He was fined $6,000. He could have gotten up to 46 years and a $1 million fine. Lankford, Georgia's first elected black sheriff, was convicted in March of two counts of extortion and two counts of tax evasion. He was acquitted on one count of attempted extortion and the jury deadlocked on 21 other counts. Prosecutors said he demanded payoffs from a jail caterer and failing to report the money on his tax returns. Lankford must surrender to federal authorities July 9 if he isn't allowed to remain free on bond during appeal. An acting sheriff was appointed to replace Lankford after his indictment. He lost his $56,000 salary upon conviction, but he retains the title of sheriff until his appeals are exhausted or his term in office ends.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet `Refuseniks' Demonstrate in Downtown Moscow
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 50 Soviet Jews who have been denied permission to emigrate rallied in downtown Moscow, demanding that their plight not be ignored as U.S. and Soviet leaders meet in Washington. ``Refuseniks are the hostages of perestroika!'' read banners and posters at the protest. ``Shame on anti-Semitism!'' The half-hour demonstration Friday on a puddle-filled square in front of the Lenin Library was timed to coincide with one in Washington. It occurred with little harassment from Soviet authorities. Two vans filled with police were parked nearby. Several plainclothes police _ who made little attempt to hide their walkie-talkies _ milled in the crowd. But only one uniformed officer walked up to the demonstrators and asked them to disperse. He walked away when protesters showed they had applied fro permission. ``Our demonstration is synchronized with a demonstration in Washington. We insist that our human rights are violated,'' said Mike Shapiro, who said he has been denied an emigration visa even though he stopped his secret work for the Soviet government more than 12 years ago. Stephen Cohen of Palm Beach, Fla., a member of the board of directors of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said there are 400 to 500 families of Jews who have been refused permission to emigrate because Soviet officials say they have knowledge of state secrets. In November, the Supreme Soviet legislature gave preliminary approval to a bill that allows emigration for virtually anyone who has entry permission from another country and no outstanding alimony obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets. It sets a limit of five years on the period a citizen can be kept from emigrating because of access to secrets. But Jewish activists claim that the bill is vaguely worded and might still be used to restrict emigration. The bill has not yet come up for a final vote. The United States is withholding action on loosening trade sanctions on the Soviet Union until the immigration law is passed. Leonid Stonov, one long-time refusenik who was told in recent weeks that he will be allowed to emigrate in August, said anti-Semitism is on the rise and that he sees a difficult future for Jews in the Soviet Union. ``All the Jewish culture, Jewish tradition, Jewish life _ everything was ruined here during the Stalin era and Brezhnev era. There is no basement, no foundation for establishing here a real Jewish life,'' he said. Mark M. Kotlyar, a refusenik from Kiev, was asked how he felt when he saw President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cheered on the streets of Washington this week. He said it was a difficult question to answer. ``On the one hand, it's important that people be friendly, that they meet our leaders, that they give them a warm reception,'' Kotlyar said. ``But on the other hand, I think that they are too rapturous about Gorbachev. He is not that good. He is not.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Won't Appeal Computer Virus Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says it won't appeal the sentence of a suspended Cornell University graduate student placed on probation for paralyzing a nationwide computer network. The Justice Department, which had sought a prison term for Robert T. Morris Jr., decided last month not to appeal the lighter sentence imposed by a federal judge in Syracuse, N.Y., on May 4. The decision, announced Friday, was made after a recommendation by Assistant Attorney General Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., head of the criminal division, officials said. Morris, 23, convicted of unleashing a computer virus in 1988 that immobilized 6,000 computers linked to a government network, was placed on three years' probation, fined $10,000 and ordered to perform 400 hours of community service. Morris was the first person convicted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. He was found guilty in January of breaking and entering the Internet Computer Network by designing and unleashing a computer virus. Under procedures that took effect in 1987, both the prosecution and defense may appeal the judge's sentence. Justice officials felt prosecutors made their point by obtaining the felony conviction, said spokesman Doug Tillett.
DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Back Drug Program Tested in Kansas City,
DOC.TEXT: Indianapolis

Federal health officials say they support a drug prevention program that focuses on changing the way communities view legal and illegal drug use, rather than just telling youngsters to say no. ``This program is unique because it utilizes all components in the community _ schools, parents, the media and community groups _ which contribute to changing the social norms for drug use and providing a healthy drug-free environment for all people,'' Charles R. Schuster, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, said Friday. Schuster's agency helped pay for an evaluation of the Midwestern Drug Abuse Prevention Research Project, a just-completed five-year study in Kansas City and Indianapolis by researchers from the University of Southern California. Researchers began tracking 5,500 teen-agers when they were in the sixth and seventh grades in 50 Kansas City schools and studied a similar group at 57 schools in Indiana. Among the major findings: _36 percent of the students who participated in the program, now high school juniors and seniors, said they drank alcohol in the last month, while 50.1 percent of those not in the program admitted the same behavior. _24.1 percent of the participating students smoked cigarettes in the last month, compared with 32 percent of those who didn't receive the program's prevention messages. _14.2 percent of the program students smoked marijuana in the past month, compared with 20.2 percent of those in a control group.
DOC.HEAD: North Testifies Before New Grand Jury Investigating Iran-Contra
DOC.TEXT: Former White House aide Oliver North testified before a newly empaneled federal grand jury that is continuing the investigation of the Iran-Contra scandal. North was accompanied into the grand jury room Friday by a prosecutor from the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. North repeatedly left the secret proceedings during an entire day of testimony to confer with his attorneys in a courthouse hallway. Walsh's office is trying to determine the precise roles that then-President Reagan, then-Vice President Bush and others played in the affair, sources familiar with the investigation said in April. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said North and former national security adviser John Poindexter were likely to be subpoenaed and granted immunity from prosecution in exchange for their grand jury testimony. North appeared in federal court a week ago in a closed session for which all records are under seal. The grand jury probing the scandal began meeting last month, after Poindexter's April felony convictions.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Conclude Emory Student Concocted Racial Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 4th graf, `Her family ...'
DOC.TEXT: Investigators suspect a black Emory University freshman faked racist threats she said she received. But prosecutors said they lacked evidence to press charges. DeKalb County Solicitor Ralph Bowden said Friday he felt premedical student Sabrina Collins needs ``counseling and treatment, not prosecution.'' Ms. Collins, 19, was hospitalized after she collapsed and became mute April 10. Her family said she had lifted a rug in her room and found the words ``die nigger die'' scribbled in nail polish on the floor. The incident ignited a campus controversy at a time of growing reports of racism at colleges around the country. Ms. Collins also had reported receiving other threats, including one in a typewritten letter sent through campus mail. But almost as soon as the Georgia Bureau of Investigation began looking into Collins' allegations, evidence suggested she staged the episodes herself, a police file released Friday said. The typewritten death threat misspelled the word ``you're,'' and the report said only Ms. Collins could have written it. The case file said ``Your' as opposed to `you're' is a grammatical mistake that Sabrina frequently makes.'' Emory police gave GBI investigators a sample of Ms. Collins' handwriting that read, ``Tammy, your the best.'' ``The typewriter used to type the letter is the same type as typewriters in the library where Sabrina works. All identifiable fingerprints on the letter were Sabrina's fingerprints. The fingerprints pattern on the letter indicates Sabrina put the letter in the typewriter and removed it,'' the report said. Ms. Collins' attorney, James Howard, was not available for comment Friday. On Thursday he maintained his client did not harass herself, and that the person responsible for the racial epithets was free to do so again and had succeeded in avoiding investigation. Emory spokeswoman Jan Gleason said university officials do not intend to press charges against Ms. Collins.

DOC.HEAD: Children Dig Up $10,000, Go on Candy Spree
DOC.TEXT: Candy sales increased suddenly in this town of 14,000 after schoolchildren shared some of $10,000 a seventh-grader found buried in a neighbor's barn. ``We've got an officer working full-time to get some of the money back,'' Clearlake Police Lt. Bob Chalk said Friday. ``But some of the money has already been spent at the Frosty Freeze and the grocery store. They're buying candy. The seventh-grader, a 13-year-old whom police would not identify, brought the packet of $20, $50 and $100 bills to Oak Hill Middle School on Thursday. It was part of $40,000 a man had buried in a metal box for the past 20 years, police said. Children probably saw the man bury something in his barn and grew curious about what they would find, police said. Principal Sue Daly said students began turning in cash on Friday. Police said about $7,000 was still missing. ``Some very honest children have been coming up to us and handing us money all day,'' Daly said. ``And police are going to the homes of some of the kids who have had big bills on them lately.'' The man who lost the money blames himself for his misfortune. ``It's just something that was stupid, bad judgment,'' he told the Lake County Record-Bee, which did not identify him. ``If a person can get back 70 percent of the money from something like this, I think they're doing pretty good,'' he added. ``It's about the same thing I would have done if I were their age.''

DOC.HEAD: Wellesley Seniors Applaud Barbara Bush, Raisa Gorbachev
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Even some students who had protested first lady Barbara Bush's selection as Wellesley College's commencement speaker praised her address, which ended with an ironic comment on first spousehood. Mrs. Bush appeared with Raisa Gorbachev at Friday's ceremony and later credited the Soviet first lady with the warm reception they received, calling her ``my secret weapon.'' Mrs. Bush stressed the importance of family life in her speech to the graduating women. But she received the loudest cheers when she closed saying, ``Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the President's spouse. I wish him well!'' One of the 575 seniors had painted on her mortar board ``Barbara Bush for President 1992.'' Another wore a picture of President and Mrs. Bush, with the first lady dressed in a suit and power tie, the president wearing a dress. Last month, 150 of Wellesley's 2,200 students signed a petition complaining that Mrs. Bush's selection as speaker ran counter to the school's philosophy that women should be honored for their own career achievements. Mrs. Bush dropped out of college to marry George Bush as World War II raged a continent away, and has been known best as a supportive wife and mother. In her speech, Mrs. Bush, who wore a black academic robe with a purple cowl, urged the graduates to pursue professional careers if they wish. But she said: ``At the end of your life, you will never regret not having passed one more test, winning one more verdict, or not closing one more deal. You will regret time not spent with a husband, a child, a friend, or a parent.'' ``I thought it was lovely _ and I was one who signed the petition,'' said Betsy Pollard, 21, a graduating senior from Pepper Pike, Ohio, as she sat with the other graduates after Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Gorbachev spoke. ``I was very moved by it. I thought she was great,'' Pollard said. Not all the protesters were appeased, though. ``Barbara Bush made choices and I respect those choices, but I think she was asked to come here because she is the wife of the president,'' said Patricia Hawkins, 32, of Deer Park, N.Y. Speaking second, Mrs. Gorbachev gave a serious, but upbeat, talk on the virtues of Soviet perestroika and the economic reforms undertaken by her husband, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Then, sounding some of the themes that Mrs. Bush hit, she spoke of ``the values that bring us together,'' including love of country and children. ``If people in the world today are more confident of a peaceful future, we have to give a good deal of credit for that to women,'' said Mrs. Gorbachev, a former university lecturer who has a Ph.D in philosophy. Seniors arriving for the ceremony found letters on their chairs urging Mrs. Bush to be a stronger proponent of women's issues. The authors also distributed armbands of purple _ the class color _ to be worn by students sympathetic with the letter. The letter said that ``in honoring Barbara Bush as our commencement speaker, we celebrate all the unknown women who have dedicated their lives to the service of others. The purple armbands you see today are in honor of these very women.'' When college President Nan Keohane cited that section in her remarks, loud applause erupted. Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush smiled broadly and clasped hands. Later, the first ladies toured downtown Boston, pausing for a stop at the Public Garden near Beacon Hill. There, Mrs. Gorbachev told reporters, ``I belong to the people who believe that children and family are very important to women.'' Mrs. Gorbachev, who has a daughter, acknowleged that many women now feel otherwise. ``It's one of the great controversies of our time,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Vaccine Protects Chimps from Human AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: A biotechnology company that nearly gave up looking for an AIDS vaccine three years ago now says it has made a vaccine that protected chimpanzees from the human AIDS virus. ``Our scientists just didn't give up,'' Jack Murphy, spokesman for Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, said Friday. ``We have fairly high hopes for this, but it will take years to develop anything that could protect humans from AIDS,'' Murphy said. ``This, right now, is more of a scientific development and certainly not a breakthrough.'' Dr. Daniel F. Hoth, who directs the AIDS division at the National Institutes of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., called the Genentech findings ``a potentially very important step.'' ``It's another brick in the wall we are building to show that an AIDS vaccine is feasible,'' Hoth said. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration must approve the vaccine for testing on humans before further research can begin, Genentech officials said. The company had virtually abandoned similar research in 1987 after making no headway. Until recently, researchers were only able to protect chimpanzees from a simian form of the AIDS virus, but not the human virus itself, Murphy said. The Genentech vaccine is among several being developed in hopes of finding a way protect people from contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, which leaves victims vulnerable to deadly cancers and ailments. More than 80,000 Americans have died from AIDS since it was first reported in the early 1980s. Vaccines don't cure a disease, but prevent those who have been vaccinated from becoming infected. The Genentech vaccine is genetically engineered, as are two other vaccines the FDA has approved for testing in people to protect them against the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. One of the vaccines, approved for testing in August 1987, was developed by MicroGeneSys Inc. of West Haven, Conn. The second, developed by Bristol-Myers-Squibb Co., of New York, was approved for human trials in November 1987. Dr. Jonas Salk, who developed a vaccine for polio, also is testing an experimental vaccine made from inactivated AIDS viruses that are replicated and don't contain anything that could be infectious. ``The hardest part about developing these vaccines is they're very specific and work against only one type of virus,'' Murphy said. Eventually, he said, a vaccine must be developed that protects against all strains of the disease. Phillip W. Berman of Genentech and Jorg Eichberg of the Southwest Biomedical Research Center of San Antonio, Texas, developed the Genentech vaccine for chimpanzees that were housed in Texas during the experiment. The research is to be published in the June 14 issue of the British medical journal Nature. Genentech got permission from the journal to announce the findings early so it could be reported at the company's upcoming annual shareholders' meeting on June 8. In the experiment, two chimpanzees immunized with the experimental vaccine and then injected with the HIV virus remained healthy six months afterward. An unvaccinated chimp became infected within seven weeks, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Enter Campus Building to End Violent Protests
DOC.TEXT: Riot police firing tear gas raided a university campus early today to end violent protests that have forced the suspension of classes for seven weeks. At the request of faculty members, about 1,500 riot police entered the campus of Sejong University in eastern Seoul and took away 116 students barricaded atop a five-story school building. The students hurled firebombs and rocks as police stormed the building, but no serious injuries were reported. On Friday, hundreds of students armed with steel bars seized the building after driving out their president, who was protected by a rival student group. A dozen students were injured in clashes between the rival groups. Sejong students have suspended classes to demand that their president resign. They also called for reforms, more student autonomy and an end to corrupt school operations. Radical students have staged similar protests on many other campuses in recent years to expel pro-government or corrupt foundations that run schools. Education authorities have accused radicals of using campuses as anti-government strongholds.

DOC.HEAD: British Columbia Truckers Block Border
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of striking British Columbia truckers snarled traffic at four U.S.-Canada border crossings to press for higher pay. But new talks were planned to try to end the week-old dispute. The truckers' Western Owners Operators Association, the trucking industry and the Teamsters Union have agreed to go back to the bargaining table, the province's solicitor general, Russ Fraser, said late Friday. He said he would name a mediator today. Fraser said he has asked truckers to stop blocking the border crossings and scale back the strike, which has halted grocery deliveries in many areas, causing spotty shortages around the province. Pickets and parked trucks blocked crossings in both directions late Friday at Blaine, Lynden, Sumas and Oroville, Wash. The independent truckers, who have been on strike since last weekend, let passenger cars and non-commercial vehicles through. Royal Canadian Mounted Police reported a bomb threat, a broken windshield and a severed brake line on one truck. Rick Sather, a member of the Canadian Western Owner-Operator's Association committee overseeing the blockade, said some violence was regrettable but expected and not encouraged by association leadership. ``Desperate people do desperate things,'' Sather said. ``There must be 2,500 guys out here now, and it's when the trucks start burning that you have to start getting worried. A few broken windshields ain't anything.'' Fraser would not say why police had not moved in to clear the blockades. ``There are things we can do if it's seen that the law is being broken consistently,'' he said, refusing to elaborate. Only spotty shortages were reported around the province, but some said lack of deliveries could make the strike felt in short order. ``I would imagine that people are starting to get a little shaky,'' said Art Tonlinson, director of services for the B.C. and Yukon Hotels Association. ``Going into tourist season, it could be disastrous.'' Canadian truckers are demanding an increase in base pay to $40 Canadian per hour. They currently earn $26 to $35 Canadian per hour, but they pay for all their own fuel and truck maintenance. Truckers say they can't meet their expenses at current rates, which they said are lower than they were 10 years ago. In U.S. dollars, the truckers demands are equivalent to $34 per hour, and their current base wages range from $22 to $29 per hour. American truckers had differing views on the blockade. Steven Boyd Vinson, of Centralia, Wash., said he didn't realize the Canadian strike meant blocked traffic. ``I figured there'd just be a bunch of guys on the side of the road yelling,'' he said, adding he didn't think the blockade was ``doing anybody any good.'' ``I'm all for it,'' said Larry Radcliff, an Oregon-based trucker. ``They've got to get their wages up.''

DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch Alleges Coors Advertising Deceptive
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch has accused its competitor Adoph Coors Co. of false advertising for implying that Coors beer comes from Rocky Mountain springs, when some of it contains Virginia water. In a recent letter to the Federal Trade Commission, the St. Louis-based Busch said, ``Coors produces liquid beer concentrate in Golden, Colorado then ships that liquid via railroad tank car more than a thousand miles east where local water is added to dilute the concentrate prior to packaging.'' ``It's a clear matter of consumer deception,'' said Busch executive vice president Michael Roarty. Coors spokeswoman Anita Russell told The Denver Post in a story today that Busch was merely trying to discredit the company in the competitive beer marketing game. Russell said the ad was accurate and that Rocky Mountain spring water is the company's ``birthright.'' She acknowledged about 14 percent of the company's 17.7 million-barrel beer production in Golden last year was shipped as concentrate to the company's Elkton, Va. plant, where water and carbonation were added before packaging. Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. is the industry leader, with about 42 percent of the U.S. beer market. Coors this year passed Stroh's to become the third brewer with 9 percent of the market. Miller Brewing Co. is second with more than 20 percent. In its complaint to the FTC, Busch referred to a recent Coors television advertising campaign in which a voice says, ``Clean, fresh, pure Rocky Mountain Spring water. Next time you reach for a beer, remember...'' Then the screen reads: ``Great Beers Start Here. Coors.'' Claude Wild, the FTC regional director in Denver, said he had not seen the Busch letter.

DOC.HEAD: Counterfeit Cash Gives New Meaning to `River Bank'
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't exactly pennies from heaven, but a juror who spotted a river of floating cash thought he stumbled upon a godsend. Instead, the 20-foot-wide bed of bills was scooped up by federal agents who proclaimed the fortune a fake. U.S. Secret Service agents believe counterfeiters dumped the $5, $10 and $20 bills into the Miami River. Many of the bills had similar serial numbers, a detail counterfeiters try to avoid, said Secret Service spokesman Paul Hackenberry. ``It must not have been good if they threw it in the river,'' said Hackenberry. But the $20,000 in fake greenbacks looked pretty real to Carlos Rangel, who noticed the bills Thursday morning as he arrived for jury duty at the Metro-Dade Justice Building. ``The money was floating all over the place,'' he said. ``I've never seen so much money in my life.'' Rangel reported his find to a bailiff, who contacted police.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The world has waited long enough, the Cold War must end.'' _ President Bush, of an array of new U.S. agreements with the Soviet Union.

``Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the president's spouse. I wish him well!'' _ first lady Barbara Bush, at the commencement of Wellesley College.

They have nothing, but they'd give you the shirt off their back.'' _ Katie Kelly, who quit her job as a movie critic on ``Entertainment Tonight'' to teach English in Vietnam, of the Vietnamese people.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Escape Figure Injured In Southern New Mexico Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crash has hospitalized pilot Charles ``Cheater'' Bella, who made headlines two years ago when his chopper was commandeered for a prison escape. Bella, 44, and passenger Robert Pounds Sr., both of El Paso, were hospitalized in stable condition after their helicopter crashed while trying to reach the top of a mountain Friday afternoon, state police spokesman Harold Covey said. Both men suffered only minor injuries. But Bella is beginning to think there's a message in his recent helicopter troubles, his wife, Carrol, said. ``I think there's someone upstairs telling us to get out of the business,'' she said. ``He told me he thought he'd had it (with flying). We've had too many bad things happen to us and helicopters.'' Bella was the pilot of a helicopter that landed inside the recreation yard of New Mexico State Penitentiary in Santa Fe on July 11, 1988. Three inmates jumped aboard and escaped. The helicopter was fired upon by prison guards and U.S. Customs agents during the escape and ensuing air chase. Bella and two of the inmates were arrested at Albuquerque International Airport. The third inmate was captured near an airport south of Los Lunas. Bella was acquitted last year of conspiracy and assisting an escape. He maintained he was forced at gunpoint to take part in the escape.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes Kill Two in Texas; Snow Falls in Rockies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Iraan is cq, 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms spawned about 10 tornadoes from Minnesota to Texas, killing two people and injuring 19. Late spring snow fell in the Rockies. One twister late Friday near the west Texas town of Iraan caused nine car accidents, and two people were killed. Mike Cox of the state Department of Public Safety said the tornado apparently struck cars on a highway. Fourteen people were injured in the accidents, including two state troopers cut by flying glass when high winds blew out the windows of their patrol car. Five more people were injured when a house collapsed, authorities said. The twister also blew down an old gymnasium and damaged the water supply in nearby McCamey, where officials warned 2,400 residents to conserve water. Also in Texas, a storm raked the Dallas-Fort Worth area with winds of up to 60 mph and dumped 2 inches of rain in about 20 minutes, the National Weather Service said. The latest storms come after spring storms and some of the worst flooding Texas has seen in 50 years killed 13 people and forced about 10,000 from their homes. Forty-six counties have been declared disaster areas. An unseasonable cold front pushing past the Rockies on Friday caused the turbulent weather. Other tornadoes were reported late Friday in Wyoming, Nebraska, South Dakota and Minnesota, the National Weather Service said.
