In northwestern Minnesota, stong winds thought to be a tornado damaged at least three farms and felled trees near Felton. Forecaster Mark Ewens in Fargo, N.D., said the winds in Minnesota were most likely a gust-front tornado, a rare twister that forms ahead of storm fronts. ``They're small, weak tornadoes that nonetheless cause a lot of damage,'' Ewens said. In South Dakota, twisters were spotted in central and eastern parts of the state, but no damage was immediately reported. Severe thunderstorms also crossed the state, bringing up to 3 inches of rain in some areas. Severe thunderstorms spawned five tornadoes and golf-ball size hail in central Nebraska, the weather service said. Five farm houses were heavily damaged in Merna, and minor damage was reported southwest of Sargent. A funnel cloud was spotted near Cheyenne, Wyo., but dissipated quickly and no damage was reported. But thunderstorms dumped as much as 4 inches of rain. Snow fell in the Big Horn Mountains and was expected in northern Colorado mountains. ``It is unusual for this time of year. It's not inconceivable, but it is unusual,'' forecaster Jim Hatten said.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Send Asbestos Victims Fund Back to Bankruptcy Court
DOC.TEXT: Two judges have ordered the overhaul of a financially ailing trust fund designed to compensate more than 130,000 victims of asbestos-related illnesses. A federal judge and a New York state judge said Friday the fund, set up by the Manville Corp., was out of money and suggested the company advance it $200 million to $300 million so it can resume payments to victims. In a joint order, the judges ordered Manville's bankruptcy case reopened to overhaul the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust. The judges ordered the trust to make changes in 10 days and said that if the bankruptcy court did not resolve the payment plan they would impose their ruling at a hearing on July 9. The trust was formed from the company's 1988 reorganization, six years after it was driven into bankruptcy court by lawsuits over production of asbestos, the insulation and building material found to cause severe and sometimes fatal illnesses. The trust came under fire last month because of a cash shortage induced by more claims, larger payouts and quicker settlements than expected. The trust told the judges that claimants filing this year wouldn't get paid until 2004. ``Many more than 100,000 claimants all over the country and the limited assets cry out for a more workable and compassionate system,'' U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein and New York State Supreme Court Judge Helen E. Freedman said in a joint order. The judges are supervising nearly 500 asbestos lawsuits against the trust and other defendants stemming from work at the Brooklyn Navy Yard dating to the 1940s. Last month, the judges sharply criticized trust management and said the bankruptcy court could lift an injunction barring asbestos victims from suing Manville directly. Currently, only the trust can be sued. On Friday, they supported keeping the injunction in place if changes in the trust are made. As part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, Manville placed $2.5 billion in assets, mostly stock, into the trust. The company also agreed to contribute $75 million annually beginning in 1991 plus 20 percent of annual net income from 1992 until all claims are paid. Trust managers told the judges this week it had paid out almost all of its $800 million in cash. They said the fund has not been mismanaged, denying claims that hundreds of millions of dollars were paid to a few plaintiffs' lawyers. The judges said more than 130,000 remaining claims require an estimated $6.5 billion, and with incoming claims and costs, the trust needs at least $7.5 billion. But the trust now is worth only about $1.5 billion, they said. The trust has paid an average of about $42,000 on each of the first 22,000 claims plus 8 percent administrative costs, the judges said. Denver-based Manville issued a statement that it was pleased the judges supported continuing the injunction against lawsuits against the company. The company, which makes fiberglass and forest, construction and other products, said it is ``willing to discuss issues related to cash flow and liquidity of the trust.'' It declined further comment on the court order. A spokesman for the Washington, D.C.-based trust said all officials were out of town or in meetings and could not comment on the ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Wind and Rain Prevail in West, Plains
DOC.TEXT: Wind and rain prevailed early today in the West and the Plains. Fair weather blessed parts of the Southeast and New England. Georgia, North Dakota, Oregon and Washington state received rain early today. Thunderstorms were predicted for later today in a band from Montana through the central United States and south to Texas. Summer-like sun and mild temperatures were expected to continue today in New York and Vermont, followed by rain later in the week. Severe thunderstorms spawned about 10 tornadoes from Minnesota to Texas on Friday. Late spring snow fell in the Rockies and hail battered Texas. The Dallas-Fort Worth area was whipped by winds of up to 60 mph and drenched by 2 inches of rain in about 20 minutes, the National Weather Service said. Caribou, Maine, tied a high temperature record for the date Friday with a reading of 82 degrees. Other reports at 3 a.m. EDT: _East: Albany, N.Y. 56 fair; Atlanta 68 showers; Boston 62 fair; Buffalo 59 fair; Charleston, S.C. 74 partly cloudy; Chattanooga 68 cloudy; Cincinnati 70 hazy; Cleveland 67 cloudy; Detroit 69 hazy; Hatteras 68 fair; Jacksonville 68 foggy; Key West 81 fair; Knoxville 62 foggy; Macon 71 cloudy; Miami 80 fair; New York 63 fair; Philadelphia 63 fair; Pittsburgh 64 fair; Portland, Maine 59 partly cloudy; Richmond 67 hazy; Tampa 75 fair; Washington, D.C. 66 fair. _Central: Birmingham 72 cloudy; Bismarck 54 rain; Chicago 76 fair; Denver 49 partly cloudy; Des Moines 69 fair; Fort Worth 80 cloudy; Indianapolis 72 hazy; Kansas City 71 windy; Little Rock 76 fair; Louisville 71 hazy; Memphis 74 fair; Nashville 71 cloudy; New Orleans 79 fair; North Platte 53 windy; Oklahoma City 72 windy; Omaha 71 windy; Rapid City 52 windy; St. Louis 73 partly cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 75 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 54 fair; San Antonio 82 partly cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 59 fair; Anchorage 54 cloudy; Boise 49 partly cloudy; Casper 38 partly cloudy; Fairbanks 66 showers; Great Falls 46 windy; Honolulu 76 partly cloudy; Las Vegas 65 fair; Los Angeles 61 fair; Medford 51 cloudy; Pendleton 53 cloudy; Phoenix 80 fair; Portland, Ore. 56 rain; Reno 56 cloudy; Salt Lake City 48 fair; San Diego 62 fair; San Francisco 56 fair; Seattle 51 cloudy; Spokane 47 rain. _International: Calgary 46 showers; Montreal 55 fair; Ottawa 57 partly cloudy; Regina 59 showers; Toronto 61 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 59 rain; Merida 79 fair; San Juan 79 showers.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $28.7 Million in AIDS Case
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded $28.7 million in the case of a 5-year-old boy who contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion. The boy's lawyer said he believed it was the largest award ever in an AIDS-related case. The jury Friday awarded $26.7 million to the boy, Alex Edwards, and $1 million each to his parents, Roy and Pat Edwards. The jury on May 23 found Dr. Abraham Kuruvilla and his clinic, Neonatology Associates Ltd., liable for ordering the transfusion to correct severe respiratory problems caused by fluid in the lungs. The Edwards' lawyer, R. Douglas Dalton, had argued that Kuruvilla should have received consent from the boy's parents for the transfusion. The boy's father testified that the couple expressed concerns about AIDS and offered to donate their own blood when the boy was given a previous transfusion. But Kuruvilla's lawyer, Duane Olson, said Mrs. Edwards signed a consent form letting doctors treat her son as they saw fit. Dalton said the largest previous verdict he knew of in an AIDS-related case was $12 million awarded March 8 in Columbus, Ohio, to an 8-year-old girl who contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion. Olson said he would seek to overturn the award. Two other defendants, a blood bank and the hospital where the transfusion was performed, settled out of court. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a fatal disease caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Floodwaters Uncover Centuries-Old Canoe
With PM-Storms Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Recent flooding along the Red River unearthed a remarkably well-preserved canoe buried for 250 years beneath tons of silt. The nearly 25-foot long dugout is carved out of a single log of what appears to be a cottonwood tree. It has a square hull, and only a part of the bow and a section of bottom are missing. ``This is a phenomenal find,'' said Bonnie McKee, a board member of The Archaeological Conservancy in Dallas. Dale Moore, a farmer in this community about 100 miles northeast of Dallas, made the discovery during a Memorial Day picnic with his family. Moore and his daughter were fishing when they found the canoe upside down on a dried-out section of the river bank, he said. ``I stopped and said, `Have you ever seen a square tree?''' he said. Moore, who enlisted the help of four friends to move the canoe, is keeping it soaked down under burlap. Eventually it will undergo a process by which moisture is slowly removed and replaced by a strengthening solvent. J.C. Blaine, a museum consultan and specialist in early American artifacts, said: ``We very rarely get a wooden artifact in this kind of shape. Not only that, but this is the largest one of its kind.'' The canoe, which weighs about 600 pounds, is covered with hack marks. ``They appear to be metal tool marks rather than stone, which would mean that it was made either by Frenchmen or by Indians who had trade with the French,'' Blaine said. He said the canoe likely comes from between 1730 and 1740 when such tools were available. ``The Indians had lots of wooden tools, but we never get to see them unless something gets washed out of the river,'' Blaine said. Glass and metal stay, but wood disintegrates unless it is in water.'' Blaine said the deteriorated cells of the wood were being held together by the water in them, which also prevented bacteria from attacking. ``This never should have come out of the water,'' said Blaine. ``Then again, if it hadn't we wouldn't be able to see it.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Trustee, U.S. Attorney Meet Over Grand Jury Probe
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosecutor met with the man overseeing bankrupt Eastern Airlines to head off a possible indictment of the airline for allegedly falsifying maintenance records, a source said. The bankruptcy trustee, Martin R. Shugrue, met Friday afternoon with U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney, according to a highly placed law enforcement source who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Maloney did not return several calls and declined to comment on the investigation earlier in the week. But the source said Shugrue ``was just trying to convince him not to indict the airline.'' Shugrue reportedly fears any indictments against Eastern would scare away passengers and possibly torpedo his efforts to save the airline. ``This is a meeting we've been trying to arrange for quite some time and it's to present the facts in the case, said Robin Matell, an Eastern spokesman in Miami. ``I don't know the nature of the talks.'' The Daily News reported Friday that the 10-month-old federal grand jury investigation _ concerned with the airline's safety and maintenance procedures at Kennedy and LaGuardia airports _ is nearly complete and that several indictments are expected. The panel is looking into allegations that Eastern altered maintenance and safety records at the airports as well as questionable practices at the Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta, the airline's largest hub. One former Eastern official at another airport said mechanics were routinely certifying that they had tested for water in fuel tanks when they had not done so. Large amounts of water in a fuel tank could cause an engine to stall. According to the News, federal investigators were looking into whether top Eastern officials were aware that Eastern managers at Kennedy and La Guardia allegedly ordered mechanics to disregard safety guidelines and then falsified logbooks to show that proper checks were made. Shugrue was appointed trustee to run Eastern as Frank Lorenzo's replacement as the airline tries to pull itself out bankruptcy proceedings. The Machinists union at Eastern has been on strike since March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Karl Marx City Gets Name Change
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Karl Marx City will now be known as Chemnitz, but the previous name hasn't been completely relegated to the history books. City council members on Friday formally adopted the name Chemnitz, as the city was known before the former Communist government changed it in 1953 to honor the founder of modern socialism. However, the council decided that the city of 309,000 will be known by both names for a one-year transitional period. In an April referendum, more than 76 percent of the people voting said they wanted the city's old name back. Chemnitz is about 75 miles south of Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor's Death Blamed on Overdose of Potent Pain-Killer
DOC.TEXT: A 29-year-old doctor died from a self-inflicted overdose of a potent pain-killer that has claimed the lives of 18 other U.S. doctors in the past three years, hospital officials said. The doctor, David Leyda, died at Hartford Hospital on April 25 after taking fentanyl, a synthetic narcotic 200 times more potent than morphine, said Dr. James J. Richter, head of the hospital's department of anesthesiology. ``It's extremely potent, it produces a quick high, and it is addictive,'' said Dr. James O'Brien, director of the drug and alcohol treatment center at the University of Connecticut Health Center. ``Unfortunately, we have a percentage of doctors who abuse it,'' O'Brien said Friday. ``In the last two or three years it's become a drug of choice among doctors.'' Forms of the drug, including one sold as China White, also have shown up on the streets in recent years. Leyda, of Ottumwa, Iowa, was in the third year of a four-year residency program in anesthesiology at Hartford Hospital. He was found in a private waiting room at the hospital with a syringe nearby. There was no indication that he committed suicide, and hospital officials and the state medical examiner's office said they consider the death an accidental overdose. Richter said the department did not know before his death that Leyda had a drug problem, but concluded that he did after a subsequent investigation in which Leyda's apartment was searched and drug paraphernalia was found. Richter said Leyda was the 19th anesthesiologist in the U.S. to die from a fentanyl overdose in the past three years. Because of their easy access to potent drugs, anesthesiologists are considered more likely to abuse drugs than are other doctors, Richter said. Fentanyl is so potent it can be taken in tiny doses that are undetectable in urine tests. The potency means the risk of overdose is great. ``It has a very narrow safety margin,'' Ricther said. ``The danger zone is unpredictable.'' Richter said the department lectures residents once a year on the dangers of drug abuse and has in place a strict system in which doctors must account for all of the drugs they are given from the hospital pharmacy. ``The problem is that you're dealing with extremely bright people and they can conceal their behavior to a great extent,'' Richter said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Probe Crashes
DOC.TEXT: A 2{-ton experimental NASA probe crashed and sustained about $2 million damage when a wind gust foiled its landing. Dozens of batteries and electronic devices were strewn on the ground at the landing site, according to Jack Tueller, a scientist with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who helped build the probe. The probe, used to measure radioactivity in the upper atmosphere, had made two successful experimental flights over Australia in 1988, officials said. A wind gust apparently caught it as it touched down Friday in eastern Arizona. ``It was supposed to land very softly,'' said Tueller. ``In the two landings in Australia, there was very little damage.'' The probe can measure faint emissions from stars, and ``was putting us on the cutting edge of astronomy,'' Tueller said. ``That's why it's so sad to see it smashed up.'' The gamma-ray imaging spectrometer is one of two in the world, Tueller said. The other belongs to the University of California in San Diego. NASA engineer Al Huters said the probe cost $2 million to $3 million to build. He said the device rides on a steel gondola about 10 feet square and is carried aloft by a helium-filled balloon. It was launched Thursday morning from an airport at Fort Sumner, N.M., and reached an altitude of more than five miles. NASA workers loaded the wreckage onto a flatbed trailer-truck and said the probe would be taken to the Goddard Space Center in Maryland for repairs.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Lost Lovers Meet Again Through Dating Service
DOC.TEXT: What an angry father put asunder more than three decades ago a modern matchmaking service has restored. Judy Musso and William Vogue plan to be married years after they stopped seeing each other because her father disapproved. ``It's almost a storybook thing,'' said the Rev. Douglas Stearns of the DeSoto Presbyterian Church who will preside over ceremonies on Sept. 1. Ms. Musso said her mother is happy she has found Vogue again, and so are her two sons and his two daughters. Her father died in 1979. The couple fondly recalls when they first met 32 years ago at a charity ball in San Diego. ``I was 31 and she was 19,'' said Vogue. ``I'll never forget it. It was May 17, 1958. She had on a light blue formal gown overlaid with lace. And she had a tiara on her head.'' But after nine months of secret meetings, Vogue left the state and lost contact with her. They both married three times and raised families. Their paths crossed in March when they became members of a Dallas area dating service. Ms. Musso, 51, picked Vogue's voice recording, but had no idea she had met him before, even after talking an hour on the phone with him. ``We knew each other by different names,'' Ms. Musso said. Vogue, 63, had changed from Ray Wilhelm Voge to William Ray Vogue, and he knew Ms. Musso by her maiden name, Hotchkiss. But when Vogue picked her up for dinner, she instantly recognized him. ``My heart almost stopped,'' Vogue said. ``We didn't stop holding each other for 15 minutes.'' Vogue asked to marry her after five hours, and five days later she had moved into his home. ``This time it's for good,'' Vogue said.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Troops in Show Of Force Against Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Filipino troops backed by armored vehicles staged a show of force today against Commmunist rebels after U.S. officials ordered American troops to stay on their base for security reasons. About 500 troops and police motored through the streets brandishing M-16 rifles and carrying banners denouncing the rebel New People's Army. The motorcade passed in front of the U.S.-run Clark Air Base and through nearby neighborhoods of Angeles, about 50 miles north of the capital Manila, where many rebels live and operate. Police Lt. Col. Julius Yarcia announced the formation of neighborhood vigilante groups to help fight the rebels. ``We just want to convince the people that we are willing to fight and that we have the manpower and the firepower to fight the enemy,'' Yarcia told reporters. On Friday, U.S. officials announced renewed restrictions on the 20,300 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at Clark, one of six U.S. bases in the Philippines. Officials cited an undisclosed security threat in the area, where Communist rebels killed two U.S. airmen last month. ``Local, current conditions dictate we take action right now,'' said the spokesman, Lt. Col. Ron Rand. He did not elaborate in his announcement broadcast by the U.S. military's television station. Today, Rand said security patrols around the sprawling base have been doubled to protect American lives. Philippine intelligence sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said rebel troop movements Friday prompted the U.S. decision. Yarcia said that in addition to the civilian vigilantes, two companies of troops from the elite Philippine Constabulary Regional Special Action Force would be sent to Angeles to augment the three battalions stationed in the city. One week ago, U.S. officials relaxed restrictions imposed after rebels killed Airmen John Raven and James Green on May 13, one day before U.S. and Philippine officials began talks on the future of the six U.S. bases. Troops had since been allowed off-post between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m., but Rand said the ``limited liberty'' arrangement is indefinitely suspended. Communist guerrillas have fought for 21 years to establish a Marxist state and have pledged to continue attacking Americans until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. Eight Americans have died in politically motivated violence in the Philippines since April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Prepares To Leave Hospital, Begin European, U.S. Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to CORRECT that cyst related to bladder; Pickup 3rd, `Dr. Gus...'
DOC.TEXT:
African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, hospitalized for the removal a benign cyst, said today he felt fine, and prepared for a six-week tour of Europe, the United States and Africa. Mandela, looking tired after seven days at Johannesburg's Park Lane Clinic, held a brief news conference with his surgeon to discuss the removal of a non-malignant cyst related to his bladder.
Dr. Gus Gecelter said, ``There is no question that the cyst is anything but inflammatory.'' He said Mandela, 71, had experienced no adverse effects from the operation. ``He had no problems before or after the operation,'' said Gecelter, who has attended Mandela for several years. Routine medical checks to Mandela's heart, lungs and abdomen were ``perfectly normal,'' he said. ``He is a very fit young man for his age,'' Gecelter said. Mandela said he felt ``on top of the world.'' Mandela was expected to leave the clinic this weekend. He begins his tour of African, European and American nations on Monday. The trip includes stops in the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Ireland, Italy, Botswana, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique. Mandela said he would use the trip to thank the international community for helping secure his release in February after 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. His release came under political reforms implemented by President F.W. de Klerk. He also said the pressure applied by foreign nations contributed to the release of other political prisoners and helped bring about the first talks between the ANC and the white-led government. ``I will also ask the international community to maintain sanctions, because whatever de Klerk has said, it is up to now merely rhetoric, nothing further has been done _ all the pillars of apartheid are still in place,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Official Says U.S. Embassy Was Target of Raid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with alleged guerrilla plans to fire rockets at U.S. Embassy. Pickup 7th, `In a...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Heavily armed Palestinian guerrillas who were intercepted off the Israeli coast this week intended to attack the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv, a senior Israeli official said. Maps seized from the 16 guerrillas on Wednesday indicated they were headed for Tel Aviv's densely populated beachfront hotel district, where the embassy is located, the official said Friday on condition of anonymity. ``During the debriefing we conducted ... it was established that the U.S. Embassy was one of the targets in the vicinity of the hotel district,'' he said. An army spokesman said he was not authorized to comment on the report. An Israeli military analyst said today that the guerrillas planned to fire Soviet-made Katyusha rockets at the embassy. ``We know that at least one speedboat, or maybe two, had orders, after onloading their men in the Tel Aviv Marina, to go back to sea and launch from the sea the rockets on the American Embassy,'' said Ben-Ishai, military correspondent for the daily Yediot Ahronot, speaking on Israel radio. But Ben-Ishai said the rockets probably could not have hit their target, located in the hotel district near the marina. U.S. Embassy spokesman Don Cofman today refused comment on the reports and would not say whether the embassy had stepped up security. In condemning the aborted raid Wednesday, the State Department left open the possibility the incident could affect the U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. That dialogue began after PLO leader Yasser Arafat denounced terrorism in 1988. The Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction believed to have its main headquarters in Baghdad, Iraq, has claimed responsibility for the abortive raid but said it was not aimed at civilians. Arafat has denied Israeli charges that the PLO itself was involved in the raid, but he has not condemned it. In a statement Friday in Baghdad, the Front said its guerrillas had instructions to hit military sites only in a 50-mile-wide area around Tel Aviv. The Front is headed by Mohammad Abbas, known by his nom de guerre Abul Abbas. A member of the PLO's executive committee, he masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in which an elderly American was shot and killed. Israel claims Libya helped mount Wednesday's strike, which was aimed at crowded Israeli beaches. Israel's military intelligence chief, in an interview with the Yediot Ahronot daily, provided the most detailed account yet of that alleged involvement. Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak said the guerrillas trained in a camp set aside for them by Libyan authorities on the Mediterranean coast. ``The investigation shows beyond doubt that Libyan military personnel were involved in all stages of preparation,'' Shahak said in the newspaper interview. But a Libyan official denied Libyan involvement in the raid. Gadallah Azouz el-Talhi, Libya's foreign minister, said: ``Some news media claimed that a Libyan ship carried the speedboats that tried to go to shore. Libya has no connection at all with the operation,'' el-Talhi said during a visit to Egypt. The Libyan ambassador to Lebanon warned today that the United States ``would definitely be held responsible'' for any Israeli retaliatory attack on Libya. In an interview on Lebanon's Communist-run Voice of the People radio, Libyan Ambassador Ashour Fortas claimed Israel was consulting ``with the United States for an aggression against Libya.'' Israeli forces in helicopter gunships and patrol boats foiled Wednesday's attempted raid as 16 guerrillas headed for the coast in speedboats. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. No Israelis were injured. On the day of the incident, beaches and beachfront hotels were crowded with Israelis celebrating the Jewish holiday of Shavuot.

DOC.HEAD: Uniformed Men Take Away Reporter For Western Media, Govt Denies Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with government denying arrest and calling it kidnapping. Pickup 4th graf `Jameel was...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: An Indian journalist was taken from his home today by men wearing Indian army uniforms, witnesses said. The government denied the military was holding him and called it a kidnapping. Yusuf Jameel, who was covering the separatist movement in Kashmir for Western news organizations, was taken away from his Srinagar home in Pratap Bagh district, said Jameel's servant, Hakim Din. Din said he woke up Jameel after answering the doorbell rung by two men wearing army uniforms, demanding to meet the reporter. Jameel's photographer, Mehraj Uddin, who also lives in the house, said Jameel, while getting dressed, told him: ``I am being arrested by the army. Take care of yourself.'' A state government spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said the security forces are ``nowhere involved in this alleged disappearance'' and called the action an attempt at ``maligning the administration and the security forces.'' Police registered the case as a kidnapping and began investigating ``to trace out Mr. Jameel and culprits,'' the spokesman said. Din and Uddin said Jameel was driven away in a jeep that looked similar to those used by the army. Another vehicle that resembled an army pickup followed the jeep and both vehicles were full of men wearing soldier's uniforms, they said. Other witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the men were armed but did not use violence. Jameel was covering the bloody Moslem separatist movement for Reuters, the British news agency, and the British Broadcasting Corp. He has been working for Reuters for at least two years and for the BBC for about five. He also reports for the The Telegraph, a major Indian daily published in Calcutta. India, which launched a crackdown on Kashmiri separatists in January, has discouraged foreign reporters from traveling to the area. At least 486 people have been killed since the crackdown began. Most were militants or supporters of the campaign for the separation of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem-majority state, from predominantly Hindu India. Kashmir was divided along a still-disputed frontier between India and Pakistan after British colonial India became independent in 1947 and was partitioned along religious lines. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the territory, in 1947 and 1965. About 64 percent of the 6 million people in Indian-governed Jammu-Kashmir are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Kills British Soldier in West Germany, Another in England
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with IRA claim of responsibility. Pickup 3rd pvs, `There is...'
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army today claimed responsibility for murdering a British soldier outside his home in West Germany and another soldier on a railway platform in England. ``Active Service Units of the Irish Republican Army carried out two separate operations against British military personnel in England and West Germany last night,'' the IRA said in a statement issued in Dublin, Ireland. ``While British troops remain in Ireland such attacks will continue,'' said the statement distributed to news media. IRA claims of responsibility for attacks in Britain and Europe normally are made in the Irish capital. Police in Dortmund, West Germany, said two suspects eluded a chase early today after gunmen killed a British army major. One police officer was shot in the foot during the chase. In the central England city of Lichfield, police were looking for two men who shot three soldiers in a daylight attack at a railway station. A 19-year-old soldier was killed, and the gunmen fled across the tracks, police said. The other two soldiers survived the attack. Earlier today, Defense Secretary Tom King indicated he believed the IRA was responsible for both killings. ``There is no argument or reason in this. It is simply that they are out to kill,'' King told Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. ``They are out to cover the humiliation of their mistake in killing two young Australians in Holland ...'' The attack in Germany came six days after an IRA unit shot and killed two Australian tourists in Roermond in The Netherlands. The IRA said the victims had been mistaken for British soldiers. The Defense Ministry said Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee of the Royal Artillery was shot today as he drove with his wife from the military base in Dortmund, West Germany to their home. Dillon-Lee was shot several times in the head after he stopped his car in front of his house, the ministry said. He died immediately, but his wife was not injured. German police said one of their officers was shot and wounded as police cars chased the gunmen, who escaped. In Britain, meanwhile, police said they were looking for two men who fled the scene of the shooting at Lichfield City train station, 100 miles northwest of London. Police initially were reported to have worn masks, but Lichfield police said today it appeared neither man was masked. Scotland Yard said an anti-terrorist squad was assisting with the investigation. Chief Inspector Tony Johnson of the Staffordshire Police said the shooting ``bears the hallmarks of an IRA attack.'' He did not elaborate. Authorities said the three soldiers were shot while waiting on a platform for a train Friday. Witnesses said the gunfire sent commuters fleeing. The three soldiers, who were in training at the Lichfield army base, were waiting for a train to nearby Birmingham for weekend leave, said Detective Chief Superintendent Malcolm Bevington. He said two men appeared on the platform, pulled out handguns and shot the soldiers, then jumped onto the tracks, ran across the line and through a builder's yard opposite the station. The Ministry of Defense identified the slain soldier as 19-year-old Pvt. William Robert Davies of Pontarddulais, south Wales. It identified the wounded soldiers as Robert Parkin, 20, and Neil Evans, 19. A British Rail employee who witnessed the shooting said he jumped across the tracks to try to help the soldiers. ``I and a station employee tried to staunch the flow of blood from the chest of one of the soldiers,'' he said. Although the soldiers were dressed in civilian clothes, their hairstyles and manner of conduct indicated they were in the military, he said. On Sunday, the IRA killed two Australian lawyers traveling in Roermond after mistaking them for British soldiers. The IRA later expressed deep regret over the error. The Australians, who lived in London, were traveling in a British-registered car, one with his wife, the other with his girlfriend. The IRA wants to unite the predominantly Protestant Northern Ireland with the Catholic Republic of Ireland in a single socialist state.

DOC.HEAD: Louisville Seeks to Recruit Black Faculty
DOC.TEXT: University of Louisville President Donald Swain has established a system of cash payments and other incentives aimed at increasing the number of black faculty members at the school. ``My intention is to move us ahead quickly in the next five years,'' Swain said in an interview. He said, for example, that he will offer $10,000 to academic departments that not only hire black faculty members but keep them at the Kentucky campus for a sustained period. Similar programs are under way at other American schools. The Louisville initiative represents ``a variation on a theme that others are using,'' says Reginald Wilson of the American Council of Education. The University of Michigan began in 1987 to target a percentage of its budget to hiring minority faculty. Wilson said that since then, Michigan has hired 77 minority faculty members, including 40 blacks. Miami University in Ohio also has ``significantly increased'' its black faculty, Wilson said. He said the school launched the project by funding five positions out of his budget. Wilson said that Eastern Illinois University gives recognition and monetary awards each year to the departments that have been successful in increasing minority staff. At the University of California at Santa Barbara, the number of minority faculty members increased from 7 percent to 14 percent over the last 15 years. But Chancellor Barbara Uehling said bidding wars, in which recruiters offer high salaries, promotions and sometimes tenure, make it difficult to keep them. ``These programs are required to get these institutions motivated to do something,'' said Wilson, who noted that in the 1960s colleges and universities were motived by ``moral suasion.'' ``The major appeal is economics now,'' he said. Swain acknowledged that his ``action-oriented presidential initiative,'' which also includes providing financial support to help candidates complete doctoral degrees, was prompted by racial tensions on campus. Also, Swain said ``Kentucky remains under a federal mandate to end the last vestiges of segregation in higher education _ this means specifically adding African-American faculty.'' ``Over and above legal requirements, we must attract more African-American faculty to serve the needs of the diverse racial and ethnic groups _ the largest of which is African-American _ who look to U. of L. for educational opportunity,'' he said. The university had an enrollment of 23,180 in the fall of 1989, including 2,666 members of minority groups. Black students totaled 1,985, about 8.6 percent. Of the 1,650 faculty members, 172 were minorities, including 36 blacks, said Denise Fitzpatrick, director of public information. Swain said that faculty affirmative action, while making some progress in the last nine years, has not ``made sufficient progress, especially in attracting and retaining African-American faculty.'' ``I would like the University of Louisville to be a leader in affirmative action,'' he added. For most colleges and universities, recruiting and retaining minority faculty members has become increasingly important. The American Council on Education said minority representation on faculties nationwide remains below 11 percent. Between 1977 and 1985, the number of black faculty members barely increased and the black share of all faculty positions dropped from 4.4 percent to 4.2 percent. In 1988, only four blacks in the entire United States received doctorates in mathematics. Swain said the goal of his initiative is to ``remove all obstacles so that people won't have any excuses about the procedure.'' Among other things, an ``African-American Faculty Incentive Fund'' will be established to encourage academic departments to hire and retain black faculty. In disciplines with few blacks, a black candidate can be offered a junior faculty position if the qualifications are similar to white candidates. The initiative also includes providing financial support and a faculty positions for black doctoral candidates who have completed all the requirements except the dissertation. A ``grow our own African-American faculty'' program also will begin this year to identify promising undergraduates and encourage them to seek doctoral degrees at the university. The best qualified will be offered fellowships and other financial benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Talk Show Host Whips Up Frenzy Over Thrifts
DOC.TEXT: For a studio audience more accustomed to talk of S&M than S&Ls, it was complicated stuff. ``Tomorrow, male strippers _ it will be a lot easier,'' talk show titan Phil Donahue told the audience as they struggled with the complexities of the escalating savings and loan crisis. (He was only teasing: the following show will be on the Ku Klux Klan.) Donahue took on the daunting task of bringing the S&L crisis to Main Street in a program taped Friday in the nation's capital. ``All we've got right now is the worst financial scandal in the history of our beloved democratic experiment,'' he said. ``You and I are in this.'' By the time the hour-long show was over, Donahue had whipped the audience into a frenzy over the thousands of dollars each of them, as taxpayers, will pay to cover losses to depositors in hundreds of failed thrifts. ``How much of the $400 billion S&L bailout will you pay for?'' was the question posed by the show, to be broadcast in most cities on Tuesday. The answer: more than $3,000 for each U.S. taxpayer over the next three decades, including interest. Deregulation of the thrift industry ``was the best thing that happened to the Mob since Prohibition,'' said Stephen Pizzo, one of Donahue's guests and a co-author of ``Inside Job: The Looting of America's Savings and Loans''. Pizzo said organized crime took advantage of liberalized regulations for thrifts by taking out big real estate loans that went bad. ``The money didn't go to widows and orphans,'' said Houston Post reporter Pete Brewton, another guest. ``It went to the political, criminal and business establishment of this country.'' (Loud applause.) The 200 or so ``ordinary'' people in the studio at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce building were getting worked up. They almost seemed ready to march on the White House, a stone's throw away across Lafayette Park. ``Take the money, put it under your pillow, and know where it is in the morning,'' a young man in the audience advised. A woman asked angrily why the press hasn't been covering the S&L issue more vigorously. Outside, the streets were choked with TV trucks and reporters covering the summit between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Just down the street, about 70 protesters picketed the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency established last year to manage the bailout, for not offering more subsidized housing to the poor from projects seized from failed S&Ls. Donahue's audience hissed and booed when William Greider, the other guest, suggested that government officials believe the American public is ``too stupid'' to understand the S&L debacle. ``The political assumption in this town is that you all will not get aroused enough,'' said Greider, the national editor of Rolling Stone magazine. Donahue threw more fuel on the fire by showing a videotape of Neil Bush, one of the president's sons, being questioned by Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II, D-Mass., at a recent hearing of the House Banking Committee. Regulators have alleged that Bush's role as a former director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that went bust for $1 billion, involved a conflict of interest with his other business interests. ``These are exactly the kinds of incestuous relationships that led to this kind of looting,'' said Pizzo. After the show, a spokesman for the U.S. League of Savings Institutions said industry's remaining health thrifts are helping pay for the cleanup, in the form of higher deposit insurance premiums and other charges. ``We deplore the criminal elements that invaded the savings institutions business,'' League spokesman Jim Eberle said in a telephone interview. ``We are feeling the effects of the criminal elements and the high-fliers, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Rusting Cargo Ships Still Part of Strategic Naval Reserve
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Only 40 miles from Navy's modern Atlantic Fleet, rows of rusting hulks that had their fill of salt, sun and war await the call to carry military cargo in a national emergency. Taxpayers get the bill for the 331-ship National Defense Reserve Fleet, with its dilapidated-looking World War II and post-war cargo ships, some with grass growing through wooden deck planks. Nobody can predict with certainty how many of the drab, mostly gray ships _ lined up here on the James River and two other main locations _ will be able to sail. But military experts still consider this fleet a strategic asset to move the Army's heavy equipment, even while they're busy writing plans to scrap much newer equipment as the communist threat diminishes. The government-built ``Victory'' ships of World War II and their companions in the fleet no longer have to worry about German U-boats, but they're taking salvos from members of the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation, business opportunities and energy. Chairman Ron Wyden, D-Ore., and ranking Republican William S. Broomfield of Michigan have scheduled a hearing on the issue Monday, saying they want to determine whether the fleet is a waste of money. They said the ships could be turned into moneymakers if Congress directs the ships be sold to U.S. salvage firms. ``The peace dividend is going down the drain with the rust of these federal assets,'' Wyden said prior to the hearing. Broomfield commented, ``I would hate to have the defense of our country depend on these ships, because in the time it would take to renovate them, the war would be over.'' A Pentagon official and an official of the Transportation Department's Maritime Administration (MARAD), which maintains the fleet, disagreed. ``This is not going to be pretty'' said Michael Delpercio, MARAD director of ship operations. ``Everybody looks at the ships externally and says, `What a bunch of crap.' But internally, they're in good shape.'' Jonathan D. Kaskin, director of the Navy's Strategic Sealift Division, added, ``This is the only way that we have'' to move heavy Army equipment that can't go in modern cargo container ships. He cited a decline in available commercial U.S. cargo vessels and said it would be prohibitive to build enough military airlift capacity to hold the same amount of tanks, trucks, ammunition and other equipment. Only 96 vessels in the 331-ship fleet are classified as the Ready Reserve, ships that are supposed to be able to carry the Army's equipment on five to 20 days' notice. Forty-two other ships in the fleet are so old that they will be used as target practice for Navy gunners, sunk to become reefs or traded to salvage companies for newer ships. The Maritime Administration says it is spending $6.7 million in fiscal 1990 to maintain the older part of the fleet and another $89 million for the Ready Reserve portion. The agency is requesting $225 million for the Ready Reserve in fiscal 1991, part of a plan to increase that component from 96 to 142 ships. Wyden said consideration of this request will give Congress ``a chance to ask some hard questions'' about the fleet, and Broomfield already has written Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that ``the cost and time required to restore these ships far outweighs their usefulness.'' Some ships in the fleet previously have been sold to salvage firms for as much as $1.5 million, Delpercio said. The buyers were foreign companies that were able, with cheaper labor, to underprice U.S. firms in the bidding. Both Wyden and Broomfield said they favor legislation to mandate sales only to U.S. firms, similar to a law governing disposal of Navy warships. Between the 42 inactive ships and the 96-ship Ready Reserve sits a fleet consisting of ``Victory'' ships, the name given to a class of cargo-haulers built near the end of the World War II; former commercial vessels no longer fit for service; once-active Navy ships; and various specialty vessels including the Glomar Explorer, which was built for the CIA in 1972 and used in 1974 to recover pieces of a sunken Soviet submarine in the Pacific. These ships are supposed to be seaworthy on a 30 to 120 days' notice. Except for the Ready Reserve, which is spread out across the country, the fleet is located at Fort Eustis, near Norfolk; at Beaumont, Texas; and at Suisun Bay near San Francicso. Here on the James River, the huge vessels sit quietly with their rusted and broken railings, the silence disturbed only by the sound of shoes crunching the paint flakes that litter the decks. Many of the ships were activated to carry cargo during the Vietnam War, and during a recent tour of the ships, a reporter observed that log books, maps and navigational charts used during Vietnam were still in bookcases on the bridge. Inside the compartments below deck, there are old mattresses on the metal bunk beds, dusty lockers, mess halls with the chairs still at dining tables, crank-style telephones, steel cooking pots, and even small mementos like a pocket-sized prayer book. Kaskin, who works in the Pentagon, said the size of the fleet is set by the cargo requirements of moving Army equipment _ but not troops _ to a theoretical conflict in the Middle East. The Maritime Administration's Delpercio said there have been 60 tests to activate ships in the fleet since 1977, and only four were total failures. He said one or two times, ships failed to sail in the specified time period. All except two of the tests, however, involved the Ready Reserve. Raymond Ramsay, a former Navy maritime affairs official, agreed that the appearance of the ships could be improved. But he said the real test would be the workings of the engines, boilers, gaskets, pipes, hydraulic systems and other parts that make a ship run. ``It's like buying a used car,'' he said. ``The paint and polish might be great, but you have to use it for a while. It would be a shame to run on a gamble and lose a whole ship.''

DOC.HEAD: Half a World From Home, Chinese Dissidents Press for Reform
LaserPhoto BEJ4,8
DOC.TEXT: Half a world away from home, where gunfire and bloodshed shocked the world a year ago, a small group of Chinese exiles works to reform the political system that forced them to flee. The world headquarters for the Federation for a Democratic China is a small office in a quiet, picturesque Paris neighborhood. It tries to maintain pressure on the Communist government in Beijing by urging other governments to take political measures, publishing materials on human rights and keeping track of friends and ex-colleagues in Chinese jails. The idea is to nudge the Communist Party toward peaceful political reform, says Wan Runnan, the federation's secretary-general. ``The Communist Party cannot carry out necessary reform from within,'' Wan says. ``We must put pressure on the party from the outside to adopt democracy, including from foreign governments.'' The federation does not seek to overthrow the party, Wan says. ``But what people want is economic and social stability, without corruption in the party, and the best way to avoid this is a multiparty system,'' he says. A year ago Wan Runnan was a rare breed _ a successful, elite businessman who headed Stone Group Co., China's largest privately funded company. But Wan lent his support, as well as staffers and equipment, to the student-led movement for democratic reforms in Beijing last spring. The Chinese army's violent June 4 suppression of the unarmed protesters left hundreds, possibly thousands, dead. Six days later, while Wan was visiting a computer exhibition in Hong Kong, Chinese authorities issued an arrest warrant for him and six other intellectuals, accusing them of inciting the ``counterrevolutionary turmoil.'' Wan never returned. Today he leads a humbler life in France, directing the federation's protests of human rights violations, organizing discussions and conferences on the massacre and helping a now abandoned project to broadcast pro-democracy messages into China. The federation's chairman is Yan Jiaqi, a former aide to ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang. It is staffed by a dozen Chinese and has 2,000 dues-paying members in its branches around the world. Fees are nominal, only about $10 a year. Yan's often stiff demeanor has helped shift the spotlight to his deputy chairman, Wu'er Kaixi, the flamboyant, articulate former student leader who relishes media attention and has a penchant for fainting at public gatherings. Yan and Wu'er frequently travel outside France, leaving Wan in charge in Paris. But Wan does some traveling himself, recently visiting Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland. ``The events in China of last spring had two strong effects on East Europe,'' he says. ``People saw the widespread participation of ordinary citizens, and governments witnessed the suppression, which could only make them more sensitive to their own problems.'' Details of the federation's budget were not readily available during a recent interview. But Wang Hao, secretary of finance, says there is a ``plan de finance.'' It costs about $38,000 a month to run the office itself, including rent and staff salaries, he says. The federation in its infancy was beset by its share of controversy. There have been allegations of financial mismanagement, overzealous spending by Wu'er and discord among its leaders. Exiled journalist Liu Binyan said in New York last week that he had been asked to take over the federation from Yan in September, but that he refused, noting the prickly relations among the leaders. The federation, while it boasts most of the prominent dissident names, is not the sole voice of dissent, competing with the China Alliance for Democracy in New York, and the Washington, D.C.-based Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars. The three were told to consolidate their offices if they wanted continued support from the U.S. government, according to Chinese sources in the United States. The entire movement-in-exile was given a boost in April when Chai Ling, the impassioned student activist who headed the protest movement in its final days last June, surfaced with her husband in Paris in April after 10 months on the run. Federation members insist gradual reform will come to China. ``If China doesn't adopt democracy, then the country has no hope,'' says Zhang Lun, an aide to federation chairman Yan. A 28-year-old former instructor of political science at Beijing University of Geography, Zhang advised the students at Tiananmen Square. He escaped from China late last year using the ``underground railroad'' that spirited several activists from the country. Now he receives a monthly $180 refugee allowance from the French government and wants to study sociology. He says, however, he can't abandon the hopes and friends he left behind. ``I know many, many people who were arrested,'' he says, wincing. ``I just hope they can see daylight again.''

DOC.HEAD: Russian Language Study Booming in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: Now that Seoul's ties with Moscow are improving, so many South Koreans want to take Russian that there aren't enough teachers to go around, a newspaper reported Saturday. Russian language courses at private institutes are crowded with college students and company employees, and Russian textbooks are a lucrative market for publishers, the Korea Herald said. The paper said the boom was ignited by the Soviet participation in the 1988 Olympics in Seoul and subsequent economic and other exchanges between the countries, even though they have yet to establish diplomatic relations. Presidents Roh Tae-woo and Mikhai S. Gorbachev are to meet Monday in San Francisco. Despite the lack of native Russian speakers in South Korea, many leading business groups and private language schools began Russian study programs this year, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Injured, Four Arrested in Youth Riot at Culture Center
DOC.TEXT: About 150 youths rioted at a multinational culture center in East Berlin, and five people were injured, the news agency ADN said Saturday. Four people were arrested in the violence late Friday night, ADN said. The crowd threw rocks, bottles and other objects at the culture center, set up in a former East Berlin theater as a meeting place for foreigners and Germans living in the city, the state-run news agency said. It said the youths also attacked 12 police cars ordered to the area to quell the rioting. There have been numerous reports in recent months of clashes between rightist youth gangs and foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Comes To State Convention a `Jimmy Carter' Figure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Dukakis speech delayed by local picket line. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `His name ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two years ago, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was the Democratic Party's nominee for the highest office in the land. Today, he isn't even a headline act at his own state's party convention. Dukakis was set to address the convention this morning in the notably unprestigious leadoff slot. But that speech was postponed and the entire convention was delayed Saturday morning by a police picket line that convention participants didn't want to cross. Local police are negotiating a new contract and picketed the convention when contract talks fell through. His name doesn't even appear on the agenda of the convention, a gathering he dominated through much of his three decades in Massachusetts politics. His aides have shown little bitterness over his stature at this year's convention. But the governor's press handlers made a conscious effort to avoid drawing attention to the speech, which was billed as a brief address, or moving the governor toward center stage. Two summers ago in Atlanta, Dukakis, a three-term governor, stood before the national convention as the Democratic presidential nominee, ahead of George Bush in the polls and riding a wave of successes in the Democratic primaries. Today, Bush is president, basking in popularity and the glow from his continuing summit with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. In Massachusetts, state finances are in disarray, and Dukakis' popularity is at rock-bottom. Democratic candidates avoid him. ``Politics is very unforgiving, especially in Massachusetts,'' said James French, a longtime Dukakis ally and one of a dwindling number of aides to stay on in the last months of the governor's administration. Dukakis leaves office in January. And yet, like Jimmy Carter, who disappeared from the lips of Democrats after he lost his 1980 presidential re-election bid, Dukakis hopes the years will give him back the high standing he once enjoyed in Massachusetts. ``Just as Jimmy Carter, in his many years out of office, has become America's best ex-president, and its best-loved president, the same will hold true for Dukakis at the statewide level,'' French said. It would be a major rehabilitation. An opinion poll gave Dukakis an unfavorable rating of 73 percent. And as the state budget situation has grown worse in recent months, Dukakis has been able to do little to dig himself out of that hole. The four Democrats running for governor are basing their candidacies on undoing the fiscal wrongs of the Dukakis administration. Even Dukakis' own lieutenant governor, Evelyn Murphy, has emphasized the points on which she disagrees with her boss. Dukakis launched his statewide career with a surprisingly strong second-place finish in balloting for attorney general in 1966. Four years later, in a bid for lieutenant governor, Dukakis wrested the convention endorsement by tirelessly talking to each and every one of thousands of delegates in their homes and offices. His opponent in that race, state Sen. Beryl Cohen, tried to win delegates by wooing party leaders. Dukakis lost that race. But in 1974 _ a year when there was no convention held _ he won the governorship. In 1978, another year without a convention, he lost a primary race to a Democratic gubernatorial challenger. But at the 1982 and 1986 conventions, it was all Dukakis. ``The conventions throughout the 1980s have been a Michael Dukakis show,'' French said. French said Dukakis hopes and expects that time will be on his side. ``He's been at the very top and he's also experienced the very worst and he realizes that people's judgments will be formulated three or four years from now,'' French said. ``He's very optimistic as most of us are.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Want to Do It All With Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Whether it's making money, spreading democracy or boosting morale, Americans want to do it with the Soviet Union _ and they weren't shy about exploiting the summit to say so. Fax machines whirred throughout summit week with announcements from investors and philanthropists and educators eager to publicize their new partnerships. ``Everybody is trying to use the summit to promote their projects. This is obvious. This is capitalism,'' says Edward Lozansky, an emigre physicist setting up a Soviet-American University in Moscow and the United States. One company that lucked out was Radisson Hotels International. The Minneapolis firm has signed an agreement with Intourist, the Soviet travel agency, to operate the first American-managed hotel and business center in the Soviet Union. Long before the summit was announced, Radisson and Intourist scheduled the signing for May 22. ``It worked out very nicely for us. It couldn't have been nicer,'' said Jeurgen Bartels, president of Carlson Hospitality Group Inc., Radisson's parent company. Radisson billed the project as ``a historic joint venture'' and said the 165-office business center would offer the first commercial direct-dial telephones and fax machines in Moscow. The new marble building, designed by a team of Soviets and Yugoslavians, also has 430 hotel rooms. It was nearly complete when Radisson came on board and is expected to open in December. Lozansky's Soviet-American University was formally announced at a summit-week reception. He said the event netted a raft of business executives offering money and a top Soviet scientist anxious to discuss joint research projects. Roland Schmitt, president of Rensselear Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., acknowledged that ``the idea is in a very early and very nascent stage.'' Lozansky admits the summit sped up the announcement ``a little bit'' but says he has enough money to launch the private university _ the first in the Soviet Union _ this fall. He said five Soviet professors will teach at U.S. universities and five American professors will lecture up to 75 Soviet students at Moscow State University. Eventually the school will grant its own degrees, he said, and next year maybe there will be enough money for a separate building in Moscow. Lozansky, who was forced out of his job and his country for publicly criticizing the government, said educating Soviet students American-style is a way to nudge the Soviet Union toward democracy. ``We want to pull them further and maybe a little bit faster,'' he says. Among the other U.S.-Soviet ventures that surfaced during summit week were the American edition of Commersant, the first Soviet business weekly; Operation USA-USSR, a global relief organization that will send teams of U.S. and Soviet doctors to work in developing countries; and the Heart-to-Heart Association, a partnership between Soviet television and TV preacher Robert Schuller's Crystal Cathedral Ministries. Heart-to-Heart's first project is a remarkable one given the Soviet Union's purportedly atheistic nature: a series of 12 monthly sermons from Schuller, to be broadcast to the Soviet Union's 200 million people in prime time. Schuller, host of the popular ``Hour of Power'' program, delivered televised messages to the Soviet people in December and May at the request of Soviet TV authorities. In the new climate of religious tolerance, they did not seem to mind Schuller's Biblical themes and numerous references to God. Neither did long-suffering Soviet citizens under economic siege. Apparently starved for religion and moral support, they deluged the government with appreciative calls. Schuller ended up with an invitation to be a regular. Why? ``I'm not known for preaching a sectarian dogmatism,'' Schuller said. ``They (the Soviets) were aware that the thrust of my message is building people up and giving them encouragement. I offer practical help for daily living through spiritual power. That's exactly what they need at this point. They say it and I agree with them.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Goes West To Boost Business, South Korean Ties
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the first Soviet leader to visit California since Nikita Khrushchev's tour de farce in 1959, has more serious business in mind than his fun-seeking predecessor. Gorbachev, scheduled to arrive Sunday night after four days of summit talks with President Bush and a quick visit to Minnesota, has a packed agenda highlighted by a historic first meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. Khrushchev's trip to the Golden State was a little less weighty _ a dinner with Marilyn Monroe and other Hollywood stars, an impromptu jaunt around San Francisco after eluding security guards, and a memorable fit when he was denied a day pass to Disneyland. ``What do you have there, rocket launch pads?'' he fumed. So angry was Khrushchev about missing Mickey Mouse and suffering other perceived insults by his American hosts that he reportedly considered severing relations between the superpowers. That was in the chilly days of the Cold War. In this era of glasnost, perestroika and crumbling communism, Gorbachev will be allowed where few Soviets have ever been permitted _ into the heart of Silicon Valley. Khrushchev visited International Business Machines Corp.'s San Jose plant and ate a 49-cent fried chicken special with workers in the cafeteria. Gorbachev will venture only as far into the valley as Stanford University for a speech and meeting with scholars and students. Gorbachev's speech at Stanford and his agenda in San Francisco are expected to focus on Pacific Rim politics and big business as he turns from the issues of European security and strategic arms that dominated his talks with Bush. Except for a brief excursion to view the Golden Gate Bridge at day's end, Gorbachev will leave most of the sightseeing to his wife, Raisa, during a whirlwind, 22-hour visit that includes a luncheon with 150 West Coast executives. Gorbachev's meeting with the captains of industry, including the leaders of Chevron Corp., BankAmerica Corp., AT&T, Hewlett-Packard Co., and more than 100 other major companies, is in sharp contrast to Khrushchev's unscheduled visit to the hiring hall of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union. Khrushchev was cheered by the workers. Gorbachev is likely to be applauded enthusiastically by the executives, who see opportunities for trade in the opening markets of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The Soviet president also will renew his friendship with former President Reagan over coffee Monday morning at the home of the Soviet consul general in San Francisco, where the Gorbachevs are staying. The Soviet flag is flying at San Francisco City Hall for the first time since Khrushchev's visit, and boats along Fisherman's Wharf are expected to hoist the hammer and sickle for Mrs. Gorbachev's tour. Not everyone is thrilled about the visit. Wherever the Soviet president goes he'll pass demonstrators _ Armenians, Lithuanians, Estonians, Latvians, Palestinians, and Eritreans from embattled Ethiopia _ who are upset about Soviet policies. Gorbachev, plagued by economic and political woes, apparently will use his California trip to promote the Soviet Union as a Pacific Rim trading partner with West Coast companies and to improve relations with South Korea, longtime foe of Soviet-backed North Korea. His meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo was a late addition to the schedule. But it promises to be a dramatic and significant event that could have a profound effect on both their countries. Besides being a big step toward the establishment of diplomatic ties between Moscow and Seoul and a prelude to eventual reunification of the Korean peninsula, the meeting could affect Soviet-Japanese relations, said Soviet watcher David Holloway of Stanford. ``As the Soviet Union puts more emphasis on its trade relationship with South Korea it also puts more pressure on Japan ... It's a way of telling the Japanese they're missing out on something and it might encourage them to break their deadlock in negotiations with the Soviets,'' said Holloway, a political scientist who briefed President Bush before his first summit with Gorbachev. Soviet-South Korean trade doubled to $600 million last year and is expected to surpass $1 billion in 1990. South Korea has the manufacturing expertise and high-tech products the Soviets need and are a good, close market for Soviet resources. For two years, South Korea has sought to build ties with Communist nations able to influence Communist North Korea. Since that ``Northern Policy'' went into effect in July 1988, South Korea has established formal diplomatic relations with every nation in eastern Europe except Albania, East Germany and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Some of California's Best Wines For Gorbachev Luncheon
DOC.TEXT: Some of California's finest wines and gourmet foods will be served Monday to the 150 capitalists who will lunch with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. For the teetotaling Russian leader, however, the drink of choice will be still mineral water. Hours of tasting, deliberating and negotiating by representatives of the Soviet Consulate and San Francisco Chamber of Commerce went into decisions on the five-star feast of food and wine. ``It's an all-American menu,'' said Ernest Brandner, the Fairmont Hotel's head of food and beverages. Not so American, however, as to include hamburgers, put in a hotel spokesman. ``No, he's already had enough of that in Moscow,'' he said, referring to the recent opening of a huge McDonald's hamburger restaurant. The Gorbachev banquet will be in the Venetian Room, where the hotel's most elegant dinner shows have been staged for years. Brandner estimated 40 to 50 cooks will be on duty for the event, under the direction of Kurt Kratschmar. The reception will be served hors d'oeuvres of smoked salmon on pumpernickel and Dungeness crab legs on endive. The wine will be Iron Horse champagnes from Sonoma County. The appetizer course will be lobster medallions with greens and butterflied salmon with vinaigrette dressing, served with Raymond 1987 private reserve chardonnay of Napa Valley. For the main course, the entree will be a Gorbachev favorite _ roast rack of Sonoma baby lamb with pinot noir sauce and vegetables and new potatoes. The wine will be Napa Valley's Robert Mondavi 1987 private reserve pinot noir. Dessert will be chocolate tulips with berries and a 1987 Schramsberg champagne of Napa Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Trade Barriers Sought at OAS Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The United States is expected to make a strong pitch this coming week for nations of Latin America and the Caribbean to reduce their trade barriers. President Bush is sending Special Trade Representative Carla Hills to a meeting in Paraguay of the Organization of American States to outline U.S. thoughts on how the region can overcome its dismal economic performance the past decade. In an interview Friday, Hills said she plans to stress lower trade barriers and establishing favorable foreign investment climates as two keys to the region's economic recovery. ``Investment will flow where climate is most hospitable,'' she said, adding that a number of countries have begun to scrap policies that have crippled growth in the past. ``There have been substantial changes this year.'' Other officials have cited Mexico, Bolivia, Costa Rica, Venezuela and Chile as countries which have initiated pro-growth policies. The 1980s have frequently been described as Latin America's ``lost decade'' because of the steep economic decline that occurred in almost all countries in the region. Hills will be accompanied to the annual OAS conclave of member nation's foreign ministers by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. They were due to arrive Saturday night in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion. Eagleburger is standing in for Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who will be in Europe during the consultations. Baker's top aide for Latin America, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson, also is not attending the OAS meeting. He plans to go to Rome for a meeting next week of more than 20 donor countries for a discussion on ways to help Nicaragua overcome its economic crisis. Hills will meet starting Sunday night with several of the six hemispheric presidents planning to participate in the discussions, which are taking place on the 100th anniversary of the first inter-American conference. Recent OAS meetings have become bogged down over disputes on Panama and the overall Central American question. With those issues largely resolved, an unusually small number of divisive political questions are on the agenda this year. Last year OAS delegates spent most of their energies grappling with the political crisis in Panama. This year they will be able to focus more on issues such as drugs, trade, foreign debt and the environment, U.S. officials said. Delegates also will discuss ways of promoting the scheduled transition to democratic rule in Haiti this year. Underscoring the relative harmony in the hemisphere these days is the fact that virtually all 32 OAS members have elected presidents. Paraguay is hosting its first OAS meeting, a recognition of the replacement of 35 years of military rule last year by an elected government. Hills will address the meeting at Monday's opening session and visit Brazil and Argentina afterwards.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Still Bargaining as Mayor Barry Drug Trial Nears
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's defense attorneys kept up bargaining with prosecutors over the weekend as they prepared for the start of his trial on charges of cocaine possession and perjury. Jury selection was scheduled to start Monday barring negotiation of a last-minute plea bargain in the talks between Barry's attorneys and federal prosecutors. The 54-year-old mayor last week appeared determined to see the case through in the courtroom rather than accept an agreement that would require him to plead guilty to felony charges. But sources familiar with the case, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the two sides continued to explore the possibility of an agreement. The case marks the low point in Barry's stormy tenure as mayor. His latest troubles arise from his visits to the hotel room of former city employee Charles Lewis in December 1988. Lewis pleaded guilty last year to conspiring to buy at least $140 worth of crack cocaine for the mayor. Information from Lewis led federal investigators to one-time model Rasheeda Moore, whose role in an FBI sting operation led to Barry's arrest. Barry visited her hotel room Jan. 18 while FBI cameras taped the mayor smoking crack cocaine supplied by an FBI agent posing as a friend of Moore. He is charged with possession of cocaine and perjury for lying to a federal grand jury about his involvement with drugs. The videotape is the centerpiece of the government's 14-count case alleging possession of cocaine on numerous occasions since 1984. ``I've seen this videotape, and the tape is more damaging to the government than to me,'' Barry said in an interview with The Washington Post. He admitted smoking crack but said the government had tried to kill him by providing a potentially lethal dose. Barry has not said whether he will run for a fourth, four-year term in November. A recent poll shows that his legal problems have not significantly eroded his political support. Whatever happens, Barry already has had a remarkable career. Born into a family of sharecroppers in Itta Bena, Miss., Barry grew up in Memphis, Tenn., and joined the civil rights movement while a college student. He organized the first lunch counter sit-ins in Nashville, Tenn., and became the first national chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, which engaged in demonstrations and boycotts. He moved to Washington, D.C., in 1965, where he led a one-day boycott of the D.C. transit system. He fought for replacing congressional control of the District of Columbia with a limited form of home rule. Barry designed a program to aid Washington's black poor called Youth Pride. It received millions of dollars in grants from the U.S. Labor Department and operated a series of small businesses. It was his ties to Youth Pride that created Barry's first brush with scandal. His first wife, Mary Treadwell, went to jail after being convicted of embezzling money from the organization. She now draws a city salary for serving on a parole board. Barry was not charged in the investigation. Barry won election to both the school board and the City Council. He was elected mayor in 1978. He dealt with a city financial crisis in his first term. A second term was marked by a renewal of the downtown area and declines in crime and unemployment. But his administration has been beset by scandal. The mayor's chief aide went to prison for defrauding the government of nearly $200,000 and 12 other city officials have been convicted of various crimes. The former head of the D.C. human services department and a businessman are on now on trial in the same federal courthouse for allegedly steering city contracts to favored companies. Prosecutors have investigated Barry before. The government closed out one probe in 1985, after trying unsuccessfully to prove that Barry lied to a grand jury when he denied obtaining cocaine from a former city employee.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Produce Little That Americans Want _ Except Luxuries
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-Soviet trade agreement offers the potential of billions of dollars in economic benefits for both countries, but trade experts said Saturday that the Soviets now produce precious little that interests Americans. The exceptions are well known _ vodka, caviar and luxury furs _ and for those items prices are expected to drop. That will give American consumers their very own perestroika dividend, once Congress gets around to ratifying the pact and a companion measure granting the Soviets most-favored-nation trade status. For now, trade analysts see the agreement as a badly needed public relations boost for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, bestowing on him the economic prize he had most sought from his summit with President Bush. Gorbachev wanted the accord to demonstrate that, despite his problems at home, he still could negotiate economic concessions from the West. In some respects, Gorbachev's U.S. trip could be viewed as an extended trade mission. His stops from Washington to Minnesota and California were planned to afford him a chance to court potential U.S. business investors. But analysts said daunting problems remain before either the number of U.S. companies doing business in the Soviet Union or the modest U.S.-Soviet trade increases to any great extent. ``If you look at the structure of their imports, they really don't have a lot of things that we want to buy,'' said Donald Bowles, an expert on the Soviet economy at American University. ``They are still heavily dependent on raw materials exports,'' Bowles said. ``They are only able to sell manufactured goods in the Third World, which is willing to settle for less quality.'' The Soviet Union is one of the few countries with which the United States, beset with its own trade problems, is running a trade surplus. Last year, it amounted to $3.57 billion. The United States exported $4.27 billion worth of goods, primarily grain, to the Soviet Union. That was offset by a small $703 million in Soviet sales here. Duties on Soviet products are as much as 10 times higher than imports from other countries. Economists said that once the Soviets gain the lower tariffs promised by the trade agreement, Soviet exports, especially of luxury consumer goods, are bound to rise. With the most-favored-nation tariffs, the price of a bottle of vodka is expected to drop by about $1.10. Tariffs on sable furs would fall to 8 percent, down from the current 50 percent. The tariff on Russian caviar would drop to 15 percent, half the current 30 percent levy. The trade agreement also would make it easier for U.S. companies to set up shop in the Soviet Union, a largely untapped market of 300 million people. Joseph Pelzman, an economist at George Washington University, said he expected the Soviet experience would be similar to that of the Chinese, who were awarded the lower most-favored-nation trade tariffs in the early 1980s and now enjoy a $6.18 billion trade surplus with the United States. The trade agreement is a necessary first step for a presidential waiver of the high tariffs mandated by the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment, passed by Congress to penalize the Soviet Union for its restrictions on the emigration of Jews and other dissidents.
