The administration has said it will not send the trade agreement or the Jackson-Vanik waiver to Congress until the Supreme Soviet passes a free emigration law, something that Soviet officials say is imminent. Many members of Congress say that is not enough. They charged that the administration should have stuck to an earlier position of not offering a trade deal unless Gorbachev lifted the economic blockade of Lithuania. Pelzman said those who linked a trade agreement to Lithuania missed a key point. ``The Baltic republics are likely to be the first to take advantage of the expanded trade opportunities,'' he said. ``They are the closest to Western markets and their business acumen is better.'' The administration, meanwhile, was lobbied heavily by American business interests, anxious not to be left behind in the rush to get a foothold in the Soviet Union. William Archey, a former top trade official in the Reagan administration and now vice president for international relations at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said Bush's decision to sign the trade agreement reflected a new realism about America's status in the world. ``The day has long passed since the United States can unilaterally engage in economic sanctions in any form,'' he said. ``The United States does not dominate the world economy any more and it is time we came to realize that.''

DOC.HEAD: Watergate Figure Haldeman Will Meet With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: H.R. Haldeman, a former Nixon aide who went to jail because of the Watergate scandal, is among the business and agricultural leaders who will meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday. Haldeman recently helped the Minneapolis-based Radisson Hotels International chain get approval to start a hotel in Moscow. It will be the first U.S.-managed hotel in the Soviet Union. Gov. Rudy Perpich's administration said Friday after the guest list of 145 names was made public that Haldeman was not one of the suggested names it submitted to the Soviets but was added by them. The meeting will be at the Radisson Hotel in Minneapolis. Haldeman was in Moscow last month to take part in a signing ceremony during a meeting of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council. He and former astronaut Edwin ``Buzz'' Aldrin were representing Americom International Corp., an office technology concern in Irvine, Calif., which will operate the hotel along with Radisson. Haldeman was convicted of obstruction of justice and conspiracy in the Watergate burglary and coverup and served 18 months in prison. The scandal forced Richard Nixon to resign the presidency. While in Moscow, Haldeman expressed his admiration for Gorbachev, making an implied comparison to his former boss. ``I can only say having observed one politician very closely with a remarkable ability for survival and recovery, and watching Gorbachev, I have utmost admiration for his political skills,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Alliances Ripe For Political Roles, Summit Important Step For Disarmament
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German politicians Saturday praised the arms agreements reached at the superpower summit, but regretted that no progress was reported on the issue of which military alliance a united Germany should join. The politicians also said the summit in Washington showed that the Warsaw Pact and NATO alliances are ready to take on important political roles. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said it is important that the United States and Soviets find a new level of relations. ``When the United States and the Soviet Union declare that they no longer find one a threat to the other _ which is a correct conclusion _ then that must also apply for the alliances,'' Genscher told Hesse state radio. ``This means the alliances are ripe for politican functions, for a political disarmament function, a political disarmament control function and to help build a cooperative structure of security in Europe,'' he said. Genscher said that an important related aspect to the summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is that ``the Soviets can trust that a united Germany will be a meaningful and constructive partner'' in a future European security system. Bush and Gorbachev on Friday signed the foundation of a landmark treaty for the first cuts in strategic nuclear missiles and a pact to slash chemical weapons stockpiles. Their summit ends Sunday. Horst Ehmke, a deputy chairman of the opposition Social Democrats in the West German Parliament, praised the summit for furthering disarmament and improving bilateral relations. ``We see this an important step toward further reduction of strategic nuclear weapons, complete elimination of medium-range weapons and the total worldwide ban of chemical weapons,'' Ehmke said in a statement to the media. However, he said it was ``regretful'' that the two leaders had not made any apparent progress on the question of the military security status of a future united Germany. ``It is becoming ever clearer that finding a satisfactory solution for everyone in this question is difficult,'' Ehmke said. Gorbachev has proposed handing the German unity and alliance issue to a European council that would meet annually with U.S. and Soviet participation. The council would be made up of the 35 Western, neutral and Eastern states that now make up the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The United States, which wants a united Germany to become a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has agreed to hold further discussions on the Gorbachev proposal after the summit. Top diplomatic aides from both sides are to meet in Copenhagen, Denmark, to discuss the German question next week, and again in Berlin two weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Quietly Achieves Economic Reform Under New Premier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Political revolt...' to CORRECT to last week, sted this week. Pickup 5th graf, `Markovic, 65...'
DOC.TEXT: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia _ In six months, Yugoslavia has achieved a quiet revolution. No walls and only a few Communist leaders fell, but four-digit inflation ended, the currency is convertible and the foreign debt is shrinking. Daunting challenges remain, however, from achieving political stability to reforming money-losing state enterprises. Federal elections are likely by year's end and Premier Ante Markovic, popular as the architect of reform, is promoting himself as head of a new coalition government. He says he may give up his Communist membership and form his own party. Political revolt has pushed economic change elsewhere in Eastern Europe, but U.S. Ambassador Warren Zimmermann noted last week that in Yugoslavia, ``major change in the economy has been driving political reform.'' Markovic, 65, who became premier in March last year, is the first politician who may acquire national authority similar to that of Josip Broz Tito, who died a decade ago. Since Tito's death, regional leaders have tended to have the highest standing in Yugoslavia, a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces. But opinion polls in Serbia, Slovenia and Croatia, the three most influential republics, rank Markovic second only to the regions' leaders. Those three republics are at odds politically. Non-Communists who favor secession from Yugoslavia have won free elections in Slovenia and Croatia. Serbia's conservative Communists have refused to follow the other five republics in legalizing opposition parties, and cling to the concept of strong federal rule. Because he has performed what a Western diplomat termed ``near miracles'' in the economy, Markovic appears to have a chance of bypassing regional disputes and forging national consensus. His success rests partly on popular weariness with Communist leaders who could not halt annual inflation of more than 1,000 percent or ease unemployment, which is 15 percent nationwide and far higher in the impoverished south. Markovic became premier in March 1989 after the economic crisis forced out Branko Mikulic. Markovic acted on the economic front in December after consulting Western experts. He tied the dinar to the West German mark, creating the first fully convertible currency in Eastern Europe. The foreign debt has fallen from $23 billion to $16 billion and foreign investment is up, encouraged by laws drafted on Markovic's recommendation even before he became premier. About 1,100 new joint ventures involving 1 billion West German marks _ $600 million _ were started between January 1989 and April 1990. By lopping four zeros off the old dinar to create the new, convertible currency, Markovic slashed prices that had risen to dizzying heights each day. In February, the Belgrade stock exchange resumed trading for the first time in nearly 50 years. Vuk Hamovic, one of the new private entrepreneurs in Belgrade, described the premier as ``the only bright spot in the idiotic situation in Yugoslavia.'' Hamovic joins many others in predicting that if Markovic forms a new political organization, ``everybody will vote for that party.'' The euphoria may be premature. Markovic has yet to take some of the most difficult steps: reforming and unifying a labyrinthine tax system, changing ownership laws and closing big bankrupt state enterprises. ``When I see the first big firm with over 1,000 employees shut down, then I'll believe in the future,'' a Belgrade businessman said on condition of anonymity. Markovic has promised to announce more reforms by the end of June. Yugoslav sources and Western diplomats believe they may involve the greatest effort in Eastern Europe so far to transfer ownership from the state to managers and workers. Reports say up to 70 percent of state-owned firms could pass into the hands of their workers, who would buy shares. It is not clear how freely such shares could be traded, if at all. The stock market is just being born and many bank managers are unskilled in assessing risks. Another difficulty is determining how much a company is worth. The Energoprojekt construction group, one of Yugoslavia's biggest firms, tried it before forming a holding company a year ago to manage its 10 companies. Vice president Milan Djelic said a British firm, which he did not name, will have to be brought in to do the job again before Energoprojekt can proceed with plans for managers to buy shares, which it also wants to offer abroad. Yugoslavia starts with some advantages in the economic conversion of Eastern Europe. In 1965, it became the first Communist nation to give state firms some autonomy. Free travel to the West has been allowed for 20 years, and millions of Yugoslavs have worked abroad. Tourism has brought Western visitors. Movies from the West, shown in the original language, are the most popular. Yugoslavs, stylish and freewheeling, have more ideas than any other East Europeans about what a modern Western economy entails. ``Make money, not war'' is the capitalist message beamed to firms invited to advertise on Belgrade's lively third television channel.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Town With Next To Nothing Had A Lot to Lose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Franci cq in 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Flood victims found that having next to nothing didn't mean they had nothing to lose. A month after floodwaters soaked this town of 300, the deluge elderly residents call the worst in memory is far from forgotten, with soggy reminders bearing silent witness to the destruction virtually everywhere. Ruined furniture, appliances and clothes are stacked in piles in front of stricken houses. Windows stand open to help interiors dry out. Wooden floors are warped and smell of mildew. Roy Roberts' auto salvage yard reeks heavily of diesel fumes as workers clean car engines that not long ago were submerged in 4 feet of water. Two blocks away, the Moffett school secretary works at a desk bearing a 16-inch-high stripe of stains showing where floodwaters lapped against the side. The modest community where the salvage yard is the most prominent business may have suffered irreparable harm when the Arkansas River spilled from its banks, officials say. Many residents say they cannot afford even low-interest disaster loans, and officials say about 80 percent of the homes are rented, which rules out federal grants to repair housing. But Moffett, described by one state official as a ``poor, second cousin'' to Fort Smith, Ark., isn't a nowhere town residents are eager to flee. ``I'm crazy about this place,'' said 89-year-old George Hargrave. ``I don't consider home anyplace but here.'' Roberts said Moffett thrived in the 1940s and 1950s with grocery stores, service stations and three or four nightclubs that made the town off-limits to soldiers stationed at Fort Chaffee in Fort Smith. But old Highway 64 gave way to Interstate 40, about 3 miles north of Moffett, and the town slowly ``fell off the map,'' he said. Longtime residents say there have been other floods, but none so severe. After heavy spring rains, runoff from eastern Oklahoma lakes caused the Arkansas River to swell over its banks and into Moffett. The American Red Cross immediately opened an outreach center and went door-to-door looking for those in need, spending more than $135,000 on 95 families, said spokeswoman Franci Hart. Sequoyah County was declared a disaster area and the Federal Emergency Management Agency has taken over. But FEMA relief for most residents will be limited. ``Some will be able to get repair loans, some can't afford a loan of any size,'' said state Social Services Secretary Robert Fulton. ``A lot of the houses are rented, so the landlords have got the problem of fixing them up. And there are questions whether the landlords can carry a loan.'' Dell Greer, deputy coordinator of FEMA's Oklahoma field office, said some who cannot repay loans may be eligible for up to $10,400 in federal grants to replace personal property. Sally Armstrong has lived in Moffett for 68 years. Her floor and carpeting suffered the worst flood damage at her home, which she moved back into on Wednesday after receiving a FEMA grant of $2,576. ``It's not enough but I'll have to stretch it and make it enough,'' Mrs. Armstrong said. ``I don't want a loan because there's no way I could pay it back.'' FEMA grants to repair houses are limited to the owners, Greer said. Roberts owns eight houses in Moffett. He has begun repairs on hot water heaters and said he will clean up the debris the best he can. None of the homes built in the 1940s rents for more than $100 a month, he said. ``I probably couldn't apply for a loan, but I'd take a grant,'' he said. As for his tenants, he said, ``I'm sure they'll get some help.'' Greer said it was unclear whether the $10,400 limit applies to each property or each owner. FEMA provides temporary housing for tenants whose rental homes are unlivable, he said. For many, that would mean leaving Moffett. ``We lost everything but our lives, but I'm going to try to hang around here,'' Hargrave said. ``I've been in Moffett so long. I'm not leaving.'' Earl Oxford, pastor at the Baptist Church in Moffett, remains busy attending to repairs and consoling his flock. Floodwaters buckled the floor at the church where about 50 people attend services. Free clothing was displayed outside the church for those unable to replace clothes lost in the flood. ``Most of the people are still getting over the shock,'' Oxford said. ``A lot of them are not going to get their homes fixed. A lot of them can't be fixed. If they were renting, they lost everything.'' Moffett was not the only Oklahoma community to suffer from the record flooding, but Fulton said the town with next-to-nothing may have had the most to lose. ``It seemed along the Red River, the flooding was to second homes, to lake homes,'' he said. ``This was a permanent community, already poor, that got hit hard.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Soviets Say Gorbachev Not Quite the Hero Westerners Make Him Out to Be
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES typos in 1st, 17th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: Many Soviets agreed Saturday that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev deserved praise for his foreign policy achievements at the summit, but some said he didn't deserve humanitarian awards and doubted his trip would improve their lives. ``Shame! Again he has sold out all Russia!'' one woman shouted to a sidewalk crowd around her on Pushkin Square, a kind of Moscow ``speaker's corner'' a few blocks from the Kremlin. She was referring to the five American humanitarian awards Gorbachev received Friday in Washington for striving for peace and freedom. Her comments reflected the contrast between Gorbachev's wild popularity abroad _ where he is treated like a hero for loosening up Soviet society and helping bring peace and democracy to many parts of the world _ and his unpopularity at home, where he is accused of ruining the economy and stifling freedom. The woman said she was from Lvov in the Ukraine but refused to give her name ``for a variety of reasons.'' Many Soviets believe Gorbachev's glasnost, or openness, campaign is limited and they are fearful of being quoted in the foreign press. A man in the crowd explained many people's mixed views of Gorbachev's foreign trips. ``He did much on the international arena, he earned points. But in domestic policy, he tramples on progressives,'' said Anatoly Bogudinov, 40. If the awards were presented for Gorbachev's humanitarian actions, Bogudinov said, the sponsors forgot about the basics. ``The least we want is sausage, but he doesn't give it to us, and you ask whether he deserves these awards!'' During a ceremony at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, Gorbachev received the Albert Einstein Peace Prize, the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Freedom Medal, the Martin Luther King Jr. Non-Violent Peace Prize, the Man of History award from the Appeal of Conscience Foundation and the Martin Luther King Jr. International Peace Award from Friends World College. Bogudinov asked a question of his own: What would the American people do if they had a president like Gorbachev? ``If Bush did everything on the international scene but nothing for his own country, the people wouldn't support him,'' Bogudinov said. Even criticizing the country's president, he noted, has been outlawed. The Supreme Soviet legislature passed a bill last month imposing a fine and jail sentence for insulting the Soviet president. Diagonally across Pushkin Square, at McDonald's, Soviets sinking their teeth into America's classic family fare were generally more positive about their leader and his policies. ``We're very glad our relations are improving,'' said Oksana, a 23-year-old housewife eating ice cream on the second floor of the McDonald's, which opened in January. ``We're anxious for improvements in trade and anticipate that friendship with America will bring improvements in our lives,'' said the woman, who refused to give her last name. President Bush and Gorbachev Friday approved the outlines of a landmark treaty for the first-ever cuts in long-range nuclear missiles and signed a pact to slash chemical weapons. They also signed a trade agreement and a five-year grain deal sought by American farmers. The United States, Oksana said, should help the Soviet Union not with handouts but with cooperation, for instance with joint business ventures. Another customer in the crowded restaurant said the simple fact he was talking to an American reporter was a sign that glasnost was real. ``Five years ago we wouldn't be talking to you,'' said Sergei, a 28-year-old radioman for the Soviet military who also refused to give his last name.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares for Test To Find Leak
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Saturday prepared for another test of Columbia in its effort to pinpoint the hydrogen leak that has grounded the space shuttle until mid-June or possibly July. Workers have been trying without success to locate the leak in Columbia's rear engine compartment since Thursday by increasing pressure on the shuttle's external tank, which is filled with helium. On Wednesday, the tank will be partly filled with liquid hydrogen, duplicating conditions when the leak was detected six hours before last Wednesday's launch. More than a half-million gallons of volatile liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were being pumped into Columbia at the time. ``It doesn't appear that leak is going to remanifest itself until they get that supercold hydrogen flowing through the system again,'' NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said Saturday. ``What probably has happened, the leak has sealed itself at room temperature, which is what we're working at now.'' Engineers believe the leak is in or near a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the external tank to the shuttle's main engines. Over the weekend, NASA planned to circulate helium through the shuttle's fuel system in preparation for the tanking test, then disconnect explosive devices that were attached to the orbiter for launch. Officials for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said it's doubtful the tanking test will pinpoint a cause that can be fixed easily at the launch pad. Returning Columbia to its hangar for repairs would push the astronomy mission into July, they said. Columbia holds in its payload bay a $150 million observatory called Astro that will examine ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from extremely hot stars, galaxies and other objects.

DOC.HEAD: Family Has 4,000 Sets of Salt and Pepper Shakers
DOC.TEXT: Sherman and Georgia Cutshaw are known as a spicy couple. After 16 years of marriage, the Cutshaws have amassed 4,000 sets of salt and pepper shakers. They line shelves in the kitchen, living room _ and their bedroom. ``It started just real innocent,'' Cutshaw says. ``I'd pick up a set or two of them at a yard sale or a flea market or something like that, just a little something to bring home so I wouldn't have to show up empty-handed.'' No typical couple, Cutshaw is 77 and his wife is 35. They have a 14-year-old son. And as their fascination with matching spice containers became known, relatives and friends added to the collection. ``Every time some of them would go on vacation or just out of town, they would bring us salt and pepper shakers,'' she said. ``It got to be a little fun thing for them to do too.'' Boasting exotic shakers from Cuba, Bermuda and Hawaii, the Cutshaws say their most unusual set depicts Adam and Eve. ``Adam's got a branch on,'' Mrs. Cutshaw said. ``Eve's got the lower part sort of covered up, but the upper part's not. You know, they look like Adam and Eve ought to look.'' Cutshaw says he's always on the lookout for new sets, but avoiding repitition can be tough. ``I can hardly ever find (any) now that I don't have,'' he said. The colorful variety of salt and pepper sets dominates the couple's home, but Cutshaw says the couple uses plain glass shakers when they sit down to eat. Keeping 8,000 knickknacks clean could drive some homemakers crazy, but not Mrs. Cutshaw. ``I just clean them one at a time, never getting in a hurry,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Boards May Be Too Easy on Physicians
DOC.TEXT: Increasing referrals of malpractice cases and limited resources to investigate them may be prompting state medical boards to show too much leniency in disciplining physicians, a draft government report says. Although the disciplinary boards have grown in strength in recent years, the report by Department of Health and Human Services' inspector general said most of the cases brought to them are settled through consent agreements. ``As the proportion of cases so settled exceeds 50 percent, and indeed nears 100 percent in some places, one wonders if ... the pressure to settle might not be leading some boards in some cases to act more leniently than the violation would warrant,'' the report said. The report, to be released this week, said the state boards are getting more complaints and case referrals due to laws requiring hospitals, insurance companies and others to report actions they take against physicians. ``Case backlogs remain a serious problem, ... significant staff shortages continue to impede the boards' disciplinary efforts,'' HHS Inspector General Richard Kusserow wrote in the draft report, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press. After reading the report, Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., concluded that the different state medical boards still ``don't have the tools to properly address these issues.'' ``This country is playing catch-up ball in terms of dealing with the quality issues,'' said Wyden, the chief author of a law establishing a national databank for compiling actions taken against physicians. The databank is expected to go into operation this fall. Since the law was passed in 1986, most states have implemented or strengthened statutes requiring mandatory reporting of actions taken against physicians, Kusserow's report said. Most states now require hospitals to report their actions against physicians and 33 states require insurance companies to report medical malpractice cases. But federally supported peer organizations that review Medicare claims account for only a small number of cases referred to state boards, even though they could be a major source of leads about doctors who should be disciplined, the report said. In the few instances where these peer groups do refer cases, state boards don't consider them useful sources of information because the review groups have limited authority to release case details, the report said. Although officials don't know how many complaints are referred to state medical boards each year, signs that the number is increasing are ``widespread,'' according to the report. The Federation of State Medical Boards reported the number of actions state boards took against physicians rose 29 percent from 2,019 in 1985 to 2,597 in 1987, the latest year for which figures were available. However, the inspector general estimated that only about three-quarters of those were initial disciplinary actions against physicians. The figures do not represent the number of physicians disciplined, since action by three states against one physician would be reported as three actions. Currently, there is no way to measure how many physicians warrant disciplinary action for delivering improper or substandard care, the report said. ``But some recent studies suggest quite strongly that ... the universe of potential actionable events far exceeds the number of disciplinary actions actually imposed by the boards,'' the report said. The report also found that states vary widely in the number of actions taken by their medical boards. From 1985 to 1987, statewide rates of board actions taken ranged from 2.6 per 1,000 physicians to 32.2. The median was 14.3 per 1,000 physicians. The report recommended that states use all revenues from medical licensing fees exclusively to support their medical boards. It also listed changing Medicaid and Medicare regulations as among the steps federal health agencies could take to help coordinate and foster cooperative investigative efforts among states.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Injures More Than 10 People One Week Before Elections
DOC.TEXT: A bomb in a plastic bag exploded in a crowded square Saturday barely a week before national elections, injuring about 15 people including tourists enjoying a concert, witnesses and news reports said. One witness said scores were injured, but that could not be independently confirmed. There was no immediate claim of responsibility and police refused to provide details, saying it was too early to establish a motive. With emotions running high ahead of parliamentary elections next Friday and Saturday, some people on the scene blamed the explosion on attempts to disrupt the democratic process that toppled hard-line Communists last fall. The government's CTK news agency reported ``a bomb placed by an unknown person in a plastic bag exploded on Old Town Square, causing light injuries to between 10 and 15 people.'' The brief dispatch said the explosion occurred at 4:16 p.m. Old Town Square is one of Prague's best-known historical rendezvous points for tourists as well as a site of frequent rallies and weekend concerts. Witnesses who examined the explosive device said what appeared to be a pipe bomb was placed close to a statue in the middle of the square with a detonation mechanism that included batteries hooked up by wires. It was not clear whether the bomb had a timing device or whether it was activated by a person on the scene. ``While a music band was playing, the bomb exploded, injuring scores of people, including foreign tourists, children and women present,'' said Richard Nygryn of Prague. ``I saw cut lead, glass balls on the scene as the cops were investigating it,'' Nygryn, 36, told a reporter. ``A shop widow nearby had a large hole in it as if shot through with a cannon.'' ``A man injured by the explosion told me he was just walking by when it happened and before he knew anything, he was lying on the ground with his face covered in blood,'' said. People at the scene shortly after the blast ``were blaming everybody from the interior minister to the STB for this,'' Nygryn said. Interior Minister Richard Sacher, a Christian Democrat, has been accused by opponents of shielding former agents of the STB _ the secret police of the former Communist regime led by Milos Jakes. The parliamentary elections on Friday and Saturday will be the freest balloting in Czechoslovakia four decades. The country's interim coalition government includes non-Communist President Vaclav Havel.

DOC.HEAD: Endangered Pelican and Sea Gull Eggs Stolen
DOC.TEXT: Eggs plundered from the nests of endangered brown pelicans and laughing sea gulls were swiped by fishermen who planned to eat them, federal wildlife authorities said. Acting on a tip, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service agents boarded the 65-foot trawler Gypsy Wind on Thursday and seized nearly 200 eggs allegedly stolen from a bird sanctuary near the mouth of the Mississippi River. The thieves nearly wiped out the hatchling population on the Mud Lumps barrier island by looting 26 of the 27 pelican nests and an unknown number of laughing sea gull nests, wildlife service spokesman James Bartee said Friday. Eighty brown pelican eggs and 118 gull eggs were recovered. The laughing sea gull is protected under federal laws. The brown pelican is listed as endangered, Bartee said. The five fishermen accused of stealing the eggs apparently intended to eat them, he said. ``This stuff has been going on for years,'' Bartee said. ``But we've never been able to catch anyone doing it _ we always get there too late.'' He did not release the names of the fishermen, but said the trawler was seized. The fishermen could be charged under the Endangered Species Act, the Migratory Bird Treaty Act and the Lacey Act, a law dealing with transportation of illegal wildlife, he said. The eggs are probably a total loss, ``but if there's any hope at all, we'll airlift them to Audubon Zoo'' in New Orleans, Bartee said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Supporters Rally Against Government
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of communist supporters rallied in the East German capital Saturday to protest the government's decision to take control of the ousted party's vast holdings. In the sort of demonstration that was sometimes harshly dealt with by the former Stalinist government, protesters rallied in a park to denounce what they called the ``fascist'' action of the democratic leadership. ``First, PDS banned. Second, books burned. Third, Auschwitz?'' read a banner at the rally, seeking to compare the government to Hitler's Nazi regime. PDS stands for the Party of Democratic Socialism, the reconstituted Communist Party that lost power last year after demonstrations by hundreds of thousands of people. The government news agency ADN estimated the crowd at about 65,000 people. The protesters were angry about the decision by Parliament on Thursday to put the vast holdings of the defunct Communist party in trust pending an investigation by an independent commission of their value and ownership. The former Communists amassed perhaps billions of dollars in houses, businesses and property during their four decades in power. Lawmaker Gregor Gysi, leader of the former Communist faction that holds 66 seats in the 400-member Parliament, has accused the government of seeking to eliminate his party by seizing its assets. Although the party finished a distant third in East Germany's first democratic elections on March 18, it enjoys its strongest support in the capital, where many people owe their careers to loyal party membership. The step by Parliament was part of the process of moving East Germany to a system of private ownership. East Germany is to combine its economy with West Germany's by July 2, a prelude to full unification expected next year. The action also was aimed at preventing former Communists from benefiting financially from German unification by disposing of their assets in a free market economy. The law passed by Parliament will allow Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere to form a commission in coming days that will have broad powers to search houses, interrogate witnesses and seize evidence. East Germany's economic minister, meanwhile, said in a newspaper interview Saturday that the nation will experience massive unrest during the difficult early stages of moving to a free market. ``I predict a hot autumn in the GDR,'' Gerhard Pohl was quoted as saying in the West Berlin newspaper Berliner Morgenpost. Many state-supported enterprises are certain to close when forced to compete with more efficient Western companies, and others will have to lay off workers to survive. Anywhere from 500,000 to 4 million people will lose their jobs in the first two years of unification, according to estimates. The country has about 10 million workers. ``Unrest among the populace cannot be avoided,'' Pohl said. East Germany is wrestling with how to dispose of the so-called ``people's-owned enterprises,'' of the old communist regime. Pohl said 168 such enterprises have been converted to some sort of joint private ownership, 200 are being considered for similiar status and 8,000 are still state-owned. He said all should be moved to the private sector by late October.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Against LaRouche Followers Dropped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to ADD suspects' hometowns.
DOC.TEXT: All charges against three followers of extremist Lyndon LaRouche accused of bilking an elderly woman out of $72,000 were dropped because of concern for the alleged victim's health, a prosecutor said. Patricia Noble-Schenk, Ron Fredman and Richard Blomquist, all of Chicago, had each faced charges of robbery, intimidation, theft by threat and three counts of residential burglary. Their second trial was to begin Monday in this northwestern Illinois town. ``The case is dismissed and now closed,'' Ogle County State's Attorney Dennis R. Schumacher said Friday. The three had been accused of bilking 89-year-old Harriet Driver out of $72,000. But during the first trial in March, Mrs. Driver became ill on the witness stand. She was hospitalized for a week, and a mistrial was declared. The three were employees of a Chicago-based company linked to LaRouche which solicited donations and distributed literature for the extremist. Prosecutors had said the three pressured Mrs. Driver to donate money, but the defense had argued Mrs. Driver gave the contributions willingly. ``We worked out our concerns with Mrs. Driver, her family and her doctors,'' Schumacher said Friday. ``We've decided that there is nothing further in the best interests of Mrs. Driver that we can do.'' LaRouche, who was convicted of federal charges of conspiracy and mail fraud, is serving a 15-year prison term in the federal medical prison in Rochester, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: In 13 Years of Grade School, High School, She Didn't Miss a Day
DOC.TEXT: Tracey A. Stewart will be missed when she graduates from high school Sunday. After all, teachers and students in Raleigh County have seen her in class every day for the past 13 years. ``Some times when I think about it, I think I must have been crazy,'' said Ms. Stewart, a senior at Liberty Raleigh High School. ``I can't believe I did all this for a certificate.'' Ms. Stewart said she has no secret formula for perfect attendance. ``I don't think it's a big deal,'' she said. ``My parents go to work, so I would rather go to school than be at home by myself.'' But she also said she'd probably not keep up the perfect record if she had it to do over again. Ann Stewart, Tracey's mother, said she remembers plenty of times when her daughter dragged herself from a sickbed to attend classes. ``There were times when I tried to get her to stay home from school, but she wouldn't do it,'' Mrs. Stewart said. Ms. Stewart said the closest she came to staying home was during her sophomore year, when she was depressed about her brother and his friends having graduated the year before. ``But I got over it,'' she said. Ms. Stewart had a lot of incentives besides classwork to make her get out of bed every day. She participated in basketball, volleyball and several clubs and held a job. Now, she's ready to move on to Beckley College and, eventually, West Virginia University. ``I'm just like every senior. I'm just ready to graduate,'' said Ms. Stewart.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Holds Annual Conference in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A group that monitors the Helsinki Accords on Saturday began two days of hearings on past Soviet human rights abuses in a test of whether the Kremlin would tolerate public discussion of its record. The hearings coincide with the superpower summit in Washington, where human rights issues were on the agenda of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush. Officials of the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights said they decided to hold their annual meeting in Moscow to gauge the city's suitability for hosting the 1991 Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. ``We wanted to see if it is possible to hold a private meeting in the Soviet Union without an official invitation or an official sponsor,'' said Jeri Laber, the group's director. So far, she said, there have been a few problems, especially with visas for Soviets living abroad, including former political prisoner Yuri Orlov. ``The problems have been solved, but not without lots of fights and discussions,'' she said. Gerald Nagler, a conference organizer, said many delegates, particularly those from Eastern Europe, had to wait until the last minute before receiving Soviet visas. Laber and Nagler said that since arriving in Moscow, the delegates had not been harassed or mistreated by authorities. The Helsinki Federation was founded in 1982 and is the umbrella group for the 17 national Helsinki Watch committees. It monitors compliance with the final provisions of the 1975 Helsinki Accords, which covered European security issues, economic cooperation and human rights. Moscow has been accepted as the site for the federation's 1991 meeting. But organizers said it was important to find out early whether it was possible to hold a meeting in the Soviet capital without political or bureaucratic interference. Before its public session Saturday, the group heard private reports from delegates, including Rosalynn Carter, wife of former U.S. president Jimmy Carter, and Yelena Bonner, the widow of activist Andrei Sakharov. The group later took testimony from Soviets about political prisoners, psychiatric abuse, prison conditions, legal changes and freedom of the press under the reforms initiated by Gorbachev. Findings will be presented at a meeting in Copenhagen June 6-7.

DOC.HEAD: Sign of Conflict: Street To Be Named for IRA Prisoner
LaserPhoto NY29
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Doherty is pronounced DOCK-er-tee.
DOC.TEXT: Irish Republican Army member Joe Doherty isn't leaving prison, but he's getting a new address _ one his supporters hope will refocus attention on his case as he starts his eighth year in a federal jail. The City Council this week is prepared to rename the street corner below his cell Joe Doherty Corner. The plan to honor Doherty, the convicted killer of a British army sergeant in 1980, has angered British officials who condemn him as a terrorist and a murderer. Supporters of the name change, which is to remain in effect until Doherty is released, hope it will help free him. ``It is an abomination that Doherty should be held in a prison in our city as long as he has been,'' said Carolyn Maloney, the city councilwoman who proposed the change. A City Council committee and a local community board already have approved the proposal. The full council is expected to pass the measure at its Tuesday session. Supporters hope to hold the official ceremony renaming the corner on June 18 _ the beginning of Doherty's eighth year at the jail. ``He's lived here as long, maybe longer, than most of the people in this neighborhood,'' said Paul Goldstein, district manager of the community board that approved the name change. Indeed, he has been in the Metropolitan Correctional Center longer than any other inmate in its history, longer than most of its guards. His seventh-floor cell and an orange prison jumpsuit are the fixtures in his life. Doherty was unaware of the move to rename the intersection until last week, when his lawyer, Mary Pike, told him about it. ``He was visibly delighted. ... He's touched and delighted that the people of the city have seen fit to address the injustice of his situation,'' Pike said. The 35-year-old prisoner has been the focus of a legal battle since his arrest at a Manhattan bar in 1983. Three years earlier, Doherty was convicted of murder in the machine-gun slaying of a British army captain during an IRA ambush in Northern Ireland. Doherty escaped from a Belfast prison before his conviction, used a false passport to enter the United States and avoided capture for two years. The British want him returned to finish his prison term. The Reagan and Bush administrations have supported their request but deportation has been blocked in the courts. Supporters say Doherty is a freedom fighter entitled to political asylum. And the list of those supporters is impressive: Mayor David Dinkins, Cardinal John J. O'Connor and more than 100 members of Congress have called for his release. The almost exclusively Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to push the British out of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, join it with the Republic of Ireland and set up an all-Ireland socialist state. Doherty has never been charged with a crime in the United States; he's been held without bail that entire time. His lawyers were back in court on Friday arguing for his release pending resolution of his status. Courts have ruled that he was entitled to a hearing on whether he should be given political asylum, but U.S. Attorneys General Edwin Meese and Dick Thornburgh have refused to grant him such a hearing. The whole matter is still being weighed in federal court in Manhattan. North of the prison in midtown Manhattan is the British Consulate, where reaction to the honor for Doherty was a mixture of surprise and disgust. ``He's a murderer. ... The vast majority of the people in Northern Ireland will feel somewhat bewildered and puzzled by the decision to name a street after him,'' said Brian Kirk, information director. It's not the first time city officials used a street sign to send a political message. Last year, the corner of 42nd Street and 12th Avenue _ the site of the Chinese Consulate _ was renamed Tiananmen Square. A section of First Avenue opposite the United Nations was christened Raoul Wallenberg Walk in 1985 after the Swedish diplomat who died or disappeared in Soviet custody after World War II. The victory by Doherty supporters does not mean he will be able to see a street sign through the jail's tiny windows. ``The irony is though the sign will be literally right outside, Joe will not see it,'' said Pike.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Focus on Europe's Future in Final Day of Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0538 to include AP logo
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a final full day of summitry, moved Saturday from the splendor of the White House to this rustic mountaintop hideaway to review regional disputes and make a last-minute stab at narrowing differences over Europe's future. ``I'm at the president's disposal,'' the Soviet leader said after a 30-minute helicopter ride with Bush from the South Lawn. Gorbachev said their talks, in the relaxed atmosphere of the 143-acre presidential compound, would give them a better understanding of each other. Bush, questioned by reporters, declined to discuss the day's agenda, but said, ``We have lovely trails here we can walk on. It's a totally relaxed environment.'' The heavily wooded camp, 65 miles northwest of Washington in the Catoctin Mountains, has been the site of momentous meetings by world leaders. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill met at the presidential retreat to plan the Normandy invasion. Dwight Eisenhower and Nikita Khrushchev forged the ``spirit of Camp David.'' Jimmy Carter brought the leaders of Israel and Egypt together there in search of Middle East peace. Bush and Gorbachev met at Aspen Lodge, a rustic building with a large living room and a picture window view of the mountainside. At lunch, they dined on sorrel soup, crabmeat salad and blueberry and nectarine sorbet. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arriving at Camp David before the leaders, expressed confidence about reaching a treaty before year's end to cut troops and tanks in Europe _ even though the summit has failed to make apparent progress on that front. ``We're very hopeful,'' Baker told reporters. Shevardnadze said, ``We are also quite ready for that. I have my pen ready.'' He took a pen from his pocket and waved it over his head. After two days of meetings, major differences still divided Bush and Gorbachev. The Soviet leader, concerned about the military strength of a united Germany, has opposed Bush's demand that the new nation be a full member of NATO, including its military command. Despite U.S. concerns, Gorbachev also has showed no sign of easing coercion of Lithuania, which is struggling for independence from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev told reporters that the main subject at Camp David was regional disputes _ which includes Afghanistan, the Middle East, Cuba, Central America and southern Africa. ``The most important thing today we're going to discuss is go over the planet and its flash points and discuss regional issues,'' the Soviet president said. ``And of course, we will pursue our general discussions in order to understand each other better.'' Bush and Gorbachev are to wrap up their summit with a mid-morning news conference Sunday at the White House. Afterward, the Soviet leader heads for talks with businessmen in Minneapolis and a rendezvous in San Francisco with former President Reagan and a meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on normalizing relations. The major business of the summit was concluded late Friday with agreement of a long-awaited deal to slash long-range nuclear missiles, an accord to halt production of chemical weapons and a trade pact that Gorbachev said was politically important for him at home. They also signed a five-year deal to expand U.S. grain sales to the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has described the Camp David meeting as the most important session of the summit, saying it will determine whether their achievements were ``just important or very important.'' Gorbachev is the third Soviet leader to visit. Following the Khrushchev-Eisenhower talks, Leonid Brezhnev met there with Richard Nixon. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev flew ahead of their husbands to Camp David and were on hand to greet them amid a formal naval welcoming ceremony. Because Camp David is run by the Navy, Bush and Gorbachev were ``piped'' aboard as if boarding a ship. A ship's bell heralded their arrival. Then, they boarded golf carts and rode away for their meetings. Mrs. Bush took the wheel of her cart, with Mrs. Gorbachev as her passenger. The president asked Gorbachev, ``Do you want to drive?'' Gorbachev deferred to his host. ``Forward, march,'' Bush said, with a hand signal. ``Here we go. A great day.'' Meanwhile at the State Department, U.S. and Soviet officials signed agreements establishing cultural and informational centers in Washington and Moscow and a pact aimed at doubling circulation of government magazines, ``America Illustrated'' and ``Soviet Life,'' distributed in the respective countries. They also signed a customs cooperation agreement in which U.S. officials would provide special training to Soviet customs agents in to stop smuggling of illegal drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats Nuclear Trigger Resumption Hinge on ``Criticality''
DOC.TEXT: As the Energy Department prepares to resume making nuclear warhead triggers at the Rocky Flats weapons plant, concern remains about 62 pounds of plutonium in the plant's air ducts. At issue: Whether enough plutonium has accumulated to lead to ``criticality'' _ the point at which a nuclear reaction become self-sustaining. Phil Warner, general manager at Rocky Flats for plant operator EG&G Inc., said the plutonium in the air ducts poses no threat, but state officials and environmentalists want the plutonium removed from the air ducts before plutonium processing resumes at the plant. Energy Secretary James Watkins suspended plutonium operations at Rocky Flats in November and said they only resume when safety problems are solved. Rocky Flats, 16 miles northwest of Denver, has been operating since 1953. The plutonium, discovered in the air ducts earlier this year, got into them over many years because filters that were supposed to catch the plutonium sometimes failed to work and sometimes were removed after becoming clogged, officials said. EG&G scientists have said that, in a worst-case scenario, the plutonium in the air ducts ``could release neutrons that could injure or kill within 10 feet,'' Warner said. ``To my knowledge, there's never been a criticality accident that involved a nuclear explosion,'' said Robert W. Terry, senior health physicist for the Colorado Department of Health. ``The hazard is to the plant workers in the immediate vicinity of the accident,'' he said. ``It's not the type of accident likely to create a widespread environmental hazard to the off-site population.'' Witnesses to nuclear criticality elsewhere say that when the nuclear reactions occurred, they saw a blue flash followed by ovenlike heat. Workers within the deadly 10-to-15 foot radius are bombarded with neutrons and gamma radiation. Their skin reddens and severe nausea sets in quickly. In extreme cases, the victim becomes comatose within 20 minutes and death follows in a few hours or days. The plutonium accumulation is the latest in a nearly chain of problems that began in June 1989 when the FBI and Environmental Protection Agency raided Rocky Flats, looking for evidence of illegal disposal of hazardous wastes. A federal grand jury is examining evidence gathered during that raid but has not issued indictments. Late last year, the Energy Department replaced Rockwell International as the plant operator with EG&G as the controversy over hazardous waste disposal at the plant heated up. EG&G took over Jan. 1. EG&G has completed its external radiation measurements of the air ducts, said Doug Croucher, director of nuclear safety for EG&G-Rocky Flats. Samples from two of the ducts have been sent to the government's Los Alamos laboratory in New Mexico to determine what form the plutonium is in, and if there are other hazardous substances present. ``When we've taken the samples (from all of the ducts) and know what's in there, then we'll end up with our plan on what we'll do,'' Warner said. ``We'll never get rid of all of it, but I think we'll find a way to deal with'' the air duct plutonium, said Victor Stello Jr., the Energy Department's deputy assistant secretary for facilities. Stello said if the plutonium is in an easily removable form, such as dust, it may be vacuumed out, he said. In other cases, the entire duct could be removed and replaced. Gov. Roy Romer, other elected officials and environmentalists are concerned the plant will be restarted too soon. Energy Department inspections planned in late June and July could lead to resumption of production by fall. Romer wants the air duct problem resolved before production is resumed, and he has asked Colorado's congressional delegation to hold hearings on whether the suspension of production at Rocky Flats has jeopardized the nation's security. ``His concern is if they are pushing too hard (to restart production at Rocky Flats) there might be a chance that corners will be cut. And we don't want that to happen,'' said John Haggard, Rocky Flats program manager for the Colorado Department of Health. But Melinda Kassen of Boulder, lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, maintains that the federal government``really hasn't made a case they have to restart at Rocky Flats for the purpose of national security.'' ``So, if it isn't absolutely necessary that they restart for national security, then why don't they use this opportunity to get into compliance with health and safety laws ... while they're shut down,'' she said. Critics also fear what would happen if fire would hit in those plutonium-contaminated ducts as it did in the plant's plating laboratory two weeks ago. The blaze caused more than $100,000 in damage, but no one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Officials Sign Culture and Customs Pacts
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union signed agreements Saturday to establish cultural centers in each other's capitals, increase circulation of two magazines and cooperate on customs enforcement. Under the customs agreement, the two sides will share information and the United States will train Soviet border agents in techniques to catch drug smugglers, said Carol Hallett, commissioner of the U.S. Customs Service. ``We're going to provide training and share our experience ... to assist them in preventing some of these problems from getting to the point they have for us,'' she said. Hallett also said the agreement could help stop the transfer of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons to unstable Third World countries. The three agreements, signed in a ceremony at the State Department, were negotiated earlier in the year and fill out a package of arms and trade accords announced by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday evening. Under the cultural agreement, each country will open a ``cultural and informational center'' in the other's capital, providing libraries, seminars, film showings, language instruction and student counseling. Bruce S. Gelb, director of the U.S. Information Agency, said the United States soon will begin looking for a building to house the cultural center in Moscow. He said the center should be in operation within two years. Under the magazine agreement, the circulations of ``America Illustrated,'' a Russian-language magazine published by the USIA, and ``Soviet Life,'' the Soviet government's English-language magazine, are to double to 250,000 copies a month in 1991. After 1991, the circulation of the two magazines is to be governed by demand and availability of funds.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Buys Posh San Francisco Hotel
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese hotel chain took over the posh Portman Hotel and changed its name after buying it for a reported $103 million. Tokyu Corp., a Tokyo-based conglomerate that owns 75 other hotels through various subsidiaries, on Friday formally took over the 331-room hotel a block from Union Square. New owners and managers greeted employees at the hotel's back door, and handed doormen pillbox hats bearing the hotel's new name, Pan Pacific. The Japanese conglomerate paid $103 million for the Portman and a 96-year lease for the land it occupies, according to reports in Saturday's San Francisco Chronicle. The hotel is the kind of ``trophy'' property that Japanese investors like to buy to establish an immediate presence in the American market, said Jay Scott, a consultant for Laventhol & Horwath. The 3-year-old hotel, which built its reputation by offering such upscale amenities as Rolls-Royce limousine service, has turned in disappointing results in recent years, analysts said. The previous owner was Atlanta-based Portman Properties, headed by architect-developer John Portman. The new owners plan an advertising blitz aimed at Southern California and New York, said Robert Wilhelm, managing director of the Pan Pacific Hotel. ``Our advertising budget for this year will be about $650,000, about double what it was under the Portman,'' Wilhelm said.

DOC.HEAD: Stage, Screen Actor Sir Rex Harrison Dies At 82
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Harrison created..', to CORRECT date of revival to 1981 sted 1979. SUBS 30th graf, `Harrison married...',to CORRECT spelling of wife's name to Mercia sted Marcia and ADD name of fifth wife. Picks up 31st graf pvs, `Harrison is...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY15, NY19, NY18, NY20
DOC.TEXT: Sir Rex Harrison, the English actor whose charm graced plays and films for half a century and made him the quintessential Henry Higgins in the musical ``My Fair Lady,'' died today at age 82. Attorney Harold Schiff said the actor died of pancreatic cancer in his sleep about 4:45 a.m. at his Manhattan residence. Knighted only last summer and still at work on Broadway three weeks before his death, Harrison was hailed as one of the most gifted comedians of his time. ``He's the best light comedy actor in the world,'' Noel Coward once said, ``next to me.'' Harrison created the role of Henry Higgins in the Broadway premiere of ``My Fair Lady'' in 1956, invented a style of half-talking, half-singing called ``soft singing'' and won a Tony award as best actor. He won an Academy Award for the same role in the 1964 film version, which also won the Oscar as best picture, and revived the role on the stage in 1981. He had appeared in his last play, ``The Circle,'' a revival of a 1920s comedy by W. Somerset Maugham, on Broadway until last month. He missed the last nine days of the run because of illness, said Jeffrey Richards, a spokesman for the play's producers. Elliot Martin, who produced ``the Circle'' and three other shows Harrison starred in, said he had noticed the actor was losing weight and did not look well in the final weeks that he performed. ``He said, `Well, these gallstones are acting up and I'll be all right after I have a bit of a rest,''' Martin recalled. ``He died with his boots on, no question about it,'' he said. Schiff said Harrison wasn't told about his cancer and ``didn't want to know. I saw him on Friday. He was OK. He was just fading away. Fortunately, there was no pain at all.'' When he was knighted last summer, Harrison said he had no intention of retiring, because ``I wouldn't know what to do.'' ``I think they rather like to leave awarding honors until you get to a certain age,' he said. ``It was a marvelous moment kneeling there and getting tapped on each shoulder.'' Among his films were ``Doctor Dolittle,'' 1967, and ``The Yellow Rolls-Royce,'' 1964. But his most famous film appearance was his reprise of his stage role as the stuffy language professor Higgins in ``My Fair Lady,'' who falls in love with a Cockney waif after teaching her how to speak proper English. The Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical, known for such songs as ``The Rain in Spain'' and ``I Could Have Danced All Night,'' was based on the George Bernard Shaw play ``Pygmalion.'' Married six times, Harrison said he brought much of himself to playing Higgins, who at first is cold and imperious with Eliza Doolittle. ``I wouldn't call it a hardness exactly, but in the piece I was trying to train this girl Eliza and she irritated the hell out of me,'' Harrison said in a 1989 interview with a London newspaper. ``Women can irritate the hell out of me. I don't tell women what to expect out of me. They learn to adjust, I suppose. Either that or they walk away, which has happened throughout my life.'' ``He was like all very great stars. He was temperamental, he was excitable and he was very funny,'' his agent, Lawrence Evans, said in London. ``He had the best sense of humor of almost any actor I have ever known,'' said Evans, who worked with the actor for more than 40 years. ``He was a lovable, irascible man.'' The actor last appeared on the London stage in ``The Admirable Crichton'' in 1988. ``He has now become a gently feathery presence who potters benignly about with little of the tenor bark that was once his trademark,'' wrote a critic for the Guardian newspaper. Harrison was born Reginald Carey Harrison in Huyton, near Liverpool, on March 5, 1908. He joined the Liverpool Repertory Theatre in 1924. His first appearance on the London stage was in 1930 and by the end of the decade he emerged as a star, having played in Rattigan's ``French Without Tears'' from 1936 to 1938. The first of his six marriages was in 1934 to Collette Thomas, a French teacher. Marriage number two was to actress Lili Palmer in 1943, and she accompanied him as he began his American career. Asked what sort of a husband he was, Miss Palmer once said: ``He was a man's man, an Englishman. Let's face it, Englishmen don't like women.'' After that marriage was dissolved in 1957, Harrison married actress Kay Kendall, who died of leukemia in 1959. Playwright Sir Terence Rattigan said of those times: ``I realized Rex's great courage. He made the last two years of Kay's life the best years.'' Years later, Harrison starred in Rattigan's ``In Praise of Love,'' the story of a man whose wife is dying of an incurable disease and is forbidden by doctors from telling her. Harrison married English actress Rachel Roberts in 1962. They were divorced in 1976. He then married Elizabeth Harris and later married Mercia Tinkler. Harrison is survived by his wife; two sons by previous marriages, Noel and Carey; a sister; and grandchildren. The funeral service will be private but there will be a memorial June 18 in Manhattan. Schiff said Harrison had requested his memorial be called a celebration and that there be jazz.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Visit to American Farm Will Be Mind-Boggling for Soviets
With AM-Summit-Soviet Reax, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev visits the Brand family farm in Minnesota on Sunday, the Soviet leader will see a picture-perfect 240-acre operation profitably run by four people _ an utterly alien concept at home. By contrast, the Dzerzhinsky Collective Farm on the outskirts of Moscow has 140 acres and a staff of 1,300. As a vegetable farm with greenhouses for winter crops, the Dzerzhinsky operation could be expected to have a few more workers than the Brands, who raise alfalfa, corn, soybeans and 75 dairy cows on their spread in Farmington. But the Soviet farm also has its own stores in Moscow, its own drivers and trucks to haul produce to the stores, its own construction workers to build farm buildings and housing for the staff. President Gorbachev's reforms allowed it to sell one-third of its crop at market prices last year, so the farm spent the profits on its own fully staffed hospital. Under the Communist system of bureaucratic distribution, it is difficult to obtain nearly everything _ from building supplies to the services of a skilled stonemason. There is no such thing as renting a spare tractor or running down to the local feed store for a few supplies. So state businesses have evolved into huge self-contained communities, hoarding scarce resources like trucks and construction workers so they will be available when needed. The result is massive inefficiency. Soviet farms employ more than eight times as many people as American farms. And they produce far less food, even using the production statistics that Soviets now admit are inflated. Many Soviet farms resort to old-fashioned barter to obtain needed materials. Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, reported Saturday that one collective farm traded 30 tons of meat and 50 tons of potatoes to a Dnepopetrovsk factory for metal, wire fencing and other products. Gorbachev himself has said 25 percent of his country's crops are lost in harvest and storage. Soviet farming also has taken a toll on people. Working and living conditions in isolated villages drive some residents to drink heavily, the government newspaper Izvestia reported Saturday in an article about eight farmers from Tula who died after downing a poison they thought contained alcohol. Gorbachev is bringing needed change to Soviet agriculture. He promises a switch to a market system, albeit slowly. He pushed through reforms to allow family farming on land leased from the state for up to 50 years, and he has allowed more produce to be sold directly to consumers. But he still won't allow a Soviet family to own their own farm. That idea veers too closely to capitalism. Gorbachev tried to raise grain production and reduce imports last year by promising to pay Soviet farmers in foreign currency for exceeding planned production. Newspapers reported the program a failure. Most farmers, disbelieving the offer, ignored it. Last month, Gorbachev doubled the price paid to farmers for their grain, and bread prices are expected to triple on July 1 to help cover that change. As Gorbachev said in Washington on Friday, he was naive to think that minor tinkering with the Soviet system would fix the economy. ``There was no incentive. There was no motivation for people to work,'' he said. But many Soviets question Gorbachev's intentions on agricultural reform. There will be no radical change, reformers say, as long as the key Communist Party post in charge of agriculture is held by Yegor Ligachev, an ardent believer in collective farming.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Officials, Media Believe Gorbachev No Whirling Dervish
DOC.TEXT: When Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev climbed aboard Marine One for a 30-minute flight to Camp David on Saturday, it may have been his first ride in a helicopter. In the past, he has avoided them. Most foreign leaders who visit Washington and arrive by jet at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland take a short helicopter ride to the White House. But on his arrival last Wednesday for a four-day summit meeting with President Bush, Gorbachev traveled into the city by motorcade and made his formal appearance at the White House the following morning. During his December 1987 summit with former President Reagan, Gorbachev declined an offer to take a helicopter from Andrews to the White House. All U.S. presidents since Dwight Eisenhower have made frequent use of helicopters, both for speed and to avoid tying up Washington street traffic with motorcades. But Gorbachev, who has flown in many jets, has never been known to use a helicopter, either inside or outside the Soviet Union. A leading Soviet journalist, Novosti Press Agency head Albert I. Vlasov, said he believed Saturday's flight was the Soviet leader's first in a whirlybird. Soviet diplomats said they did not know whether Gorbachev has an aversion to choppers, but one official said it would not be strange if he did. ``So who does like helicopters?'' said the Soviet official, who requested anonymity. ``They shake, they whirl around, they make noise. A car is much better _ if you can take one.'' As helicopters go, however, the presidential version _ a modified military H-3 _ is relatively comfortable. It is VIP-equipped with a dozen seats. Bush sits in a captain's type chair, facing another one, which Gorbachev presumably used. There is a pull down table that can be opened between them, or left up for more leg room. The rest of the seats are bench-style along the sides. To give Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev the same comfortable seats their husbands got, they flew to Camp David in a separate but identical helicopter, departing from the South Lawn of the White House 10 minutes after the two heads of state.

DOC.HEAD: Tough Issues Still Block Treaty _ And Star Wars Could Come Out Of Closet
DOC.TEXT: Three major issues _ and possibly that old nemesis, Star Wars _ still block the way to a landmark treaty to cut U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles. Despite optimistic summit statements by President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, indicating the treaty can be concluded this year, roughly 30 issues remain unresolved. Ever since 1982, when President Ronald Reagan reversed his skepticism of the arms control process and proposed deep cuts in globe-girdling nuclear bombers, missiles and submarines, American and Soviet negotiators have been grappling with a multitude of thorny issues. One of the most difficult was the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative, known informally as Star Wars, the Reagan dream of mounting a defense in space against Soviet ballistic missiles. Moscow threatened to delay cutting offensive arms unless the United States abandoned that program. Last year, the Soviets relented. But they did not swear never to try again. And last week, as negotiators working at the State Department burrowed into the toughest remaining offensive weapons issues, the Soviets tried again to establish what the experts call ``linkage.`` A senior U.S. official, describing the attempt, said Friday night: ``We thought we had this problem straight, and then the Soviets made proposals that unraveled it. And that sort of slowed us up on the pace that we were on because we had to push them back onto the ground that had been agreed _ which we managed to do.'' The tactic that worked was deferring the issue to a second round of negotiations to be held immediately after the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) is signed. ``In the future talks the two sides will discuss strategic stability issues of interest to them,'' a joint statement issued Friday night said, ``including the the relationship between strategic offensive and defensive arms...'' That appears to mean the Star Wars genie is back in the bottle. But it has a way of escaping. In the meantime, American and Soviet negotiators must confront three tough issues when the bargaining resumes June 11 in Geneva. They are: _The kinds of restrictions to impose on the 154 heavy, ground-based SS-18 intercontinental missiles the Soviets will retain under the treaty. Secretary of State James A. Baker III proposed last month in Moscow very limited testing, but the Soviets are demanding more freedom to improve their deadliest nuclear weapon. _Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a strategic weapon, as the United States demands. That would mean counting Backfires against numerical weapons limits established in the treaty. The Soviets have offered to make a declaration that the bomber would not be used on intercontinental missions. And they are willing to restrict in-flight fueling, as the Soviets offered to do 13 years ago. _The restrictions to be imposed on U.S. and Soviet transfers of weapons barred under the treaty to allies _ from the United States to Britain, for instance. Surveying the road ahead of him, a senior U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, acknowledged: ``So we've got our work cut out for us.'' But, he added: ``We can continue with the president's commitment to finish a treaty this year. And we intend to do so.'' Apart from the three tough issues, and a lot of unfinished work on how inspectors will make sure the cuts are faithfully executed, there are more than two-dozen other issues to be ironed out. Also, there is the vexing problem of the text itself. More than 400 pages have been compiled already in Geneva, but the wordage will mount as negotiators come to closure on unsettled issues. And then will come the lawyers, poring over the language for loopholes. It is a serious task, as the debate in the Reagan years over the meaning of the 1972 U.S.-Soviet Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty showed. The treaty restricted anti-missile defenses as a means of deterring a nuclear attack. The theory was a potential aggressor would not risk devastating retaliation by launching a first strike. However, the advent of the Strategic Defense Initiative marked a change in U.S. strategy. The Reagan administration, the Senate, which had ratified the 1972 treaty, the Soviet Union and the arms control community examined the text under a magnifying glass. Proponents looked for evidence the program was legal, opponents for proof it was not. The administration insisted the treaty did not prohibit the development of an anti-missile system using nuclear weapons in space. The Soviets and American critics, including all the former U.S. negotiators except Paul H. Nitze, said Star Wars was in confict with the treaty. The debate has subsided with Bush administration's muted enthusiasm for Reagan's dream. But the seeds of disagreement are firmly planted. Initially, the treaty was advertised as massively cutting U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear weapons _ by 50 percent. That claim is not made any more. In the negotiations the two sides have cut various deals to allow them to hold on to favorite weapons through a variety of strategems. For instance, the United States can pack 20 air-launched cruise missiles aboard a B52 bomber, but the warheads will be counted as 10 apiece on the first 150 bombers. Jack Mendelsohn, deputy director of the private Arms Control Association, said Saturday that the treaty, as it stands now, would result in a 30 percent reduction in U.S. ballistic warheads. The Soviets would have to destroy 50 percent of their warheads, as well as 50 percent of their 308 SS-18 missiles and the throw-weight _ or deliverable power _ of the missiles, Mendelsohn said in an interview. But the treaty also will give the two sides enough leeway to rejigger their strategic weapons arsenals in a way that will result in an overall reduction of no more than 10 to 20 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Killings of Two More British Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army on Saturday claimed responsibility for the shooting deaths of two British soldiers, striking less than a week after it killed two tourists in the Netherlands. Gunmen of the group fighting British rule in Northern Ireland killed a British army major Saturday outside his home in Dortmund, West Germany, and wounded a police officer when they got away during a chase. In the central English town of Lichfield, police hunted for two men who shot and killed a soldier and wounded two others waiting for a train Friday afternoon. ``While British troops remain in Ireland such attacks will continue,'' the IRA said in a statement distributed to news media in Dublin, Ireland. On Sunday, IRA gunmen killed two London-based Australian lawyers in the town square in Roermond, the Netherlands. The IRA later said it had mistaken the men for soldiers. ``There is no argument or reason in this. It is simply that they are out to kill,'' Defense Secretary Tom King said Saturday in an interview with Press Association, the domestic news agency. ``They are out to cover the humiliation of their mistake in killing two young Australians in Holland,'' he said. The attacks in the Netherlands, Germany and England continued an IRA strategy of attacking ``soft'' targets associated with the British army, such as off-duty soldiers or recruiting centers. The IRA, a mainly Roman Catholic group, seeks to unite Ireland under a socialist government. It is outlawed both in the predominantly Catholic Republic of Ireland and in Northern Ireland, a British province where paramilitary Protestant groups side with London. Rolf Hannich, a spokesman for the West German federal prosecutor, said Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee was shot several times in the head as he returned to his home in a British army housing area in Dortmund just after midnight. ``He had parked his car and gotten out when one of two persons in a Mazda car shot him,'' Hannich said, quoting a Dortmund police report. His wife was in the car but was not hurt. The suspects' silver Mazda was spotted a short time later in Dortmund and two police cars tried to stop it. ``Shots were fired from the Mazda at the police cars chasing it, and one policeman was hit in the foot,'' Hannich said. The car was later found abandoned in Hamm-Boenen, about 15 miles east of the murder scene. It was the second IRA killing in less than a year in Dortmund, home to about 10,000 British soldiers. On Sept. 7, an IRA unit killed Heidi Hazell, 26, the German-born wife of a British soldier. About five hours before the West German attack, two men with handguns shot the three soldiers at the Lichfield City rail station, about 100 miles northwest of London, then fled across the tracks. The Ministry of Defense identified the dead man as 19-year-old Pvt. William Robert Davies of Pontarddulais, South Wales. The wounded men were Robert Parkin, 20, and Neil Evans, 19, the Ministry of Defense said. The attacks followed a spate of reports last week that Peter Brooke, the top British official in Northern Ireland, was making progress toward arranging negotiations on a new political agreement for the province. Brooke's delicate initiative is intended to open negotiations between Protestant parties and the mainly Roman Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party. Sinn Fein, the IRA political wing _ which draws about a third of the Catholic vote in Northern Ireland _ is excluded from the negotiations. The IRA and other republican splinter groups fighting British rule have caused more than half of the nearly 2,800 deaths in Northern Ireland since the British army entered the province in 1969. In addition, the IRA has killed at least 14 people in Europe and several dozen in England, including 21 in pub bombings in Birmingham in 1974 and 11 Marine bandsmen in Deal, Kent, in September. Loyalist paramilitary groups associated with Protestants in Northern Ireland are responsible for about one-fourth of the deaths, while 12 percent are blamed on the police and army, according to a study published last year by Irish journalist Michael McKeown.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Not Optimistic About Cambodia Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whose rebels are fighting the country's Communist regime, arrived Saturday for peace talks, but he said other guerrillas may not honor a proposed cease-fire. ``There will be a dangerous situation after the signing,'' Sihanouk said in Beijing before boarding a plane for Tokyo. ``There will be peace on paper but not on the ground.'' The three days of talks toward ending the 11-year-old civil war are mired in dispute even before their scheduled start Monday. The Hun Sen government supported by Vietnam refuses to consider giving an equal voice to Sihanouk's powerful Communist allies, the Khmer Rouge. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in 1978 to end three years of rule by the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge, whose repressive policies are blamed for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Cambodians. Sihanouk, who also represents two non-Communist guerrilla groups supported by the United States, said in Beijing that he will sign the cease-fire accord with Premier Hun Sen ``to show the good will of the resistance and in order to show that I am in favor of a quick return of peace in Cambodia.'' But he said the Khmer Rouge, the strongest of the three guerrilla factions, have told him they are unhappy with the agreement crafted by Thailand's defense minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh.
