The Khmer Rouge claim Vietnamese troops still occupy Cambodia despite a massive pullout last year and that Vietnam has annexed Cambodian territory. ``So there will be a possibility that in Tokyo the Khmer Rouge will more or less sabotage the peace process,'' Sihanouk said. He also criticized Hun Sen for saying that Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan should not be allowed to sign the peace accord. By ostracizing the Khmer Rouge leader, Sihanouk said, ``indirectly Hun Sen encourages the Khmer Rouge to go on fighting.'' Sihanouk said there will be no effective body to oversee the cease-fire, and he called for reconvening the Paris Conference on Cambodia, which ended in failure last year. Resistance forces led by the Khmer Rouge have launched major attacks in recent days in a drive to expand areas under their control before the June 4-6 Tokyo meeting. Guerrilla leaders and diplomats say the Khmer Rouge have made the most substantial gains, but the pro-Hanoi government of Hun Sen also has been active on the battlefields. Sihanouk, 67, was not available to reporters upon arriving in Tokyo. He held a 55-minute meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and thanked him for agreeing to a Thai suggestion to host the conference, a Foreign Ministry official told reporters. Speaking on condition of anonymity, the official said Sihanouk told Kaifu he had made a major compromise in recently proposing that two sides _ his guerrilla coalition and the Hun Sen government _ make up a national council to prepare for elections.

DOC.HEAD: `My Fair Lady,' `Dr. Dolittle' Actor Rex Harrison Dies at 82
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 18th graf, `Among them...', to CORRECT spelling of Dr. Dolittle, one `o'. Eliza Doolittle with two o's is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY15, 19, 20, 21 and 27; LaserColor NY24
DOC.TEXT: Oscar-winning actor Sir Rex Harrison, who taught the king's English in ``My Fair Lady'' and talked to animals as the lovable Dr. Dolittle during a 66-year career, died in his sleep Saturday. He was 82. The actor, a stage and screen star in the United States and his native England, died of pancreatic cancer at his Manhattan home, said his attorney, Harold Schiff. ``To watch him and to work with him was a joyful experience,'' said Julie Andrews, who played Eliza Doolittle to Harrison's professor Henry Higgins in ``My Fair Lady'' on Broadway for three years. ``I doubt there was anyone before like him. ... The theater has lost an extraordinary one-of-a-kind.'' Harrison won a Tony award for his Broadway portrayal of Higgins and earned a best-actor Academy Award for his screen version opposite Audrey Hepburn. ``He was the essence of a great actor, a fabulous technician. ... He had a wonderful sense of humor, fabulous diction,'' Miss Hepburn said. ``He was the personification of a superb actor, the quintessential actor. ``He was always thoughtful and helpful and fun, and I really adored every minute I worked with him.'' Harrison had been ill only a short time and did not know he had cancer, Schiff said. Doctors told him he was suffering from gall bladder trouble, the lawyer said. ``He just thought he was not well. He didn't want to know,'' Schiff said. Harrison, who debuted on Broadway in 1936, died three weeks after his latest appearance there May 11. He played Lord Porteous in W. Somerset Maugham's 1920s comedy ``The Circle,'' which is vying for ``best revival'' honors at Sunday night's Tony Awards ceremony. ``He died with his boots on, no question about it,'' said ``Circle'' producer Elliot Martin, referring to Harrison's decision not to retire. ``He wanted to be on the stage. That was it. That was his life,'' Schiff said. ``He didn't care about ... retiring, he didn't care about anything else but the theater.'' Harrison was best known for his high-tone Higgins in ``My Fair Lady.'' ``Mr. Harrison is perfect in the part _ crisp, lean, complacent and condescending until at last a real flare of human emotions burns the egotism away,'' New York Times critic Brooks Atkinson wrote. The musical version of George Bernard Shaw's ``Pygmalion'' opened on Broadway in 1956, with the film coming out eight years later. Harrison reprised his role in a 1981 Broadway revival that earned him $50,000 a week. Harrison, who characterized his vocal range as ``one and a half notes,'' half-spoke, half-crooned ``I've grown accustomed to her face'' hundreds of times as the stuffy language professor who falls in love with a Cockney waif after teaching her how to overcome her lower-class accent and speak proper English. ``I could have played Higgins for 20 years, but I wanted to do other things,'' Harrison said in 1985. ``And I did, in fact.'' Among them was his role as Dr. Dolittle, the fanciful jungle gentleman who conversed with wildlife. The film introduced Harrison to a new generation of young moviegoers. Earlier prominent roles came in the 1940 film ``Major Barbara'' and ``Blithe Spirit'' in 1945. ``He had the best sense of humor of almost any actor I have ever known,'' said his agent, Lawrence Evans, who worked with Harrison for more than 40 years. ``He was a lovable, irascible man.'' Harrison was born in Huyton, near Liverpool, on March 5, 1908, and joined the Liverpool Repertory Theatre in 1924. His first appearance on the London stage was in 1930. By the end of the decade he emerged as a star, appearing in Sir Terence Rattigan's ``French Without Tears'' from 1936 to 1938. He last appeared on the London stage in ``The Admirable Crichton'' in 1988. In addition to his awards for ``My Fair Lady,'' Harrison won a Tony for his portrayal of Henry VIII in Maxwell Anderson's ``Anne of the Thousand Days'' and a special American Theater Award for his overall stage achievements. He was knighted last year by Queen Elizabeth II and described the event as ``a marvelous moment.'' Harrison, dubbed ``Sexy Rexy'' by the late columnist Walter Winchell, was married six times. He is survived by his wife, Mercia Tinker; a sister; two sons by previous marriages; and several grandchildren. He first married in 1934 to Collette Thomas, a French teacher. He married actress Lili Palmer in 1943 and she accompanied him as he extended his career to the United States. In 1957, Harrison married actress Kay Kendall, who died of leukemia in 1959. Rattigan said of those times: ``I realized Rex's great courage. He made the last two years of Kay's life the best years.'' Years later, Harrison starred in Rattigan's ``In Praise of Love,'' the story of a man whose wife is dying of an incurable disease and is forbidden by doctors from telling her. Harrison married English actress Rachel Roberts in 1962. He then married Elizabeth Harris, and then Miss Tinker. The funeral will be private, but there will be a public memorial service June 18 at the Little Church Around the Corner in Manhattan. Harrison requested that the service feature jazz music, Schiff said. In lieu of flowers, the family asked instead for contributions to establish a Rex Harrison Scholarship in Drama at Boston University and to benefit collections at the school and at the Actor's Fund in Englewood, N.J., or the Little Church Around the Corner.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Ken Wahl is leaving the ``Wiseguy'' TV series he has starred in since 1987, but a dispute remains over whether he really wanted to go. The actor says he was fired by the show's executive producer, Stephen J. Cannell. Not so, says Cannell, one of Hollywood's leading writer-producers. ``I still want him to do the show,'' he said. But, he added, that Wahl wrote to him saying he wanted out. Wahl, speaking by phone from Mexico where he is making a movie, said the letters were written ``only to get their lawyers off my back, because I had no intention of leaving the show.'' The Wahl-Cannell flap surfaced after CBS announced last week that it was pulling ``Wiseguy'' from its prime-time schedule for retooling. Once it returns at midseason, Wahl is to leave after a few episodes while Steven Bauer is introduced as the new star. Wahl said the trouble between himself and the show's producers began last season when an old injury flared up. ``They didn't believe the doctors and they didn't believe me about being hurt,'' he said. Later, he said, Cannell told him he was unhappy with the show and wanted to revamp it. ``He thought that he'd get into creative arguments with me. So he said, `Why don't we shake hands and leave it go at that?','' Wahl said.

Actor Robert Redford called Saturday for a surge in grass-roots political action to force politicians to move quickly on environmental issues. ``Poll after poll indicates that the people are way ahead of the politicians,'' Redford said. ``It is time to send a message to our elected officials _ that if they do not protect our environment, they will be voted out of office or never get elected in the first place.'' ``I don't think we need to wait around anymore for something to come from the top,'' he said. ``It ain't gonna happen. I don't want to be told, `Read my lips' when the lips aren't saying anything.'' During commencement ceremonies at the University of Massachusetts campus near Boston Harbor, Redford said President Bush failed to follow up on campaign promises on the environment. ``President Bush made Boston Harbor a big campaign item, but after the election, when there were no more TV ads, he cut funding that would have cleaned it up by $400 million,'' Redford said. Redford, who received an honorary doctorate, also encouraged students to buy environmentally safe products. ``If you stop buying things that destroy the planet, companies will stop making them,'' he said. Redford, star of such films as ``The Sting'' and ``Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' is the founder and president of the Institute for Resource Management, which sponsored a conference on global warming last summer.

Former world heavyweight boxing champ Larry Holmes threw his weight around in court for a family friend. He appeared in Dade District Court on behalf of 19-year-old Saudi Rogers, who was arrested twice last year on drug charges and wanted to be released early from house arrest. The fighter told Judge Fred Moreno that he believed Rogers could be trusted and said he helped the youth get a job at a Jacksonville hotel. ``He's on a straight line, and I wouldn't be here if he wasn't,'' Holmes said. The judge granted the request Friday, saying, ``I have a feeling if he screwed up you could take care of him probably better than me.'' The court appearance by Holmes, a longtime friend of Rogers' widowed mother, generated a crowd of autograph seekers that included lawyers, bailiffs, guards, police officers and defendants. Some of the spectators were begging for sheets of paper from legal pads to have something for Holmes to write on.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last two items also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano said Saturday ``it's very likely'' that he will sign a contract to become a basketball analyst for ABC. ``It's a bit premature for me to say anything,'' Valvano said before teeing off in a charity golf tournament. ``We're hopeful that things will be worked out.'' Valvano also said he expected the deal to be announced by ABC on Monday. The former coach, who was forced to resign in April after irregularities were disclosed in the Wolfpack basketball program, said he would continue to live in Raleigh. The Greensboro News & Record also reported that Valvano would sign a three-year, $900,000 contract to become color analyst for ABC and ESPN next season. Neither network would confirm the report, the newspaper said.

Former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson's $85,000 Mercedes is taking an impounding. And he may lose the car if a certain bill isn't paid. Tyson's 1990 gold Mercedes-Benz 500SL convertible _ with car phone and leather interior _ has been sitting in the city of Hudson's car pound for nearly a month. At week's end, he owed $126 for towing and storage fees. City officials mailed a notice to Tyson on Thursday, advising him that he has to reclaim the car within 10 days of receipt of the letter or else lose it to the city of Hudson. An auction may be held by late June. The car was impounded May 2 after police arrested 31-year-old Isadore Philip Bolton, described as a Tyson aide, for driving it without license plates and a registration. Sgt. Eugene Shetsky, who's in charge of the city's impounded cars, said he doesn't like the car just lying around, adding: ``There are a lot of other things to think about than an $85,000 car.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Decisions on China, Lithuania Set Stage for Trade Pact
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: True, there were some 11th-hour negotiations. But the seeds of President Bush's decision to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union were sown in his renewal of trade benefits for the Chinese and his refusal to impose sanctions against Moscow over Lithuania. Bush's action meant that for the second time in as many weeks, he was ignoring widespread congressional opposition to a trade agreement with a regime whose human rights policies have been sharply criticized. Bush's earlier renewal of trade benefits to China and his decision not to slap economic sanctions on Moscow over its hardline approach in the Baltic states made it harder for him to say no to an anxious Gorbachev, some aides are suggesting. If Bush won any private assurances from Gorbachev on Lithuania in exchange for the trade deal, neither side was letting on. U.S. officials insisted that Bush did not extract any such commitment from Gorbachev; and Soviet officials continue to characterize the stalemate as an internal dispute that they will resolve themselves. U.S. sources said that, even though Soviet officials balked at the last minute at signing a grain deal, Bush's mind was not made up by this last minute Soviet attempt at haggling. Instead, Gorbachev's fervent, direct appeal for the agreement and Bush's desire to help strengthen the hand of the embattled Soviet leader at home had more bearing on his decision, the officials. ``It was quite obvious that Gorbachev was seeking something on the economic front. It's obviously something that he wanted to take home,'' said one official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The Soviet leader himself made it clear in his comments to congressional leaders on Friday at the Soviet Embassy that he sorely wanted the trade pact. And, in fact, Gorbachev himself raised the specter of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in noting that the United States had extended its most-favored-nation trade hand to Beijing _ but not to Moscow. Gorbachev pressed the same points in meetings with Bush both on Thursday and on Friday, said an administration official. At one point, Bush even expressed frustration that the Supreme Soviet had not yet acted on-long pending legislation to codify more-liberal emigration policies, sources said. The Soviet leader told Bush he would make an even harder effort to get the law passed, the sources said. Sources said Gorbachev's forceful pleas, together with Bush's historical bias against economic sanctions, helped the Soviet leader win his case. As Bush and Gorbachev relaxed at the U.S. presidential retreat here in the Cactoctin Mountains of Maryland on Saturday, the divisive trade decision was behind them and they went on to other issues. But the Bush administration still faces a likely battle in Congress as the president tries to win approval of the new agreement. A tough battle is also expected on the China move. With China, Bush renewed already existing most-favored-nation status for another year. But the Soviet Union has not had most-favored-nation status since 1952, when it was revoked by Congress. The Jackson-Vanik amendment to the 1974 Trade Act requires a country to have both a trade agreement with the United States and a law allowing free emigration before it can be granted most-favored-nation status. In giving Gorbachev the trade agreement _ the first part of the equation _ Bush also attached a short string. He told the Soviet leader he would not even send the measure to Congress for approval until the Supreme Soviet passes the emigration law. However, the strings extended only to emigration policy, not Lithuania. And the absence of any Soviet concessions on Lithuania is what is likely to stir the most opposition. The Senate passed a resolution May 1 urging Bush to hold off granting most-favored-nation status to the Soviets until they lifted the blockade against Lithuania. Administration officials are backpeddling _ trying to assert that there never had been a link between trade and Lithuania. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday, ``There has been no formal linkage by anybody in this administration that I am aware of'' between the two issues. Baker didn't place it there, but the emphasis clearly was on the word ``formal'' since before the summit one official after another had informally linked the trade pact with progress on two fronts: the Soviet emigration law and Lithuania.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Palestinian Leader Warns of Anti-U.S. Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A pro-PLO Palestinian leader in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip said Saturday that U.S. targets in the region might be attacked as anti-American sentiment intensifies. ``I'm thinking of people who will just want to express their anger, both against American symbols and American institutions,'' Palestinian intellectual Sari Nusseibeh said in an interview. He said he and others who have urged restraint are becoming increasingly isolated. Palestinians are angered by Washington's veto of a U.N. Security Council resolution calling for a council-appointed team to be sent to the occupied lands to report on Israeli abuses. U.S. Embassy spokesman Don Cofman said U.S. officials ``are aware of the mood in the territories,'' but he declined comment when asked whether additional steps had been taken to protect Americans. The U.S. State Department issued a travel advisory for the Middle East on Thursday, urging Americans to use ``extreme caution.'' The advisory cited the recent upsurge of violence. Cofman also refused comment on reports confirmed by Israeli officials that the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv's beachfront hotel district was one of the targets of Palestinian guerrillas intercepted by Israeli forces off the coast Wednesday. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured in the failed sea raid. The Palestine Liberation Front of Mohammed Abbas claimed its guerrillas were involved. The Front is a faction of the PLO and on Saturday Kuwait's al-Watan newspaper quoted Abbas as apologizing for not informing PLO leader Yasser Arafat in advance of the failed attack. Abbas said, however, that more attacks will be launched against Israel. Arafat has disassociated the PLO from the operation but has stopped short of condemning it outright. The U.S. State Department has left open the possibility that the operation could affect the U.S.-PLO dialogue begun after Arafat renounced terrorism in December 1988. Wednesday's incident was the latest in an upsurge of violence that began with the May 20 massacre of seven Arab laborers by an Israeli gunman. Israeli security forces killed 16 Palestinians and hurt hundreds in subsequent protests. Two Israelis were killed in retaliation, including a 72-year-old man who died in a bomb explosion in Jerusalem. In the Gaza Strip on Saturday, five Palestinian teen-agers were wounded by army gunfire in clashes, Arab doctors said. An army official said he was checking the reports. Jerusalem police spokesman Uzi Sandori said Saturday that police dismantled a bomb attached to a gas balloon in a Jerusalem restaurant. The bomb was discovered after police noticed four masked youths near the restaurant and began searching the area, he said. On the northern outskirts of Jerusalem, ultra-Orthodox Jewish youths gathered along a main thoroughfare and stoned Arab-owned cars, Israel radio said. Nusseibeh, described by Israel as one of the heads behind the 30-month Palestinian uprising, said young Arab activists are increasingly pressuring for more violence against Israel. He said the Arabs in the occupied lands are rapidly losing hope that a peace settlement can be reached. He blamed hard-line Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who has rejected U.S. proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. ``There is going to be a rapid deterioration into a cycle of bloodshed and violence,'' Nusseibeh told The Associated Press in a telephone interview Saturday. ``I believe more and more Palestinians will turn to using guns and explosives. I assume that the Unified Leadership will probably go with the people,'' said Nusseibeh, referring to the underground umbrella group of various PLO factions coordinating the uprising. ``It's quite possible that there will also be attacks against American targets,'' he said. Until now, the uprising leadership has ordered activists to stick to stones and firebombs, saying that the use of firearms would only give Israel an excuse to crack down harder. On Friday, Palestinian leaders including Nusseibeh declared a boycott on contacts with U.S. diplomats and called on the Arab world to boycott U.S.-made goods to protest the U.S. veto in the Security Council. In response, the 15,000-member Gaza Strip Trade Union Federation on Saturday called on workers in the Arab world to refuse servicing U.S. planes and ships on Tuesday. That day marks the 23rd anniversary of the start of the 1967 Middle East war in which Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Algae Muddies Clear Lake; Ballot Proposal Would Create Special Distict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT spelling of Karan.
DOC.TEXT: Clear Lake is anything but _ as anyone who's seen the algae blanketing its surface can attest. But supporters of Measure A on Tuesday's ballot aim to make North America's oldest lake worthy of its name. It would establish an ``algae abatement district,'' similar to mosquito abatement districts, water districts and fire districts. With an average depth of about 35 feet, Clear Lake's warm water is host to a delicate ecosystem and more than 100 varieties of algae, including three kinds of blue-green ``nuisance'' algae. Usually, the algae goes unnoticed by scores of bass anglers and tourists who flock to the lake for fun and fishing. ``All we need is a good afternoon breeze to blow it away,'' said Bob Mingori, president of the Lake County Chamber of Commerce. ``Generally, it's the sign of a healthy lake.'' But every so often, on no particular schedule, the algae ``blooms,'' creating a thick, smelly, oil-like slick. When it rots, it creates methane gas that kills fish, and the stink chases away tourists. Fed up with debates and studies, Sylvia Savage modeled Measure A after another nuisance: the mosquito. Savage's proposal would require Lake County to set aside money for algae cleanup. ``I want to immediately start reducing it by getting boats and water barges and vacuuming that algae up,'' said Savage. She said that a similar effort in 1985 cleaned a one-mile area and scooped up more than 200 pounds of algae in less than one hour. But critics of Measure A fear it could drain county funds. Instead, residents hardest hit by the algae outbreaks can control the problem privately by pumping air into the water or spraying it down with hoses, they maintain. County Supervisor Karan Mackey said it would be irresponsible to create a second special district when the mosquito district could handle the algae challenge. ``We are not trying to make this lake clear,'' Mackey said. ``It has never been clear.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Journalist, Moslem Shopkeeper Kidnapped
DOC.TEXT: Two men posing as army officers on Saturday kidnapped a local journalist reporting on the Moslem separatist movement in Kashmir for Western news organizations, officials said. Hours later a Moslem shopkeeper also was abducted in a similar manner, said the officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules. No one claimed responsibility for the alleged kidnappings, and it was not immediately clear if the two incidents were related. The kidnappings occurred during a break in a curfew. Hundreds of people have died in violence since a government crackdown on separatists began in January. Officials said journalist Yusuf Jameel, a Kashmiri Moslem who has reported for Time magazine, the British Broadcasting Corp. and Reuters, was led away from his home in Srinagar. The city is the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state and the cradle of the movement to secede from mostly Hindu India. A servant of Jameel, Hakim Din, said two men wearing army officers' uniforms arrived at the house in a jeep similar to ones used by the military and demanded to meet the reporter. Jameel's colleague, photographer Mehraj Uddin, who also lives in the house, said Jameel told him: ``I am being arrested by the army. Take care of yourself.'' The government denied Jameel was arrested or taken away by ``any of the security forces or the army for helping any investigation.'' A state government spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said officials suspect foul play by people bent on ``maligning the administration and the security forces.'' He said the police registered the case as a kidnapping and started investigations ``in the right earnest to trace out Mr. Jameel and culprits.'' Jameel also has reported for The Telegraph, a major Indian daily based in Calcutta. Four hours after Jameel's disappearance, two men wearing military uniforms who arrived in a jeep took away a shopkeeper, Ghulam Mohammad Gujwari, in another Srinagar neighborhood, the government officials said. Residents on Saturday used the curfew break, the first in 12 days in Srinagar, to stock up on sorely needed food supplies. A combination of round-the-clock curfews imposed by the government and strikes ordered by Moslem militants have made daily life difficult in the city. At least 486 people have been killed since January in Kashmir, the scenic valley comprising Srinagar and neighboring districts. Most of the victims were militants or supporters of the separatist campaign. Kashmir was divided along a still-disputed frontier between India and Pakistan after British colonial Inida became independent in 1947 and was partitioned along religious lines. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the territory, in 1947-48 and 1965. Relations between the two nations have sunk to their lowest point in years over the Kashmir issue. India accuses Pakistan of funding and training the militants. Pakistan denies the claim and says India is crushing a movement for self-determination. About 64 percent of the 6 million people in India-governed Jammu-Kashmir are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arrested in `One-In-a-Million' Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A doctor was killed in his apartment kitchen by a stray ``one-in-a-million'' bullet when two young men sprayed semiautomatic rifle fire at random, police said Saturday. Andre Crump, 20, surrendered to police Friday, and Anton Abdalla, 20, was arrested later that night, said police Sgt. Mary Wrensen. Both face murder charges in the Friday morning slaying of Dr. Jolaolu Mojola, 60, in Manhattan's Harlem section. The two men fired about 15 shots in a pair of bursts using a semiautomatic .22-caliber rifle, police said. One bullet flew through Mojola's third-floor window and hit the doctor as he walked out of his bathroom. ``Something hit me in the chest!'' the victim reportedly called out to his wife before collapsing. Emergency medical workers pronounced him dead at the scene. ``It was a proverbial one-in-a-million shot,'' said police Capt. Daniel McKenna. ``Six inches in another direction, and it would have hit a brick wall and not him.'' Other residents of the building narrowly escaped injury. A woman lying on a couch in her fifth-floor apartment watched two bullets slam into her ceiling, while another bullet went into a first-floor room. Mojola was born in Lagos, Nigeria, and went to medical school in London. He came to the United States in 1961. The gynecologist worked for 10 years at hospitals before going into teaching, consulting and writing.

DOC.HEAD: State Lifts Accused Nurse's License
DOC.TEXT: The state suspended the license of a practical nurse accused of slashing the intravenous tubes of seven hospital patients, officials said. Friday's action against Kenneth A. Closs, 38, of North Lauderdale was the first emergency suspension of a Florida nurse since 1985, said Larry Gonzalez, secretary of the state Department of Professional Regulation. Closs, arrested Thursday on eight counts of violating the state's anti-tampering law, remained in custody Saturday at the Broward County Jail on $52,500 bond. One count was dismissed Friday after Magistrate Barry S. Seltzer ruled the charge defective. Deputies say Closs admitted cutting the tubes over the Memorial Day weekend, saying he wanted to embarrass University Hospital in the Fort Lauderdale suburb of Tamarac for disciplining him. No one was injured. Detectives have expanded their investigation into allegations that Closs kept drugs intended for his patients. Hospital spokeswoman Lynn Farber said two patients complained last month of not receiving medication. In one case the medication was Demerol, an addictive painkiller. ``The meds were signed out to Closs,'' she said. The first slashing May 26 came five days after Closs' supervisor reprimanded him, took away his key to a narcotics cabinet, barred him from dispensing medications and offered him a chance to seek professional help, Farber said. Closs refused the offer, she said. Deputies said eight tubes to seven fourth-floor patients were cut. Closs worked the overnight shift on the fourth floor, and most of the tubes were slashed on his shift.

DOC.HEAD: Two Journalists Gunned Down In Prime Minister's Hometown
DOC.TEXT: Two journalists were killed Saturday, just minutes after completing reports about the ethnic violence that has turned Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province into a battleground, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the slayings of Ahmed Khan Kamal, a correspondent for Pakistan Press International, a small, privately-owned news agency, and Muthair Naqpit, with Nawa-e-Waqt, a leading Urdu-language daily. The slayings occurred outside the telegraph in Larkana, Ms. Bhutto's home town, 200 miles north of Karachi. Karachi, however, showed signs of returning to normalcy. Shops and offices opened and traffic clogged the streets during a curfew break free of the random shootings that have brought the city of 8 million to a virtual standstill. For nearly three weeks ethnic violence has plagued southern Sindh Province, where more than 350 people have died and thousands have been wounded. The trouble is rooted in deep hatred between native Sindhis and the Mohajirs, descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. Sindhis accuse the better-educated Mohajirs of taking the best jobs and most valuable land. Police blame the violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, which is demanding that the Mohajirs be recognized as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindhis. The violence forced has authorities to impose tough security measures, including indefinite curfews and checkpoints manned by heavily-armed soldiers. Ms. Bhutto has called out the army to help local security forces restore law and order to the province, and on Saturday, troops started to crackdown on violence. The army announced that loudspeakers at mosques, a main source of inciting violence, could only be used to call worshipers to prayer. It also issued shoot-to-kill orders for anyone caught looting or setting fire to property. On Friday, officials said soldiers in Sindh arrested more than 1,000 people suspected of ordering the violence, which began May 15. Most of the violence has been in Karachi and in Hyderabad, a city of 3 million 150 miles to the north. Kamal and Naqpit, however, were gunned down outside the local telegraph office in Larkana after sending stories to their papers about a news conference with Sindhi nationalists. Gunmen surrounded the reporters, opened fire then fled, police said. A correspondent for Pakistan's largest Urdu daily, Jang, was shot and killed earlier in the week at the press club in Khaipur, 170 miles northwest of Karachi. Police said the motive was not clear. Ms. Bhutto has acknowledged the Sindh government led by her Pakistan People's Party has not done enough to stem the rising violence. But she blames neighboring India for stirring much of the trouble. New Delhi has denied the allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Promise To Free Cuban Doctor And Nurse
DOC.TEXT: Ethipian rebels said Saturday they will release a Cuban physician and nurse to U.S. diplomats five months after the two were captured in the fall of a town near the Sudanese border. The U.S. Embassy will take custody of the two on Thursday and fly them to London, said T. Ebba, spokesman for the rebel Oromo Liberation Front. The Cuban government will take charge there, he said. In Cairo, Egypt, Counselor Abdul-Rahman Hamza of the Sudanese Embassy, who first announced the planned release, said he was not told how the United States came to be involved in the case. The U.S. Embassy in Khartoum was closed for the weekend and officials could not be reached for comment. Cuba, a supporter of Ethiopia's Marxist government and an opponent of the United States, has diplomatic relations with Sudan but no embassy in Khartoum. In Cairo, Cuban Ambassador Jorge Cubiles Hernandes said he knew nothing of the plan. The captive Cubans, Dr. Pedro Ulaka, 35, and Jolanda Hernandez, 23, both of Havana, disappeared in the first week of January with four other Cuban medical personnel. All six were working at Asosa, in far western Ethiopia just east of the Sudanese border, when the area came under attack from anti-government forces. The Oromo Liberation Front, a tribal resistance group active since the early 1970s, claimed the Asosa victory. Two of the Cubans were released in April in San`a, Yemen. Hamza said two will remain captives after Thursday's release but that the Sudanese government was still trying to gain their release. They ``are in good health,'' he said. Hamza said the U.S. Embassy in Khartoum already has acted as go-between once this year, previously in the release of Poles held by Ethiopian rebels. U.S. diplomats teamed with Polish government representatives in January to free 30 Poles held for 20 days by rebels from Eritrea in northeastern Ethiopia. They were seized from a ship that came under fire because rebels suspected it was running guns to the Addis Ababa government.

DOC.HEAD: `Dead Poets Society' Takes Top Foreign Award
DOC.TEXT: Peter Weir's ``Dead Poets Society'' was named best foreign film Saturday at the David of Donatello awards, Italy's version of Hollywood's Academy Awards. The Italian film ``Porte Aperte'' (Open Doors), directed by Gianni Amelio, won the prize for best film. Mario Monicelli was named best director for ``Il Male Oscuro'' (The Obscure Illness). Awards for best actor and actress in a foreign film went to Jessica Tandy for ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and Philipe Noiret for ``Life and Nothing Else.'' Other foreign winners included Louis Malle, for directing ``Milou en may'' (Milou in May), and Woody Allen, for the screenplay of ``Crimes and Misdemeanors.'' The awards were presented in a ceremony at Rome's Teatro delle Vittorie.

DOC.HEAD: Quality Problems at Veterans Hospitals Cited by Study
DOC.TEXT: Quality standards at VA medical centers generally lagged behind those of other hospitals in a survey made by a national accrediting group, officials confirmed Saturday. Veterans Affairs Department officials said Saturday they were concerned about the results of the survey by the group that accredits most of the nation's hospitals and will move quickly to make changes where problems can be remedied. The Joint Commission on Accreditation of Health Care Organizations, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., studied 116 of the 172 VA centers that provide medical care to 3.5 million veterans annually. It found the centers at least 20 percent more likely than other hospitals to fall below quality standards in the areas of emergency services, special care services, surgery and anesthesia services, surgical case review, alcohol and drug treatment planning and fire safety. It did not name any centers. The Los Angeles Times, in editions last week, quoted William Jessee, the commission's vice president for accreditation surveys, as saying the VA had ``a seriously aging infrastructure in its health care facilities.'' Jessee said the VA had not been ``adequately funded to bring these physical plants up to current life-safety standards.'' VA spokesman Don Smith acknowledged that a number of problems were found at centers on the West Coast, particularly in the area of record-keeping. ``We recognize a necessity'' to keep better records, Smith said in an interview Saturday. ``We haven't been doing it in some instances and we need to do that.'' Smith said, however, that record-keeping problems were not the same as deficiencies in providing care. He added that he did not ``think that the recitation of the commission's findings will shake the system to its roots.'' ``I don't want to excuse them, though, and I don't think the system wants to excuse them,'' he added. Don Avant, a special assistant to the commission president, said in a telephone interview there were many ``good people'' in the veterans health care system, but he added that the department was ``bureaucratic.'' The department asked the commission to make the study in response to a request from Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. On a system with a maximum score of 100 the average for the veterans centers was 69.8 while that of the average of 5,182 other hospitals was 77. Hospitals are surveyed every three years for accreditation purposes. Under the system, a score of 90 merits a ``commendation'' rating, while anything lower than 50 puts a hospital on a probationary status. Six percent of veterans hospitals received 87.5 points or more in the study, compared with about 25 percent of other hospitals. But 16 percent of the veterans institutions scored 57.5 or fewer points, compared with 4 percent among other hospitals. Smith said six veterans medical centers are on ``conditional accreditation'' status: Long Beach, Sepulveda and Palo Alto in California; Portland and Roseburg in Oregon; and Walla Walla in Washington. He said all veterans hospitals are accredited.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack West of Salvadoran Capital in Escalation
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels attacked army positions Saturday just west of San Salvador, residents said, in the second day of intensified fighting in the 10-year-old civil war. Guerrilla commander Jorge Melendez, speaking on clandestine rebel Radio Venceremos, said the insurgents are trying to pressure the government into negotiating an end to the war. The fighting took place in Ciudad Merliot, seven miles west of San Salvador, the capital. The residents, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they knew of no casualties. The armed forces said 15 guerrillas were killed and 25 wounded in fighting with army troops Friday along the Pan-American highway 45 miles east of San Salvador in San Vicente province. A rebel camp was destroyed, the armed forces press office said. It did not say if any government troops were killed or wounded. Also Friday, urban guerrilla commandos blew up more than 20 utility poles and high-tension wire towers, leaving a third of the country without power on the first anniversary of President Alfredo Cristiani's presidency. Cristiani, of the rightist Republican Nationalist Alliance, pledged when he took office to work for peace. Representatives of the U.S.-backed government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the guerrillas' organization, agreed in May on an agenda for talks to achieve peace in about a year. More than 71,000 Salvadorans, mostly civilians, have been killed during the war in this Central American country of about 5.5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Two Wounded in Bombing at Army Base
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at an army training base near this southern town Saturday, wounding two officers, police reported. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the bomb was planted at the entrance to the complex on a hill 10 miles west of Nabatiyeh. He said the wounded were a captain and a lieutenant, but declined to give their names. Army headquarters in Beirut declined to comment. Police said the explosion caused some damage but gave no details. The one-story building on a hill overlooking the Mediterranean was a military radar base before the civil war broke out in 1975. The radar equipment was removed several years ago and the facility has been used as a training base, mainly for Shiite Moslem soldiers serving in south Lebanon. Most of the troops in the south sympathize with the Syrian-backed Shiite Amal militia, which has been fighting with the fundamentalist, Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, since mid-1987. More than 1,000 people have been killed and 3,000 wounded in that power struggle for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect.

DOC.HEAD: Blue Cross Won't Donate Retirement Party Money to Charity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0578 to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: What seemed like a good idea to Genevieve McLaughlin _ donating the $1,200 her retirement party would cost to charity _ failed to go over with a committee appointed by her employer, Independence Blue Cross. Spokesman Dick Mendenhall announced the panel's decision Friday, saying the non-profit health insurance company would not donate the money but will continue to pick up the tab for retirement lunches at a fancy hotel for employees of a decade or more. The $1,200 lunches are complete with flowers, photographs and a $100 gift certificate. The guest of honor can invite up to 35 co-workers, and a handful of managers attend. Ms. McLaughlin thought a better use for the money would be donations to her favorite charities: St. John's Hospice and her grandson's Little League team. Mendenhall explained why the committee, which was appointed to study the issue, disagreed. ``The point of this sort of luncheon is to honor the person through a gathering of associates and friends, for reminiscence, camaraderie and so on,'' said Mendenhall. ``These luncheons are entirely voluntary. ... If the person doesn't want a luncheon, then we don't have one.'' Mendenhall said donating the money would defeat the purpose: ``The intent of the recognition is to encourage interaction with other employees.'' Ms. McLaughlin, 64, believes she won despite the decision. ``I brought this to a head, and I know that between the news reports, other companies are going to read about it and maybe somebody out there is going to have a heart and say, `We're going to let the employees have what they want,''' she said. ``Maybe somebody will even want to sponsor a Little League team.'' Blue Cross told Ms. McLaughlin she could still have a going-away luncheon, but she's still not interested. The former Medicare claims adjuster made a few waves with her request. After her story was reported in the Philadelphia Daily News, a reader wrote the paper suggesting that she think about running for local office. Another letter writer, a 15-year Blue Cross employee, worried that the company might decide to drop the lunches altogether. ``I want mine,'' she wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Jumpy Apartment-Dweller Lands on Police Officer
DOC.TEXT: The sound of a battering ram used in a drug raid at a neighbor's apartment spooked a man who hopped out his window into the waiting arms of a police officer in the right place at the right time. Poor balance combined with bad timing to aid in the arrest when the man tossed a small bag of cocaine to the ground while fleeing, then ``looked back to see where it was ... and he tripped,'' police Cmdr. Rudy Legenza said Saturday. Legenza arrested the man Friday for investigation of cocaine possession and resisting arrest. Thought to be an undocumented alien, the man was being held by immigration authorities. His name was withheld. ``We were going for apartment 5, but apparently the man in apartment 4 thought his apartment was being raided,'' Legenza said. ``He jumped out through a window and landed on me.'' The arrest of the man dashing from his first-floor apartment was ``an easy catch _ so to speak,'' he said. Three people from the other apartment were arrested for investigation of various drug charges, police said. Police knew of no links between the neighbors.
