DOC.HEAD: Injection of Healthy Muscle Cells Into Dystrophy Victims Called Promising
DOC.TEXT: A new procedure using healthy muscle cells may help correct the protein defect that causes the most common childhood form of muscular dystrophy, a researcher said Saturday. In a preliminary study, the genetic therapy called myoblast transfer produced a protein whose absence due to a gene defect causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy, said Dr. Peter K. Law of the University of Tennessee-Memphis at the Muscular Dystrophy Association's meeting here. The degenerative neuromuscular disease strikes young boys almost exclusively. ``Until now, we have been dealing with children that are dying _ a disease that so far has had no hope, no treatment and no cure,'' Law said. ``For that reason, I feel that the development of this work is very important.'' The procedure involves injecting healthy muscle cells of an adult, often a sibling or parent, into the youth with Duchenne dystrophy, researchers said. Law said the therapy as the first effective treatment for Duchenne, but not as a total cure, because it is still unknown how much function children will develop with it or how much longer they will live. Duchenne victims usually die in their teens or young adult years. Law's study found that a big-toe muscle injected with healthy, immature muscle cells produced dystrophin, the protein missing from those with the disease. ``Our intention is to furnish the muscle with the missing formula, the missing recipe, the blueprint,'' said Dr. Leon I. Charash, a neurological specialist in New York who is the chairman of the MDA's Medical Advisory Committee. ``The concept is giving the cells what they missed.'' The researchers noted that the studies were still very preliminary, but said research on the therapy in Canada has produced similar results. ``These are the first known clinical tests in the world of this therapy, so the results will require extremely cautious and lengthy analysis,'' Law said. ``But if all goes as planned, if our work remains on schedule, we hope to bring this forth as a widespread treatment by 1992.'' Law said no adverse effects from the procedure or the anti-rejection treatment were reported. Charash said the therapy, if successful, eventually could be applied to other dystrophies. He also noted, however, that the therapy has been done on the smallest of levels and will next be tried on larger muscles, as the Canadian researchers have begun. ``Myoblast transfer holds great promise as a potential therapy for muscular dystrophy and other devestating hereditary muscle diseases,'' Charash said. ``Many more questions must be answered and much remains to be done before the procedure can become a treatment, but Dr. Law's finding is an exciting first sign of success.'' Law's research, along with others, is funded by the MDA, which oversees research, treatment and care for people with 40 neuromuscular diseases. The organization, based in New York, is moving its national headquarters to Tucson.

DOC.HEAD: Abbas Says Arafat Did Not Know of Failed Attack Beforehand
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian leader who claimed responsibility for last week's failed raid against Israel said PLO chief Yasser Arafat had no advance knowledge of the attack, a newspaper reported Saturday. Mohammed Abbas, leader of the Palestine Liberation Front, also pledged to carry out more raids against the Jewish state. ``We vow to continue the struggle until the objective of our people in independence and liberation is achieved,'' Abbas said. He was speaking in an interview with Kuwait's al-Watan newspaper. The daily did not say where he was interviewed. ``We mean what we say. This operation is the beginning of a ... combat effort against the Israeli enemy,'' he said. Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, was the mastermind of the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro in the Mediterranean. An American passenger in a wheelchair was killed in that raid. The Palestine Liberation Front led by Abbas is a faction within the PLO, but is not considered to be directly controlled by Arafat. Abbas was quoted as saying that Arafat had no knowledge of Wednesday's foiled attack on Israel. ``It's true the PLO has nothing to do with the operation,'' Abbas said. `We are under no obligation to inform Abu Ammar beforehand about any operation.'' Abu Ammar is Arafat's nom de guerre. Arafat has disassociated the Palestine Liberation Organization from the operation, but has stopped short of condemning the failed raid. Arafat has also rejected Washington's demand that he expel Abbas from the PLO's ruling executive committee. In December, Washington began talks with the PLO after Arafat renounced terrorism. Arafat said the expulsion of Abbas could only be done by the Palestine National Council, the PLO's parliament-in-exile. Abbas also said the seaborne raid was not planned with Libyan or Iraqi help. Israel has charged that Libya assisted in the planning of the raid. Abbas said the foiled attack, in which four gunmen were killed and 12 captured before they reached a beach crowded with Israeli bathers, cost $3 million and had been planned for two years. He said the raid was launched as a message to the superpower summit in Washington and to avenge the slaying of seven unarmed Palestinian workers by an Israeli gunman near Tel Aviv on May 20. He said the raid carried two messages to the United States and the Soviet Union, ``that the Palestinian people are determined to continue their struggle until the liberation of Palestine and the achievement of independence, and that ... they should be fully aware that the influx of Jews into Palestine is a crime against Palestinian human rights.'' Hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews are expected to immigrate to Israel in the coming years.

DOC.HEAD: Rex Harrison: The Last of a Breed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 13th pvs, `Claudette Colbert...' to ADD Lynn Redgrave comment; pickup 14th pvs, `Edward Fox...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Obit-Harrison, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fellow actors lamented the death of Rex Harrison on Saturday, saying the gentle actor-knight will be remembered as much for his civility and urbanity as for his versatility and skill as an actor. Actor Edward Fox said Harrison's talent was like the sun: ``It's difficult to give a name to, (but) you know when it's out.'' Harrison died in New York early Saturday of pancreatic cancer at age 82. ``He was the master of a certain kind of acting in which he really was incomparable,'' said Dame Wendy Hiller, 77. ``There isn't anybody to put alongside him ... (his) subtlety and skill and technical expertise,'' she said. She first starred with him in the 1941 film ``Major Barbara,'' based on the George Bernard Shaw play. They most recently appeared together in a British television adaptation of ``The Kingfisher,'' a play in which Harrison performed on Broadway in 1978. Over the years, Dame Wendy said she called Harrison ``Liverpool virus'' and ``prop-ridden Harrison'' _ joking references to his background and his fastidiousness with props during filming. ``We sort of agreed to disagree,'' Dame Wendy said, recalling their ``good-natured sparring matches.'' In New York, Julie Andrews, who performed with Harrison in ``My Fair Lady'' for three years, said: ``To watch him and to work with him was a joyful experience. I doubt there was anyone before like him. ... The theater has lost an extraordinary one of a kind.'' Audrey Hepburn, who played Eliza Doolittle opposite Harrison's Professor Henry Higgins in the movie version of ``My Fair Lady,'' remembered him as ``a superb actor, the quintessential actor.'' ``He was always thoughtful and helpful and fun, and I really adored every minute I worked with him,'' she said from Switzerland. Claudette Colbert, who starred with Harrison in ``Aren't We All?'' on Broadway, said in New York: ``I am terribly sorry. I think it was a great loss to the theater. ... He was a great, great comedian.'' Actress Lynn Redgrave, who also starred in ``Aren't We All?'' in 1985, called Harrison ``the master of high comedy playing.'' ``Nobody knows how to do what he did. He gave high comedy a danger, accuracy and razor sharpness, and at the same time it appeared to be completely effortless. You could never see the joke coming,'' she said from San Diego. Edward Fox, who co-starred with Harrison in his final London stage appearance, a 1988 revival of ``The Admirable Crichton,'' said he ``was that very rare thing _ a great actor.'' ``I remember him with great affection and with great admiration,'' said Fox, who called Harrison's London performance as Chekhov's Platonov in 1960 ``one of the great evenings in the theater.'' Michael Winner, the film director and a longtime acquaintance, called Harrison ``the last of the old-style sophisticates. He had this great, great star quality of charm.'' ``When an actor like Sir Rex dies, then you realize it's the passing of a style that won't come again,'' said Rosemary Harris, who starred with Harrison in London and on Broadway in 1983-84 in Shaw's ``Heartbreak House.'' The play afforded Harrison one of his finest roles _ as the bearded, ever philosophical Captain Shotover, presiding over the teetering ``ship of state'' that is Britain. ``He was sublime,'' Harris said of Harrison's performance in the play. She said she last saw Harrison six weeks ago in New York when she presented him with a special Drama League award for outstanding achievement in the theater. Preparing for the presentation, Harris said she was struck by the unexpected breadth of Harrison's career. ``I realized what a thoroughly cosmopolitan man he is,'' she said. ``How many actors have gone from playing Siamese kings to British royalty? That's quite a span, isn't it?'' Harris herself returns to the London stage in October to star in W. Somerset Maugham's ``The Circle,'' in which Harrison played on Broadway last season.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Allows Top Defector to See Family
DOC.TEXT: The Communist government for the first time has allowed the family of a high-level defector to go abroad to visit him and it is considering letting him return from China, an official said Saturday. The government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the move was meant as a gesture of good will toward China before the visit of Deputy Foreign Minister Dinh Nho Liem to Beijing. It will be Liem's third round of talks in China on the Cambodian civil war and other barriers to normalizing ties between Vietnam and China. The Vietnamese government allowed the wife and daughter of 87-year-old defector Hoang Van Hoan _ a founding member of the Vietnamese Communist Party _ to travel to Beijing to visit him last month, the government official said. The decision was made by the Politburo, the highest body of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party, he said. The official also said the Chinese government last month asked Vietnam to let Hoan return home. No decision has been made, the official said. But he added, ``People tend to think it's about time to take him back; even some high-ranking officials think so.'' Hoan, a member of the Politburo from 1957 to 1976, was the first top Vietnamese leader to defect to China. Hoan disappeared at Karachi airport in Pakistan in July 1979. A month later he surfaced in Beijing, he attacked the Vietnamese party leadership, saying it was guilty of using ``Stalinist'' methods and abandoning friendship with China for the Soviet Union. Hoan called for a revolution in Vietnam. The Vietnamese official who spoke Saturday said Hoan had also published a Vietnamese-language newsletter critical of Hanoi while he was in China. Vietnam and China were allies during the Vietnam War, but they had a falling-out in 1978 over border disputes, Vietnam's treatment of its ethnic Chinese population and growing Vietnamese-Soviet ties. China launched a brief border attack in early 1979, saying it wanted to ``punish'' Vietnam for invading Cambodia and toppling the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge government. China continues to arm the Khmer Rouge and two other guerrilla groups now fighting the Vietnamese-installed government in Cambodia. However, relations with China have improved during Liem's three visits to Beijing over the past 15 months. An assistant Chinese foreign minister, Xu Dunxin, is to arrive in Hanoi on June 9 to continue the talks on Cambodia and normalizing relations. Xu will be leading the first senior Chinese delegation to Vietnam since 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Smaller, More Powerful are Watchwords for New Audio and Video Products
LaserPhoto CX6
DOC.TEXT: Smaller, clearer and more powerful are the watchwords for this year's innovations at the Consumer Electronics Show, where tens of thousands of audio, video and home-automation products went on display Saturday. Digital audio tape, the long-awaited technology that will give taped sound a quantum leap in quality, finally hits the American marketplace this fall, when Secaucus, N.J.-based Technics said it will begin shipping its first player to U.S. retailers. ``We are actively taking orders at the show and are sure that it will be off the ground this time,'' said Michael Aguilar, a spokesman for the company, a division of the Matsushita Electric Corp. of America. The SVDA10 player marketed by Technics, suggested to retail at $1,200, will incorporate a ``copy management system'' conforming with the new technology standard adopted in Japan to foil pirating attempts and head off copryright disputes, Aguilar said. A fear of such disputes is what has kept manufacturers from marketing DAT technology in the United States, even though it has been available for at least three years. Technics has also teamed with movie director George Lucas to produce Home THX, an advanced sound system designed, by one account, ``to have spaceships whizzing by your ears while you sit watching `Star Wars' in your easy chair.'' The price of such pleasure is expected to be $8,000 to $10,000 when the system, marketed by Lucasfilm Ltd., makes its debut this fall. More relevant, perhaps to the average filmmaker, is the ultra-compact camcorder, with Sony offering what it bills as the world's smallest in its Handycam CCD-TR4, a 4]-by-4[-by-6|-inch unit that weighs 1{ pounds. The device, with a suggested retail price of $1,100, uses 8-millimeter tape in a cassette about the size of a standard audio cassette and is aimed at the most active on-the-go user, said company spokesman Yuki Nozoe. Close on Sony's heels in camcorder ultracompactness is Panasonic with its Palmcorder PV-10, which uses compact VHS tapes and has a suggested retail price of $999. Also reaching new frontiers in getting a lot of information into a very small space is Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc., which is introducing the world's first hand-held electronic encyclopedia. The 5{-by-5-by-1-inch unit weighing 12 ounces affords a user access to any entry in the Concise Columbia Encyclopedia by punching words into a small keyboard, according to its Mount Holly, N.J.-based manufacturer. The unit has a suggested retail price of $299. The electronics show, which runs through Tuesday and is closed to the public, is sponsored by the Washington, D.C.-based Consumer Electronics Group of the Electronic Industries Association. An estimated 55,000 visitors, mostly retailers or their representatives, are expected to attend the event, a semi-annual gathering whose twin is held each January in Las Vegas. Consumer electronics manufacturers expect to ring up $33.97 billion in factory sales this year, compared with $32.26 billion last year, Industry Vice President Frank Myers said in a speech at the show's opening.

DOC.HEAD: Late Spring Storm Sends Heavy Winds, Rains Over Central U.S.
DOC.TEXT: An unseasonably strong storm raced across the central United States Saturday, dumping heavy rains and spinning off high winds over Iowa and Minnesota. Thunderstorms boomed from Minnesota through the Mississippi Valley into northeast Texas. Minnesota and Iowa had the worst storms. Gusts of up to 80 mph were clocked at Estherville in northwest Iowa, and 67 mph in Des Moines in the central part of the state. High winds downed trees and power lines in Marshalltown, about 50 mph northeast of Des Moines. In Minnesota, Minnetonka got nearly an inch of rain in just 15 minutes and Saint Cloud got 1.5 inches in the six-hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT. Gusts up to 60 mph were reported in central Kansas. High winds around Hutchinson, 40 miles northwest of Wichita, overturned trucks, blew off roofs and felled trees and power lines. Nearly 24,000 people in Hutchinson and surrounding Reno County were without power during the four-hour storm, but electricity was restored by late afternoon. A tornado watch was in effect until evening in parts of east-central and southeast Minnesota, most of Wisconsin, northeast Illinois, and central and eastern Iowa. Thunderstorms also extended from western into northeast Texas. Tornado watches were issued for most of Arkansas, northeast Texas, and northwest Louisiana. Scattered rain fell from North Dakota to eastern Nebraska, and over the upper Ohio Valley. Showers were more widely scattered from South Carolina to southern Florida. Sunny skies prevailed across the southwest corner of the nation. High-wind warnings were in effect for the southeastern mountains of Wyoming, where winds reached 75 mph near Granite Reservoir west of Cheyenne. The temperature dipped to 35 degrees in Grand Junction, Colo., breaking the record low for the date of 38 set in 1954. The low for the Lower 48 states was 19 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: LaRouche Launches Jail-House Campaign For Congress
With AM-LaRouche Followers-Trial
DOC.TEXT: Political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. may be languishing in a Minnesota prison cell, but campaign contributions for his Virginia congressional drive rolled in anyway. LaRouche, who is serving a 15-prison sentence for tax evasion, mail fraud and conspiracy in a $25 million fund-raising scheme, raised more than $200,000, records show. The ultraconservative activist is running as an independent against Republican Rep. Frank R. Wolf for the 10th district seat. According to records filed with the Federal Election Commission, the ``LaRouche for Justice'' campaign raised $221,318 between July 1, 1989, and March 31, 1990. LaRouche's records show that as of March 31 he had spent all but about $8,000. LaRouche and several associates were convicted last year of defrauding dozens of people who responded to fund-raising appeals for his political network. Prosecutors argued that LaRouche and his followers persuaded many people to make ``loans'' to LaRouche organizations with no intention of paying back the money. Many of those who lost money to LaRouche were retirees, and some are now seeking to recover part of their losses in court. FEC records show that a sizable number of the donors to LaRouche's congressional campaign are retirees. LaRouche is a former resident of Loudoun County, which along with Arlington County, northern Fairfax County, Falls Church and Fairfax City comprises Virginia's 10th District. Under federal law, LaRouche cannot vote because he is a convicted felon. But the law allows him to run for office and does not require that he live in the district he hopes to represent. LaRouche is at a federal prison in Rochester, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Arrested on Drunken Driving Charge En Route to Flight, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines pilot was suspended from flying after his arrest on a drunken-driving charge as he drove to work, according to a published report Saturday. ``He was on his way, yes, to fly a regular passenger flight,'' Northwest spokesman Doug Miller told the Saint Paul Pioneer Press. Hans Falkenberg, 39, of Prescott, Wis., was arrested on Memorial Day, and has been suspended from flying, the newspaper reported. Shortly after his arrest, Falkenberg ``asked to make a phone call so he could call his employer and cancel a flight,'' said Minnesota Patrol Capt. Dean Swanson. On March 8, a Northwest cockpit crew was arrested after flying a commercial jet from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis. The three crew members face federal charges of flying while under the influence of alcohol; all have pleaded innocent. The Federal Aviation Administration revoked their pilot licenses and the airline fired them. Falkenberg was stopped by a state trooper for driving an average of 73 mph in a 55-mph zone on a state highway in Cottage Grove on Monday afternoon, Swanson said. According to his arrest report, the trooper smelled alcohol on Falkenberg, then asked him to perform a series of coordination tests. ``That led to his arrest,'' Swanson said. After refusing to submit to a blood-alcohol or urine test, Falkenberg was booked into a county jail. He was given a misdemeanor citation for driving under the influence of alcohol and released that evening, the newspaper reported. He is scheduled to appear in court June 21. Northwest officials would not discuss any other details of the incident pending the outcome of their own investigation. The airline did not release the pilot's name, would not say whether he is a captain or co-pilot and would not comment on whether the flight was delayed or where it was bound. Falkenberg could not be reached for comment at home Saturday. His wife said he would have no comment, and refused to say whether he had an attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Abandoning Policy Of Silence, France Announces A Nuclear Test
DOC.TEXT: France announced that it detonated a nuclear device Saturday at its testing site in the South Pacific, the first time in 15 years it had made such a public declaration. Since 1975, France had maintained a policy of official silence on its tests at the atoll of Mururoa. Customarily, the world first learned of the tests from New Zealand, which has monitored France's nuclear program from an observation station in the Cook Islands. The new policy of public disclosure was announced by President Francois Mitterrand during a visit to French Polynesia in May. It was the latest of several steps taken by the government to defuse criticism of its testing program. Another initiative has involved inviting foreign researchers to visit Mururoa to test France's claims that there has been no severe environmental damage. France's high commissioner in French Polynesia, Jean Montpezat, said the undergound test was carried out Saturday morning with a device unleashing about 15 kilotons of energy, equivalent to the U.S. bomb dropped on Hiroshima. Premier Michel Rocard recently announced France would reduce the number of nuclear tests at Mururoa from eight to six a year.

DOC.HEAD: Retired AP Reporter Richard Smith Dies
DOC.TEXT: Richard H. Smith, an Associated Press newsman for 38 years in Ohio and California, died of respiratory problems. He was 76. Smith died Friday at Peninsula Hospital in the San Francisco Bay city of Burlingame, where he lived. The Pittsburgh native joined the AP in 1940 in Columbus, Ohio, and worked in the Columbus, Cincinnati and Cleveland bureaus. He was in the Army for three years during World War II. He then worked in the Cleveland bureau for 21 years, the last seven as correspondent. He transferred to the San Francisco bureau in 1968, and was there until he retired in 1978. Smith was active in the Wire Service Guild and served on three contract negotiating committees. Survivors include Francis, his wife of 49 years, and a son, Christopher. Services were scheduled for Friday at Burlingame Methodist Church.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Military Adviser Dies in Plane Crash in Congo
DOC.TEXT: A MiG-21 jet fighter of the Congolese air force crashed near the airport of an Atlantic coast city, killing the Soviet military adviser at the controls, a Soviet official said Saturday. Col. Gennady Milachov was flying routine exercises Thursday at about 1,300 feet when he lost control of the jet, the official said on condition of anonymity. The plane crashed in an uninhabited area near Pointe-Noire, the second-largest city in this Central African country. It is about 250 miles west of the capital, Brazzaville. The adviser was the only person aboard. The Soviet official did not say what caused the crash. About 12 Soviet military advisers are stationed in this country.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Monopoly Maker Hopes `Gorby' Visit Will Boost Sales
With AM-Gorbachev-Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: In Russian Monopoly, rubles replace greenbacks and a Moscow shopping mall stands in for the coveted Boardwalk, so the game's maker sees a visit from the ultimate Soviet bigwig as a natural promotional peg. Hoping to distribute the game throughout the Soviet Union, Tonka Corp. decorated 1,000 copies of the Russian games with a special seal to commemorate Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota. The games are being distributed by the Minnetonka-based firm to visiting Soviet dignitaries and members of the Soviet news media in anticipation of Gorbachev's arrival Sunday. Tonka's Parker Brothers subsidiary developed the Russian version of the game and printed 10,000 copies two years ago to help promote the 1988 World Monopoly Tournament in London, said company spokesman B.J. French said. ``Part of what's fun about this is that Monopoly is part of the ultimate capitalist thing,'' French said. ``It's part of Americana.'' The commemorative editions with the seal showing the U.S. and Soviet flags superimposed on the state of Minnesota aren't for sale, but Russian Monopoly is available at specialty game stores in the United States, French said. ``We're proud of the fact that Gorbachev is coming to Minnesota and since we have our roots here too, we want to be part of the celebration,'' French said. ``This game is helping us to do that.'' And that's just the beginning. ``We would like to establish the game in the Soviet market,'' said Patricia McGovern, spokeswoman for Parker Brothers, which is based in Beverly, Mass. ``We need a company in the Soviet world that would be interested in publishing and distributing the game there.'' The Russian version of Monopoly is available in the Soviet Union only in duty-free and hard currency shops where rubles have no buying power, Ms. McGovern said. In addition to the 10,000 Russian games manufactured by Parker, a French company produces the games for sale in Europe. ``Most of the people who buy the Russian Monopoly in Finland are Soviet diplomats,'' she said. ``I have received quite a few letters from people in the Soviet world that have it and absolutely love it.'' The Russian version of Monopoly is Parker Brother's 23rd foreign edition. The games are distributed in more than 30 countries worldwide, Ms. McGovern said. In its Russian form, the Monopoly board was altered to reflect Moscow's cityscape, with Boardwalk becoming Arbat, the mall where President Reagan walked with Gorbachev during the 1989 summit. Rubles replace American dollars and all references to stocks were changed to bonds becauses stocks do not exist in the Soviet Union. The Community Chest card in the American version that refers to a Christmas Club was changed to ``lottery'' in the Russian game because there are no official holidays with religious connotations in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Carne Expected To Enter Plea Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Actress Judy Carne has agreed to plead guilty to contempt of court to settle an 11-year-old case, according to her lawyer. Ms. Carne, known for her role as the ``Sock-it-to-me'' girl in the 1960s television series ``Laugh-In,'' failed to appear in 1979 for retrial on a charge of using a forged prescription to get sleeping pills. She was arrested May 19 in New York on an 11-year-old warrant in the case. Her lawyer, Philip Pitzer, said she has reached a plea agreement with Hamilton County prosecutors. She plans to appear in Common Pleas Court next Tuesday to plead guilty to contempt. ``In exchange ... the prosecution will dismiss that remaining count,'' Pitzer said. ``I think they're going to recommend the maximum fine, which is $500.'' Ms. Carne was arrested in 1977 while appearing at a local dinner theater. She was charged with using a forged prescription to buy sleeping pills and possession of heroin. A jury found her innocent of the heroin charge, but couldn't reach a verdict on the prescription forgery charge. She was scheduled to be tried again before Common Pleas Judge Thomas Crush, the same judge scheduled to hear her case Tuesday. County prosecutors have declined to comment on the case.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Had Cyst Removed But Says He's Recovering Well
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela announced Saturday he had a benign cyst removed from his bladder but expected to leave this week on a 13-nation tour to fight apartheid. His news conference came after five days of speculation on his true condition. Officials at the Park Lane Clinic in Johannesburg had said he underwent a minor operation there on Monday, but they refused to provide any details. ``He is a very fit young man for his age,'' said the 71-year-old black leader's doctor, Gus Gecelter, on Saturday. The African National Congress leader was admitted to the clinic May 27 for what ANC officials described as a routine physical examination. Aside from the announcement he had undergone a minor operation Monday, no other details were provided until Saturday by doctors, his family, or ANC representatives. Mandela, though looking at bit tired at the news conference that day, ``I feel on top of the world, and I'm looking forward to the trip with eagerness.'' Gecelter, Mandela's doctor since 1985, confirmed at the news conference the cyst on Mandela's bladder was benign. He said Mandela ``had no problems before or after the operation.'' Mandela said he was eager to begin his six-week, 13-nation tour to tell the world no significant changes have been made in South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation. President F.W. de Klerk, who freed Mandela from prison in February and launched other reforms, has been arguing that other nations should lift sanctions on South Africa because of the changes it is making. Mandela had been imprisoned since 1962 on a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. His ANC is the leading group fighting apartheid. ANC President Oliver Tambo suffered a stroke late last year. Though Mandela is deputy president of the ANC, many people have viewed him in recent months as the group's de facto leader. Mandela was expected to leave the clinic this weekend and spend at least one night at his home in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg before he begins his tour Monday with a stop in Botswana. He will then visit the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland, Italy, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique. At his news conference, Mandela described the government's proposal last week to scrap the Separate Amenities Act, which racially segregates public facilities, as ``quite insignificant.'' ``It is not the real issue over which we are fighting. The basic issue in this country is whether blacks are going to have the right of self-determination,'' he said. De Klerk has initiated talks with the ANC and other black groups to give the black majority a political role. However, he has not said he would accept majority rule.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
German Anxiety Over Reunified Germany Grounded in Memories of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 10th graf, bgng, White House xxx etc. to UPDATE with comment Saturday by President Bush's chief spokesman.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's fear of a reunified Germany is grounded in a bitter national memory of millions lost in war and a sober recognition that a historical enemy's rise might parallel its own decline. The roster of Russian dead in World War II _ 7.5 million by unofficial estimates _ dwarfs the losses of other nations and is roughly 18 times higher that of America, which was spared combat on its home soil. Millions of Soviet civilians also perished as German forces penetrated deeply into Russian territory. Yevgeny Primakov, a top adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Saturday that the lingering fear of Germany _ not the Soviet economy _ was paramount in the minds of Soviets. ``Whenever our children play war,'' he said, ``the two opposing sides to this day are the Soviets and the Nazis _ the Germans.'' Despite all the years of tension between the United States and the Soviet Union, Soviet children playing such games have never posed as Americans, he said. ``You can judge from that how deep are the fears of Germany's military might. ... Our people have survived two wars started by the Germans in this century.'' Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, with Gorbachev at his side, told reporters in Ottawa last week: ``All of the nations suffered greatly in the Second World War, but none _ none suffered more dramatically than the Soviet Union.'' Said former NATO Ambassador Robert F. Ellsworth: ``Today, the Germany question is completely different from what it has been before, because it is the Russians that are weak and uncertain.'' So the German issue, unsurprisingly, hovered over Gorbachev's talks with Mulroney, and loomed menacingly as a possible albatross around the necks of Gorbachev and President Bush, his summit host. Indeed, the summit's risk of failure may have been averted by their acknowledgements at the outset that the German question couldn't be resolved in four days of talks here. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, briefing reporters on the pair's talks Saturday at Camp David, Md., said that both Bush and Gorbachev felt their Germany discussions ``were quite productive'' in the sense that the superpower leaders ``did reach a better understanding of their positions.'' Germany was divided into Eastern and Western zones after World War II, but the Western powers remained committed to its eventual reunification despite the puppet East German government set up by the Soviet Union. Germany's omnipresence as an issue at East-West summits is richly documented. When President Harry Truman and Soviet Premier Josef Stalin met with British leaders in Potsdam in 1945, it was, in part, to carve up the Germany that the Allies had just conquered. By 1959, when Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev met with President Dwight D. Eisenhower, trouble was brewing over the Potsdam agreement. Khrushchev was proposing to terminate allied rights in West Berlin, posing the threat of a major East-West confrontation. But in subsequent superpower talks, the German issue receded into the background as arms control questions came to fore. That is, until last year's toppling of the communist government of East Germany in the wave of democratic reform that swept through central and eastern Europe. West German armed forces number about 494,000. East German forces totaled about 173,000 last year, although they may have been cut some since, and it is unclear how many of them might be absorbed into the unified German military force. Against this background, and with the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact disintegrating, Bush made it clear last week that he favors a united Germany as a full member of the U.S.-led NATO alliance. The Soviets balked, and Gorbachev exhorted the West to find ``a new melody.'' Georgi Arbatov, director of the Soviet Institute for U.S. and Canada Studies, said that ``a military alliance against the Soviet Union, that's the way we see NATO.'' In his meeting with Bush, Gorbachev proposed that the military role of a united Germany be decided by a new ``council of all Europe'' in which both the United States and the Soviet Union would participate. Diplomatic aides are to pursue the idea in Copenhagen, Denmark, this week and in Berlin two weeks later. Ellsworth, the former NATO ambassador who now is vice chairman of the private American Council on Germany, predicted the issue could still remain a thorny one for the United States and the Soviets. ``Russians are saying, `We have the memory of these fears left over from World War II.' '' said Ellsworth. ``It's totally understandable, but I just don't think that we in the West can conduct our politics on the basis of providing psychiatric therapy for the Russians' neurotic memories of World War II, valid as they are.'' ``When the Germans get unified, they are going to have to make these decisions as a sovereign people or otherwise it won't work,'' he said. ``They will have to be part of the picture, but not in their present legal status as the defeated power in World War II.''

DOC.HEAD: Summit at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Saturday's developments in the summit talks between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.
DOC.HEAD: CAMP DAVID
DOC.TEXT: The two leaders, in a day of informal discussions in the rustic mountain atmosphere of Camp David, took the opportunity to lean back and reflect on a year of dramatic international turmoil. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev joined their husbands at the presidential retreat.
DOC.HEAD: ISSUES
DOC.TEXT: Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Bush and Gorbachev skirted some of the toughest issues that divide them: Germany and Lithuania. The agenda included such regional issues as Nicaragua, Afghanistan, Cambodia, Cuba, El Salvador, India, Pakistan and the Middle East.
DOC.HEAD: AGREEMENTS
DOC.TEXT: At the State Department, U.S. and Soviet officials signed agreements establishing cultural and informational centers in Washington and Moscow and a pact aimed at doubling circulation of government magazines, ``America Illustrated'' and ``Soviet Life,'' distributed in the respective countries. They also signed a customs cooperation agreement in which U.S. officials would provide special training to Soviet customs agents in to stop smuggling of illegal drugs.
DOC.HEAD: NEXT STOPS
DOC.TEXT: After the two presidents appear at a joint news conference Sunday, Gorbachev and his wife travel to Minneapolis, where they plan to visit a dairy farm and dine with Gov. Gov. Rudy Perpich and his wife, Lola. Later Sunday, the Gorbachevs fly to San Francisco for an overnight stay.

DOC.HEAD: Crewman Killed in Yacht Race, Dozen Injured
DOC.TEXT: One crewman was struck and killed by a boom on Saturday and at least 12 people injured as 1,500 boats competed in a 52-mile race through choppy seas around the Isle of Wight, the coast guard said. A spokesman for Solent coast guard said 51 people were rescued and the 12 injured people were taken to the naval hospital at Haslar, Portsmouth after the various accidents. The secretary of the Island Sailing Club, Tony Pearson, said most of the sailors had a safe passage as they raced around the island off the south coast of England. The race was won by Spirit of Apricot in 4 hours and 14 minutes. The dead crewman was from the yacht Phoenix Too. His name was not immediately released. Seas around the island were choppy with southwesterly winds of 25 mph, and numerous other accidents were reported. In another instance, a Royal Navy helicopter airlifted a man and a woman from the yacht Raymark after they suffered serious head injuries. A Ministry of Defense spokesman said the couple had been struck by a mainsail boom as the boat maneuvered. The couple are being held in the hospital overnight for observation. Two other people suffered broken arms when the yachts Alexa and Starlight collided. Another person was in intensive care for facial injuries, and one sailor was reported to have had a heart attack during the race.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Rival Union Attacks Economic Plan
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Solidarity's rival trade union on Saturday attacked the government's economic plan for creating unemployment and appealed for a social security plan to protect workers. Alfred Miodowicz, leader of the OPZZ trade union alliance that communist authorities formed in 1984, told delegates at the union's second national congress that the country needed to prepare for a five-year battle for the ``existence of Poles.'' OPZZ claims 6.5 million members and the congress is being held in Warsaw to discuss the Solidarity-led government's plan to introduce a free market economy. The dismantling of the centrally planned economy threatens jobs in inefficient state-run industries and public service sectors where many OPZZ members work. The government's radical reform plan, designed by Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz and introduced Jan. 1, has cut subsidies to major enterprises, lifted price controls and maintained a tight wage policy. Over 400,000 people are officially receiving unemployment benefits. ``Balcerowicz's plan is faulty because it assumes a reduction of jobs _ unemployment _ from the very start,'' Miodowicz told the delegates. He also stressed the need for ``social justice'' in the economy. OPZZ was formed while Solidarity was still illegal and has never enjoyed the prestige of Solidarity. OPZZ was humiliated last week when Solidarity leader Lech Walesa managed to end an OPZZ-backed strike by railway workers that disrupted train service for a week. Also Saturday, the congress re-elected Miodowicz as chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Decisions on China, Lithuania Set Stage for Trade Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafss 6-8, bgng, White House spokesman xxx etc., to UPDATE with Fitzwater comment on considerations behind decision to sign trade pact.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: True, there were some 11th-hour negotiations. But the seeds of President Bush's decision to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union were sown in his renewal of trade benefits for the Chinese and his refusal to impose sanctions against Moscow over Lithuania. Bush's action meant that for the second time in as many weeks, he was ignoring widespread congressional opposition to a trade agreement with a regime whose human rights policies have been sharply criticized. Bush's earlier renewal of trade benefits to China and his decision not to slap economic sanctions on Moscow over its hardline approach in the Baltic states made it harder for him to say no to an anxious Gorbachev, some aides are suggesting. If Bush won any private assurances from Gorbachev on Lithuania in exchange for the trade deal, neither side was letting on. U.S. officials insisted that Bush did not extract any such commitment from Gorbachev; and Soviet officials continue to characterize the stalemate as an internal dispute that they will resolve themselves. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, briefing reporters Saturday on Bush's talks with Gorbachev at the Maryland presidential retreat, was asked what the United States got in return for signing the trade pact. ``Well, we got out of it ... what we put into at Malta (summit), which was the recognition that, as the superpower and leader of the Western alliance, that we are leading the way to help the Soviet Union integrate itself into the international economic community.'' ``Certainly signing the trade agreement, from our point of view, is a symbol and a way to encourage further development, to try to help out with that process of economic reform,'' he said. U.S. sources said that, even though Soviet officials balked at the last minute at signing a grain deal, Bush's mind was not made up by this last minute Soviet attempt at haggling. Instead, Gorbachev's fervent, direct appeal for the agreement and Bush's desire to help strengthen the hand of the embattled Soviet leader at home had more bearing on his decision, the officials said. Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said it was clear that Gorbachev ``wanted some give on the trade side ... I think he feels that if he doesn't get it he's going home empty-handed.'' The Soviet leader himself made it clear in his comments to congressional leaders on Friday at the Soviet Embassy that he sorely wanted the trade pact. And, in fact, Gorbachev himself raised the specter of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in noting that the United States had extended its most-favored-nation trade hand to Beijing _ but not to Moscow. Gorbachev pressed the same points in meetings with Bush both on Thursday and on Friday, said an administration official. At one point, Bush even expressed frustration that the Supreme Soviet had not yet acted on long pending legislation to codify more liberal emigration policies, sources said. The Soviet leader told Bush he would make an even harder effort to get the law passed, the sources said. Yevgeny M. Primakov, a top Gorbachev adviser, told reporters Saturday that the emigration law is ``on the finishing line.'' Sources said Gorbachev's forceful pleas, together with Bush's historical bias against economic sanctions, helped the Soviet leader win his case. As Bush and Gorbachev relaxed at the U.S. presidential retreat here in the Cactoctin Mountains of Maryland on Saturday, the divisive trade decision was behind them and they went on to other issues. But the Bush administration still faces a likely battle in Congress as the president tries to win approval of the new agreement. A tough battle is also expected on the China move. With China, Bush renewed already existing most-favored-nation status for another year. But the Soviet Union has not had most-favored-nation status since 1952, when it was revoked by Congress. The Jackson-Vanik amendment to the 1974 Trade Act requires a country to have both a trade agreement with the United States and a law allowing free emigration before it can be granted most-favored-nation status. In giving Gorbachev the trade agreement _ the first part of the equation _ Bush also attached a short string. He told the Soviet leader he would not even send the measure to Congress for approval until the Supreme Soviet passes the emigration law. However, the strings extended only to emigration policy, not Lithuania. And the absence of any Soviet concessions on Lithuania is what is likely to stir the most opposition. The Senate passed a resolution May 1 urging Bush to hold off granting most-favored-nation status to the Soviets until they lifted the blockade against Lithuania. Administration officials are backpeddling _ trying to assert that there never had been a link between trade and Lithuania. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday, ``There has been no formal linkage by anybody in this administration that I am aware of'' between the two issues. Baker didn't place it there, but the emphasis clearly was on the word ``formal'' since before the summit one official after another had informally linked the trade pact with progress on two fronts: the Soviet emigration law and Lithuania.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Airlines Bans Smoking On Domestic Flights
DOC.TEXT: Indian Airlines, India's state-owned carrier, will prohibit smoking on all domestic flights, the company announced Saturday. The company said the ban, which takes effect Wednesday, will not apply to its flights to Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Afghanistan or Singapore. Indian Airlines, India's biggest domestic airline, already bans smoking on some flights. Air-India, the government-owned international airline, allows smoking as does Vayudoot, a smaller domestic carrier.

DOC.HEAD: Naked Man Crashes Through Windows, Is Shot Dead in Bizarre Rampage
DOC.TEXT: A homeowner shot and killed a naked man who charged through a glass door during a neighborhood rampage, police said Saturday. The man earlier smashed his head or hand through windows at three other homes late Friday, terrorizing residents but not harming them. There was no explanation for the bizarre assault on the San Fernando Valley neighborhood. Police were awaiting the results of coroner's tests to determine if the man was on drugs, said Detective Rick Swanston. The dead man was identified as Gene Brian Hollaway, 23, who lived about a mile away from the neighborhood where he was killed and did not know any of the people who were terrorized, Swanston said. ``We are looking at it as a justifiable homicide,'' he said. Hollaway had been unemployed for about a year since being discharged from the Army. The rampage ended when homeowner James Bruner, 38, shot Hollaway as he reportedly advanced toward Bruner's wife, Elizabeth, after breaking into their house. Police were called to the Bruner home about 11 p.m. Bruner, 38, told police he was at home with his wife and child when he heard a noise in the back yard, went outside and was confronted by a blood-covered naked man. They struggled until Bruner got back inside his house and locked a sliding glass door behind him. He told his wife to call police and armed himself with a shotgun. Hollaway then threw his body through the glass door and Bruner fired twice as Hollaway moved threateningly toward Mrs. Bruner, Swanston said. Simultaneously, three break-ins were reported nearby. Residents said an intruder shoved his head through a closed bathroom window at one house and began yelling, the detective said. The man smashed a fist through a window in the front door of a second house, unlocked the door, confronted a woman, entered her bedroom, then threw himself out a front window. A bedroom window was smashed at a third house but Hollaway did not enter. Instead he went into the back yard and disrobed before proceeding to the Bruner house. Bruner was questioned, but was not arrested.

DOC.HEAD: One Man Killed in Riot at Concert by British Group in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: Police clashed with rioting music fans who tore down fences to see a concert by a British reggae band, news reports said Saturday. One man was reported killed, and 39 people were injured. The violence broke out when angry fans outside a stadium in the eastern town of Mutare late Friday ripped the fences down to enter the concert by the group Misty In Roots, the semi-official Zimbabwe Inter African News Agency reported. The rioters then overturned a car and set it on fire, the agency said. The report quoted a police spokeswoman, Judith Nqwababa, as saying police fired warning shots after rioters also tried to set fire to a gasoline station near the stadium. The news agency said police also shot tear gas to break up the crowd. ``Somebody in the crowd fired back with a shotgun, disemboweling a man nearby,'' Nqwababa was quoted as saying. Of the injured, 38 were music fans and one was a handler of police dogs. About 18 fans were arrested, the news agency said. Misty In Roots has been touring this southern African country for about two weeks to help raise funds for handicapped and orphaned children.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitute Deaths Raise Fears of Serial Killer in Nation's Capital
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf, The cops, and 8th graf, But the, to CHANGE `cops' to `police' to CONFORM to style; picks up 9th graf, ``I'm having
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of the women keep turning up. Two in one weekend. Nine over the past 14 months. Eight were white. Seven were known prostitutes. Three young women were suffocated within five days of each other last week, their bodies found in suburban Virginia. Every new murder renews the question: Is there a serial killer on the loose targeting prostitutes who work several blocks from the White House? The police aren't talking. ``We're looking at all the possibilities,'' said Mike Rocconi, an Arlington County (Va.) police spokesman, echoing statements by other police departments. ``I don't believe they are at the point where they are going to say they are all related,'' said Lucy Caldwell, a Virginia State Police spokeswoman. But the women who walk the streets once frequented by at least seven of the victims know that someone is killing white, blond prostitutes. They say they are taking precautions, even though two local police officers who knew all the dead women say business seems to be proceeding as usual. ``I'm having the guys follow me in a taxi,'' said one blond, self-described ``whore,'' identifying herself only as Susan. ``I quit working at night.'' Marie, a 22-year-old brunette with a 3-year-old baby to support, said she no longer gets into a customer's car, but she recognizes such precautions may be useless. ``If he's a serial killer, nothing's going to help us,'' said Marie, dressed like a college coed out for a jog. ``A couple of the girls he's gotten so far were fighters. ... He must have some sort of scars on him, because at least two of them wouldn't have given up their lives without a fight.'' The nine cases have similarities and differences: _Seven are known prostitutes who worked in the District. The identities and the occupations of the other two were not yet known. _Eight victims were white, including the seven prostitutes. One was black. _The three victims found last week in Virginia _ two in Arlington over the weekend and one in Alexandria on Wednesday _ were suffocated. Three other victims were shot in the head. Two were shot in the chest. One was killed by a blow to the head. _Six victims were found in the Virginia suburbs, three in the District. A criminologist said different killing methods and locations don't necessarily mean several killers are at work. ``It might mean he's trying to screw up the cops,'' said Robert O. Heck, an architect of the FBI's serial killing unit. He stressed he was discussing such killers in general, not the Washington cases. ``Different types of killing is nothing,'' said Heck, who now works for the Justice Department's juvenile justice office. ``Even geographics could change vastly with a serial killer. Twenty miles is nothing to some of them.'' The many police jurisdictions involved are sharing information, and they held a meeting Thursday that included the FBI. But no task force has been formed that would indicate the agencies believe the slayings are linked. Prissy Williams-Godfrey, a self-described madam and spokeswoman for prostitutes, said she is outraged at what she considers police inaction. ``I never thought I would see white women in America being treated like this,'' said Williams-Godfrey, who is black. ``They're being treated that way because of their sexual preference. They (police) think these women are getting exactly what they deserve.'' Instead of sending out male decoys to catch female prostitutes, she said, police should ``put women decoys out to catch the killer.'' The fact that most of the victims have been prostitutes should not ease the fears of those who aren't streetwalkers, said Merlyn D. ``Doug'' Moore, a professor at Sam Houston Criminal Justice Center in Huntsville, Texas. ``A prostitute is a more likely candidate just because of the nature of her business,'' Moore said. However, he said, ``The assumption is that the individual who is killing is only killing prostitutes, and we don't know that. How many other homicides might there be but we haven't found them yet?'' Prostitutes know danger comes with the territory. ``If you put yourself out here on the street, trying to make money, what can you expect?'' said Cindy, 25, rubbing a bruise inflicted by a customer. The freckle-faced blonde from Sacramento said prostitution has paid her bills for 11 years, the last four in Washington. Some streetwalkers claim to make $1,500 to $2,000 a week here. Although she knew seven of the murder victims, she plans to keep working. ``Washington is a good town,'' Cindy said. ``There's a whole bunch of money here for prostitutes.'' Police, meanwhile, were trying to determine the identities of two victims. One _ found suffocated Wednesday near an office complex in Alexandria _ was described as white, under 20, 5-foot-3 to 5-foot-4, about 130 pounds with brown eyes and brownish-blond hair. She was wearing a black leather and suede jacket, a turquoise and black top and black Spandex pants. A black woman who was shot five times, several times in the head, was found May 9 on a curb in Falls Church, Va. The seven victims who worked the same Washington corridor, according to authorities or fellow prostitutes, are: _Sandra Rene Johnson, 20, found May 27 in her apartment in the Country Club Towers in Arlington. She was suffocated. _Sherry Kay Larman, 26, of Lanham, Md., found May 26 on the top level of parking garage on South Highland Street in Arlington. She was suffocated. _Lisa Colleen Grossman, 29, of Fairfax County, Va., found March 18 on South Pickett Street in Alexandria, Va. She died from a blow to the head. _Carolen Marie Wallace, 22, of Forestville, Md., found Feb. 14 in a Fairfax County storm sewer near I-495. She was shot in the head. _Roxanne Lynn Johnson, 23, of Baltimore, found Oct. 1 outside Ballou High School in southeast Washington. She was shot in the head. _Cori Louise Jones, 29, found Aug. 12 on a street in the Anacostia section of Washington. She was shot in the chest. _Mary Ellen Sullenberger, 20, of Lancaster, Pa., found April 2, 1989, near 12th and L streets in northwest Washington. She was shot in the chest.

DOC.HEAD: Police Pickets Throw Democrats' Convention Into Chaos, Dukakis Bids Adieu
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Bellotti winning endorsement, Silber making ballot, quotes, details, Dukakis giving farewell speech and receiving standing ovation, remove outdated material; picks up 16th graf, `On Friday night...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SP1
DOC.TEXT: After hours of chaos due to police protests, former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti won the endorsement for governor at Saturday's state Democratic convention and John Silber won a spot in the primary. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, who had predicted she would win the endorsement, also locked up a spot in September's primary with a second-place finish. State Rep. John Flood was eliminated. Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, qualified for the primary by a razor-thin margin of 22 votes in the first round of balloting. A police picket outside Springfield Civic Center to protest decaying police equipment delayed proceedings for more than three hours when thousands of delegates remained outside to honor the picket line. Gov. Michael Dukakis' farewell speech was pushed from early morning into the afternoon. Democratic officials finally obtained an injunction to keep the picket line away from the convention center. Some Democrats accused the police of playing politics and trying to spoil the event, since the union supported George Bush in the 1988 presidential election. The 5,000 delegates gave Dukakis a standing ovation before and after his remarks. The 1988 Democratic presidential candidate urged the party to stick by its agenda of affordable housing, environmental protection, universal health care and job training _ an agenda he set in three terms as governor. ``This is the first statewide election in nearly a quarter of a century where I won't be with you in your living rooms and at your plant gates, asking, giving, working and always caring,'' Dukakis said. ``It's been a long and winding road full of highs and lows, full of thrills and chills and more than a few spills.'' ``You are my extended family,'' he told the crowd, some of whom waved ``proud of Dukakis'' signs. On the first ballot, Silber collected 746 votes, or 15.46 percent, from the 4,824 delegates. Fifteen percent was needed to qualify for the primary. ``We were sweating blood,'' said Silber, who promptly withdrew his name from further balloting, allowing his delegates to move on to other candidates. Flood received 4.5 percent in the first round, Bellotti 42.9 percent and Murphy 37 percent. Bellotti and Murphy were already assured of making the ballot based on results of party caucuses earlier this year. Under convention rules, balloting continued until a candidate received more than 50 percent. The low candidate would be dropped starting with the second ballot. In the second round, Bellott won the endorsement with 51 percent of the 4,613 delegates voting. Murphy received 40 percent and Flood was eliminated with 8.5 percent. Police had been threatening to picket the convention for weeks. Union President Robert Jacobson said officers have been forced to use decaying squad cars and other equipment. On Friday night, the union and Democratic Party announced a compromise whereby the police would only conduct an informational picket if Springfield Mayor Mary Hurley agreed not to address the convention. But Jacobson claimed Hurley violated the agreement by entering the convention center Friday night. Hurley dismissed the union's charges, saying no agreement existed for her to stay out of the convention center. She apologized to the delegates for Saturday's events. Still, some Democrats said the police union simply was trying to embarrass the Democratic Party. Some party officials noted that Alexander Tennant, state GOP executive director, and Ron Kaufman, who headed Bush's Massachusetts campaign, were both in Springfield for the convention. ``I don't know if they instigated it,'' said state Sen. Lois Pines. ``But I think they're happy about it.'' Republican Party officials could not be reached for comment, and Jacobson insisted politics were not involved in the protest.

Every new murder renews the question: Is there a serial killer on the loose targeting prostitutes who work several blocks from the White House? The police aren't talking. ``We're looking at all the possibilities,'' said Mike Rocconi, an Arlington County (Va.) police spokesman, echoing statements by other police departments.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Accidentally Blow Up Furniture Store
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels armed with a grenade launcher tried to blow up an armored police vehicle but missed their target and instead blew up a furniture store in downtown Lima, police said Saturday. The attack sparked a gunfight between the rebels and police and one bystander was killed and three people wounded, police said. On Friday, two guerrillas with the Maoist-inspired Shinning Path shot to death the manager of a Lima stove manufacturing company as he was walking near the factory, police said. Shining Path guerrillas reportedly have infiltrated the company's union, which has been on strike since May 3. The attempted attack against the police van took place shortly before midnight Friday. At the same hour, explosions rocked two Lima offices of the center-right Democratic Front coalition, the group backing novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in the June 10 presidential runoff election. Bombs also damaged two offices of the centrist Change 90 political movement, which is supporting frontrunner Alberto Fujimori in the election. Another bomb detonated at the headquarters of President Alan Garcia's center-left Aprista Party slightly wounding three people, police said. It was unclear which rebel group was responsible for the bombing and the grenade attack. Police said the rebels shot the grenade from a passing car. The explosion damaged a furniture store and three adjoining businesses, all of which were closed at the time of the attack. Police opened fire at the car, and the rebels shot back with automatic weapons before speeding off. One man walking in the area was killed by a stray bullet, and two women were wounded. One of the six policemen in the armored vehicle was wounded in the gunfight, police said. Two major guerrilla groups are fighting Peru's elected government. The Maoist-oriented Shining Path is the largest and most violent rebel group. It took up arms in 1980 and now controls large parts of the central highlands and northern jungle. The pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement started fighting the government in 1984. It often launches night attacks in Lima. The government says more than 18,500 people have died since the groups began their fight. Also on Saturday, police said a light airplane with four Peruvians aboard disappeared in a rugged area of the southern Andes Mountains after experiencing mechanical problems. The plane departed Friday morning from Cuzco bound for Ayacucho, a 45-minute flight over a Andes. The pilot reported mechanical difficulties 30 minutes after takeoff and radio contact with the plane was lost shortly thereafter.

DOC.HEAD: Malpractice Suit Yields Award of $28.7 Million in AIDS Case
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded $28.7 million to a 5-year-old boy, who contracted AIDS through an unauthorized blood transfusion, and his parents in what his attorney believes is the largest award of its kind. The Maricopa County Jury on Friday awarded $26.7 million to Alex Edwards and $1 million to each of his parents, Roy and Pat Edwards. The jury on May 23 found Dr. Abraham Kuruvilla and the Neonatology Associates Ltd. liable for Alex's AIDS infection through the unauthorized transfusion shortly after the boy's birth in 1985. Duane Olson, the Phoenix attorney representing Kuruvilla and the clinic, said he would file an appeal immediately. Olson said the award was ``worse than I ever could have dreamed.'' Alex can neither walk nor talk and needs 24-hour care due to damage to his nervous system from the disease. Jurors said they didn't know how how long the boy would live but that they wanted to make sure he had enough to provide for his needs. ``What's going to happen if he lives to be 30 or 40?'' asked jury foreman Ray Howell. Alex's parents ``won't have the money to care for him,'' he said. ``We're just real happy and pleased that the jury worked together and came up with a reasonable sum,'' Roy Edwards told reporters. The boy, dressed in blue jeans and a yellow T-shirt, was cuddled by his mother as jurors announced their decision. Holding her son on her lap, she sometimes kissed his forehead and stroked his blond hair. Kuruvilla was not present. Judge David R. Cole had dismissed two other defendants _ Blood Systems Inc., the parent company of the firm that provided the blood, and Samaritan Health Services, which runs the hospital where the transfusion was administered _ after a settlement was reached in February. Alex was born suffering from severe respiratory problems due to fluid in the lungs when he was transferred to Good Samaritan Hospital, where Kuruvilla ordered the transfusion. That corrected the fluid-related problems, Olson said during the trial. Olson argued that Mrs. Edwards signed a consent form allowing doctors to treat her son as they saw fit. But the Edwards' attorney, R. Douglas Dalton, argued that not enough was known about the risk of AIDS by transfusion and that Kuruvilla should have received consent from the boy's parents for the procedure. The boy's father testified that the couple expressed concerns about AIDS and offered to donate their own blood when the boy was given a previous transfusion. The boy tested positive for the AIDS virus in 1987. Dalton said the largest previous jury award he was aware of for an AIDS-related case was $12 million awarded March 8 in Columbus, Ohio, to an 8-year-old girl who received the AIDS virus in a 1985 blood transfusion.

DOC.HEAD: IPI Expresses Concern for Journalists in Turkey and Nigeria
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute has protested to the leaders of Turkey and Nigeria over the imprisonment of several journalists in the two countries. In a letter to Turkish President Turgut Ozal, IPI director Peter Galliner said the institute was concerned about five imprisoned journalists on a hunger strike. Galliner said the prisoners are protesting two articles of the Turkish Criminal Code which, IPI said, restrict freedom of speech in Turkey. ``We believe that the imprisonment of these five journalists is a gross violation of their basic human and professional rights and we ask that they be released without delay,'' said the message, sent Friday. Galliner said the journalists involved in the hunger strike were: Erhan Tuskan, editor of Ilerici Yurtsever Genclik, Hasan Fikret Ulusoydan, editor of Halkin Sesi, Kazim Arli, editor of Kurtulus Sosyalist Dergi, Irfan Asik, editor of Partizan and Mehmet Ozgen, editor of Bagimiz Turkiye and Devrimci Militan. In another letter sent Friday, the institute protested to Nigerian Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, over the imprisonment of three journalists and the reported closure of four newspapers in that country. The journalists were arrested after the April 22 coup attempt because their reports on the coup offended President Babangida and his military government. The IPI called on the Nigerian government to release immediately Chris Mamah from The Punch, Banji Ogundele from the Sunday News and Tolu Olanrewaju from the Federal Radio Corp. of Nigeria. ``We further request that The Punch, Lagos News, Evening News and Sunday News be reopened without delay and that the media in Nigeria be allowed to pursue their profession without further harassment,'' said the message sent by Galliner. The independent institute, with offices in London and Zurich, claims representation of leading publishers and editors in more than 60 countries. Also Friday, the Nigerian Civil Liberties Organization filed suit to block the two-week-old trial of 10 military officers accused of leading a failed coup attempt against the government. The Civil Liberties Organization, the country's most prominent human rights' group, also seeks to block the pending trial of five civilians by the same military tribunal. The organization filed suit Friday asking a state court to rule that the military tribunal cannot be impartial because the officers sitting on it were targets of the coup plotters. It also said the military will not permit the defendants to have civilian lawyers. No date has been set for a judgment on the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Sephardic Jews Win Prince Of Asturias Award
DOC.TEXT: The world's Sephardidic Jewish communities, scattered by their expulsion from Spain almost 500 years ago, have received the 1990 Prince of Asturias Cooperation Prize. The prize is awarded annually to a person, group or insititution that makes an outstanding contribution to peace, solidarity or progress among men or to the struggle against poverty, illness or ignorance or to the protection of world heritage. Asturias regional government head Pedro de Silva, who led the prize jury, praised the Sephardi for their conservation of their links to Spain over the centuries. ``Far from their homeland, Sephardic Jews converted themselves into an itinerant Spain, and with incomparable fervor conserved the cultural and linguistic legacy of their ancestors,'' de Silva said in announcing the award Friday. ``This prize seeks to contribute to an already initiated process of restoring harmony after five centuries of separation. We call on them to to reinforce their links to their land of origin and we throw open the doors of their ancient country to them,'' de Silva said, reading the jury citation. ``The Sephardic Jews form a deeply beloved part of the great Hispanic family,'' de Silva added. The prize consists of $48,000 and a sculpture by Spanish artist Joan Miro. The foundation giving the award is named for the heir to the Spanish throne. An estimated 2.5 million of the world's 16 million Jews are Sephardic _ descendents of the estimated 250,000 Jews who fled Spain in 1492 after Queen Isabella offered them an alternative of converting to Cristianity, leaving the country or being killed at the hands of the Inquisition. Most moved to North Africa, Italy, and the Middle East. Today many live in Europe, South America and the United States. Some 60 percent of Jews in Israel are Sephardi. Sepharad is the Hebrew name for Spain. The Sephardic communities have maintained many of the customs, traditions and the old Castillian language, known as Ladino, of their ancestors. Spain's Sepharad '92, the country's planned commemoration of the 1492 expulsion of the Jews, will promote numerous cultural activities aimed at enlightening Spaniards about the largely forgotten role of Jews in the development of Spanish culture.

DOC.HEAD: Events in the Soviet Union
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 2nd item, `RIGHTS CONFERENCE...' to UPDATE with Warsaw Pact meeting. Pickup pvs ultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: Saturday's events in Soviet Union:

STREET REACTION _ Muscovites differed over whether Mikhail S. Gorbachev deserved the praise heaped on him during his U.S. visit. ``We're anxious for improvements in trade and anticipate that friendship with America will bring improvements in our lives,'' said a 23-year-old homemaker. But 40-year-old Anatoly Bogudinov said the five humanitarian honors Gorbachev received Friday won't cure shortages at home. ``The least we want is sausage, but he doesn't give it to us, and you ask whether he deserves these awards,'' he said.

RIGHTS CONFERENCE _ An international group monitoring Soviet promises to improve human rights began two days of hearings in Moscow. Officials of the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights said they are testing the Kremlin's tolerance of more public discussion of past abuses.

WARSAW PACT _ The chiefs of staff of Warsaw Pact countries met in Moscow and said they hoped the Vienna negotiations on troop cuts in Europe will be successfully concluded within 1990, Tass reported. The brief Tass report gave no further details.

TELETHON _ Officials say a telethon to collect money for victims of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster raised 76 million rubles _ $115 million at the official rate. The 24-hour telethon was April 26, the fourth anniversary of the disaster.

DOC.HEAD: Liberals And Conservatives Choose Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative Party nominated New York University professor Herbert London for governor Saturday while the Liberal Party chose incumbent Democrat Mario Cuomo. The minor parties met in Manhattan to make their choices, which can be important in close elections, although neither has been a deciding factor in recent races. The anti-abortion Right-to-Life Party is to hold its convention Sunday in Albany. The Liberal Party, which feuded with Cuomo last year over its endorsement of Republican Rudolph Giuliani in the New York mayoral race, chose Cuomo unanimously, said party spokesman Carl Grillo. The Liberals also nominated Democratic Lt. Gov. Stan Lundine and Democratic state Attorney General Robert Abrams for re-election. Meanwhile, the Conservatives, traditional allies of the Republicans in recent statewide races, altered history a bit by nominating London for governor. ``London is the only clear alternative to Cuomo,'' said party spokesman Michael Long, spokesman for the party. The Republicans last week chose political neophyte Pierre Rinfret as their Cuomo challenger. The Canadian-born economist favors abortion rights, a major factor in his rejection by Conservative Party leaders. London, 51, is anti-abortion. The split between Republicans and Conservatives is expected to ease Cuomo's re-election bid. Cuomo is to be nominated Monday at the Democratic state convention for re-election to a third four-year term. The Conservatives nominated Anthony DiPerna, a retired school administrator and Conservative Party official from Suffolk County on Long Island, for lieutenant governor. Bernard Smith, the GOP candidate for attorney general, won Conservative support. New York state has 8.13 million eligible voters. Of those, 3.88 million are enrolled as Democrats; 2.6 million as Republicans; 112,786 as Conservatives; 59,176 as Liberals; and 24,204 as members of the Right-to-Life Party.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Welcomes Iranian Pilgrims, But Bars Protests
DOC.TEXT:
The government said Saturday that Iranians are welcome to take part in this year's Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca but they would not be allowed to demonstrate. Saudi Arabia broke off diplomatic ties with Iran in April 1988 after Iranian pilgrims clashed with this kingdom's police during the preceding year's pilgrimage. The battles killed 402 people, mostly Iranians. The Iranians boycotted the 1988 and 1989 pilgrimages, and some Iranian officials have said they were boycotting the 1990 season. Iran has also claimed Saudi officials were preventing Iranians from taking part this year. However, Saudi Arabian authorities stressed Saturday they are welcoming Iranians to this year's pilgrimage, known as the hajj. The official Saudi Arabian Press Agency quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying the country ``still welcomes the Iranian pilgrims to perform the Hajj rites and will present them with all facilities it accords to their brethren from around the Moslem world, provided they abide fully by the correct rules and conduct of the Hajj. ...'' But, the source was quoted as saying, the kingdom ``cannot show any leniency in any matter that undermines Islamic Sharia (law) or infringes on security, such as holding of rallies and staging of demonstrations. ...'' The agency also quoted the source as saying he regrets Iran's ``continuous rabid campaigns that are escalating day after day in a desperate attempt to convince the Iranian Moslem people that the kingdom of Saudi Arabia is preventing the Iranians from performing the hajj.'' Diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity said Saudi officials even told an Iranian envoy last month that they were prepared to raise their quota for Iranian pilgrims from 45,000 to 60,000. But the envoy apparently insisted on the Iranian right to demonstrate at the hajj, the diplomats said. That visit by Deputy Foreign Minister Mohammad Ali Besharati of Iran was the first by an Iranian official since the kingdom ruptured diplomatic ties with Tehran, accusing Iranian rulers of terrorism and subversion. After their 1979 Islamic revolution, the Iranians had been trying to mount demonstrations almost annually at the hajj. The clashes at the 1987 pilgrimage followed a demonstration by some of the 150,000 Iranian visitors that year. Nearly all Iranian Moslems are Shiites, a minority sect at odds for 1,300 years with the majority Sunnis, who include the Saudi royal family and 85 percent of all Moslems.
The late Iranian spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, accused the Saudi Arabians of being unfit as keepers of Islam's holy sites. About 2 million Moslems from around the world gather for the annual rites that culminate this year in early July.

DOC.HEAD: Delegates Split on Abortion Issue
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin Republicans rejected an attempt Saturday to adopt an anti-abortion party platform plank that would have called for the ``legal protection of all human beings, from conception on.'' But a short time later, delegates endorsed a resolution opposing abortion as a method of birth control or for the mother's convenience. The action by about 1,000 delegates and alternates at the party's one-day annual convention appeared to disatisfy pro-choice and anti-abortion delegates alike. ``It appears to make us look schizoid,'' said Fred Patz, a pro-choice delegate from Milwaukee. Alan D. Jaberg, a member of the Republicans for Choice, said he believed Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, would pounce on the issue and run with it against Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. Thompson, seeking a second four-year term, was not present when the votes on the platform and resolution were taken. He had said he planned to take no part in the convention's abortion debate. State Party Chairman Michael Grebe said he saw no political problem emerging from the action of the delegates on the issue. ``I think the party platform shows that we're a party with a diversity of views on abortion and that we are tolerant of those opinions,'' Grebe said. As for the resolution, Grebe said, ``it shows that on the specific issue a majority of delegates supports a strong pro-life position.''
