The platform plank says that while Americans have a diversity of views on abortion, ``Republicans decry the conditions in contemporary society that have swelled the number of abortions performed.'' ``We support the fostering of responsible attitudes toward sexuality and the promotion of self-esteem,'' it says, calling for child adoption as an alternative to abortion. The plank remained in the platform after delegates rejected 1,698-1,521 a plank that would have declared Republican support for ``legislation that would establish the legal protection for all human beings from conception on.'' ``It's disappointing that the party wants to become neutral on this,'' said Nick Alioto of Milwaukee, sponsor of the rejected version. Thompson has declared his opposition to abortion except in cases of rape or incest or to save a woman's life. Loftus has said he intends to make abortion a key issue in his bid to unseat Thompson.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Opposition Cries Foul Play In Special Election
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties on Saturday accused the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party of trying to rig a special mayoral election in the second largest city in politically volatile Michoacan state. The vote in Uruapan was set for Sunday after allegations of fraud and disputes over the results forced the annulment of balloting on Dec. 3. Such allegations have frequently been made against the governing party, which has ruled Mexico since the party's formation in 1929. Party leaders have pledged to end fraud and corruption within the party. Jose Rosario Torres Ramos, local chairman of the opposition Revolutionary Democratic Party, said he expects the election to extremely close and it could be decided by a few hundred votes. Uruapan, a city of 450,000, was one of more than 20 where the leftist Revolutionary Democratic Party challenged victories awarded to the governing party. The Revolutionary Democratic Party and the conservative National Action Party accused the governing party of removing the names of voters from registration lists and of adding phony names to be used by people recruited to vote for the party. ``People go to pick up the credentials and they aren't there,'' said Juan Antonio Chavez Mendoza, a member of the Revolutionary Democratic Party. He said the governing party distributed 5,000 voting credentials to party loyalists. Luis Donaldo Colosio, national party leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, denied the allegation and said his party ``is confident of an unchallengeable, clear and irrefutable victory.'' He spoke in Guadalajara, the country's second largest city, on Friday. He accused the opposition of resorting to ``violence and anarchy'' because it has little chance of winning. Revolutionary Democratic supporters seized city halls in 21 communities after the Dec. 3 elections to protest the results. Army troops using armored vehicles, firing tear gas and spraying protesters with fire hoses, forced them out four months later. No injuries were reported. Most of those arrested were released a few weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Dies Hours Before Liver Operation
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old Mexican boy who was minutes away from a liver transplant died Saturday before surgeons could begin the operation. Sammy Aguirre arrived at Children's Medical Center at 4 a.m., but his liver was failing, said hospital spokeswoman Sylvia Bodell. ``He was immediately put into the intensive care unit ... but quickly took a turn for the worse,'' Ms. Bodell said. The surgery had been scheduled to begin at 1 p.m., but surgeons determined Sammy would not survive the operation, she said. He died between 12:30 p.m. and 1 p.m. Sammy's parents, Rosa Lilia and Armando Aguirre of Buenaventura in northern Mexico, were by his side when he died, Ms. Bodell said. Parents and physicians had been elated but anxious when they learned Friday that a liver had been found for Sammy, but doctors said the boy's condition had seriously deteriorated. The donated liver came from a Florida child who was slightly larger and a little older than Sammy, said Sammy's doctor, Dr. Troy Reyna. The organ was sent to another liver transplant patient, Ms. Bodell said. On Thursday, Sammy was moved to the highest priority for patients awaiting organ transplants because his liver had failed. The boy remained in a coma. Sammy's ordeal began May 7 when he was admitted to Providence Memorial Hospital in El Paso, about 120 miles northeast of his hometown. Because Sammy was from Mexico, he was ineligible for U.S. programs that could have helped with the operation. Reyna launched a media campaign that brought a $150,000 donation from a Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, businessman and additional donations from the public.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Gorbachev Doff Their Ties; Relax at Mountaintop Retreat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf and INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf, `After lunch ...' to UPDATE with Bush's remarks on Gorbachev's first-time ringer at horseshoes.
DOC.TEXT: They shed their ties, lounged on the patio and zipped around in a golf cart Saturday, but George and Mikhail still call each other Mr. President and Mr. President, and probably always will. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater gave that account of the boundaries of cordiality as Presidents Bush and Gorbachev held informal, relaxed talks at the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains _ highlighted by some beginner's luck at horseshoes. Fitzwater described a halcyon summit day in the countryside that he said was not for policy decision-making but to ``kind of lean back and reflect'' on the relationships between their nations. No first names, though. ``They have a very warm and personal relationship but they still refer to each other as president and I suspect they always will,'' Fitzwater said. ``That's just the nature of the two men.'' ``They settled into the surroundings by removing ties and seated themselves around the large patio table which overlooks the backyard,'' he added. The two world leaders leaned back on the terrace and chatted while overlooking a view of the panoramic countryside, he said. Joined by their four closest aides, they enjoyed a ``very casual and lively give and take,'' he said. ``Both presidents seemed quite pleased with the conversations,'' Fitzwater went on. ``Both laughing intermittently at humorous asides and enjoying the warm Catoctin Mountains sunshine.'' They then took a tour of the grounds on the retreat, with Gorbachev at the wheel of one of the Camp David golf carts. They stopped at various sites around the camp ``including the gym where both presidents had a brief discussion with marines who were working out there at the time.'' After lunch in the camp's Aspen Lodge, the Gorbachevs went for a stroll around the grounds, and stopped to throw a few horseshoes, Fitzwater said. Horseshoes is one of Bush's favorite sports and one in which he delights in engaging his visitors. Before leaving, Bush said it was a great day, ``no neckties, very relaxed.'' ``The only thing that went wrong is _ I pride myself as a horseshoe player _ and, President Gorbachev picked up a horseshoe, never having played the game to my knowledge, and literally, literally _ all you horseshoe players out there _ threw a ringer the first time. Really.'' Bush said Gorbachev explained later over dinner ``that a horseshoe in the Soviet Union, when posted in one's house, symbolizes warmth and friendship. And that made an impression on me.'' Fitzwater said there were no specific agreements reached by the presidents _ just lots of ``understanding about feelings, emotions, where people are coming from and possible avenues for solutions. .... There's a lot of understanding the two men are getting.'' ``This afternoon is really an opportunity for them to just lean back and reflect on how they might help, what their differences are, what their areas of mutual understandings are.'' There was even gift-giving to add to the day's apparent idyll. Bush gave the Gorbachevs matching navy London Fog, U.S.-made, windbreaker jackets, with U.S. emblems and their names on them.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Forces Meet Little Resistance in Drive on Monrovia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf, `U.S. Navy...' to UPDATE with Pentagon comment. Pickup pvs 18th graf, `U.S. Embassy...
DOC.TEXT: Rebel troops seeking to topple the government of President Samuel Doe advanced on the capital Saturday and appeared to be meeting little resistance from government forces. Correspondents who drove the 35 miles from Monrovia to the airport, where the rebel advance had stalled earlier, said the only government troops in sight were 20 men manning a roadblock between the airport and the capital. The rebels were seen fanning out, traveling off the roads straight toward the capital. By avoiding the winding roads and marching through the bush, the insurgents would cut the distance from the airport to 25 miles. The only significant military presence in the capital was around Doe's executive mansion, where 2,000 Israeli-trained troops of his elite Special Anti-Terrorist Unit were stationed. No fighting was reported Saturday, and it was not immediately clear what happened to the remainder of Doe's 5,300-man army. A diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the latest developments could mean that many soldiers had deserted, or that the fighting had stopped because a deal between Doe and the rebels was being worked out. Hundreds of Doe's mainly untrained, ill-equipped and poorly paid troops are known to have deserted during the 6-month-old civil war, according to Liberian military and Western diplomatic sources. The government again broadcast orders for troops who had returned from battle to assemble at the Barclay Training Center, the main barracks in Monrovia. A similar call last week mustered only 70 soldiers, diplomats said. In any case, residents of the city of 500,000 braced for a heavy battle. Rice, a staple, was in short supply, many market shelves were empty, power outages were frequent and there had been no running water for two days. More than 1,000 people have been killed since the fighting broke out in December, most of them civilians slain by government troops. Workers were seen topping the walls of the Italian Embassy compound with barbed wire, while the French Embassy was reinforcing its iron-grid gates with sheets of heavy metal. The rebels _ led by Charles Taylor, the head of the rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia _ accuse the Doe administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. The rebels claim up to 10,000 people belong to their insurgency. Diplomats here put the number at about 4,000. In a last-ditch effort to end the fighting, Doe said on Friday that he would not seek re-election in next year's presidental voting. He asked the United States, which has sent warships toward the Liberian coast to evacuate U.S. citizens, to help negotiate an end to the fighting. The rebels rejected Doe's concessions but offered their own terms: If the president leaves the country the rebels would work with the Liberian government and National Assembly to set up an interim government. Rebel troops already control the country's main port of Buchanan, 60 miles southeast of the capital, and have been advancing from Buchanan and Kakata, 35 miles to the northeast. Before Saturday's advance began, the main rebel column had encamped near the international airport. U.S. Navy warships, meanwhile, were en route from the Mediterranean to Liberia to evacuate Americans if necessary, Pentagon sources said. U.S. military officials said 2,100 Marines were aboard the four ships of the 6th Fleet, which were expected to arrive off Liberia this weekend. ``These units should be in place in the international waters off Liberia shortly,'' Pentagon spokeswoman Maj. Shelley Rogers said Saturday night. U.S. Embassy officials said about 2,000 U.S. citizens, including 110 embassy personnel, and many missionaries and people of Liberian origin, remain in the country. Last month, there were about 6,000 U.S. citizens in Liberia but most chose to leave as the fighting worsened. The British frigate Andromeda and a tanker arrived off the Liberian coast Friday to help in any evacuation, said the Ministry of Defense in London. British officials said 220 British citizens remain, plus 88 British passport-holders and 189 citizens for whom the British have responsibility, including Canadians, Irish, Australians, Malaysians and Sri Lankans. Meanwhile, Church workers erected Red Cross flags outside St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Monrovia on Saturday. That signaled protection for 1,392 refugees registered by the International Committee for the Red Cross since an assault by government troops on refugees in a United Nations' compound on Wednesday. A U.N. security guard was killed in the attack and about 30 men and boys were driven away. Most were shot and killed later and their bodies dumped in the bush, survivors said. Descendants of freed U.S. slaves founded Liberia in 1822, and it became Africa's first independent country in 1847. The West African nation has a population of 2.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Raw Sewage in Biscayne Bay Brings Bacterial Threat
DOC.TEXT: More than two square miles of Biscayne Bay remained polluted with human waste Saturday after raw sewage overflowed a sewer near the Miami River, sending infectious bacteria into the water. Many of the windsurfers, swimmers and jet skiers that usually crowd the area of the bay between the MacArthur and Rickenbacker causeways and Virginia Key, east of Miami's downtown, avoided the water. But not all heeded the message. ``I'm just down in Miami for the summer so I have to take advantage of all the nice weather,'' said water-lover Steve Shapiro. Levels of coliform bacteria in the area were up to 13,000 per milliliter in parts of the bay, 13 times above what is permitted, according to the Dade County Public Health Unit. ``There's bacteria that's in human sewage, and these bacteria are in the water, and if people ingest it and get it in their bodies, it could make them sick,'' said the unit's administrator, Walter Livingstone. The health unit has been monitoring the bay since last week's heavy rains caused an aging sewer pipe near the mouth of the Miami River to overflow. Officials expected the bacteria to wash out with the tides within several days.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of a joint statement the United States and the Soviet Union released Saturday night from the site of the day's summit talks between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: The U.S. and U.S.S.R. discussed relief requirements and the prospects for the political solution to Ethiopia's internal conflict. They welcome the Ethiopian government's agreement to permit relief food to enter northern Ethiopia through the Port of Massawa under a U.N.-sponsored relief effort, and they believe that such operations would not compromise the unity and territorial integrity of Ethiopia. They also welcomed the agreement expressed by the Ethiopian government to have U.N. representatives present in the course of the negotiations between the Ethiopian government and the Eritreans. In addition, to deal with the growing problems of starvation, the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. are prepared to work together and combine their assets. U.S. food will be transported on Soviet aircraft to demonstrate our joint commitment to responding to this tragic humanitarian problem. Recognizing the continuing political and military conflicts that exacerbate the problems of starvation and recognizing also the lack of momentum on peace talks, the U.S. and U.S.S.R. will support an international conference of governments under the auspices of the U.N. on settlement of conflict situations in the Horn of Africa.
DOC.HEAD: End of text
CUNY Students End John Jay Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Students on Saturday ended their three-week occupation of an administration building at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice over budget cuts and affirmative-action issues. But a spokeswoman for the students said the protest was only partly successful. The agreement reached Friday with the City University of New York board of trustees was an unsatisfying compromise, said Sheena Hazel, a CUNY senior who helped lead the occupation. ``What we really wanted was the resignation of particular administrators'' demonstrators viewed as racist or hostile to student interests, Hazel said. Under the agreement, the students pledged to vacate the building in return for several concessions, including amnesty from disciplinary charges and permission to participate in faculty searches. However, the university reserved the right to press charges for any vandalism that may have occurred during the protest. John Jay College is part of the CUNY system. College President Gerald W. Lynch also bowed to the students' demand that a popular professor be recommended for tenure, according to Steven Young, counsel to the president. Young said the teacher, Donald Torrez, will probaly be granted tenure, although the final decision rests with the CUNY board. In an effort to foster understanding, the college will also hold monthly ``town meetings'' at which people can voice their concerns, Young said.

DOC.HEAD: Escalator Steps Collapse, Injuring 15
DOC.TEXT: Escalator steps at a subway station for Yankee Stadium collapsed Saturday night, injuring 15 people, officials said. The four steps of the ``up'' escalator collapsed just before 9 p.m., said Transit Authority spokesman Termaine Garden. The accident in the Bronx occurred about 90 minutes after a game at Yankee Stadium began. Three of the 15 injured suffered broken limbs but none of the injuries appeared to be life-threatening, he said. Some were taken to hospitals and some were being treated at the scene by Emergency Medical Service technicians, said Capt. Jeffrey Armstrong, an EMS spokesman. The escalator connects an underground train line with an elevated line, Garden said.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Summit-Ethiopia
U.S. And Soviet Union To Cooperate On Food Airlifts To Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union issued a joint statement Saturday pledging to save Ethiopians from starvation by joint food airlifts to the impoverished African nation. The statement, issued at the end of day-long summit talks between Presidents George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, also said the two countries would support an international conference under U.N. auspices to bring peace to the Horn of Africa. The agreement reflects tangible proof of the growing cooperation between Soviets and Americans in resolving conflicts in their spheres of influence around the world. The two superpowers cooperated on an agreement that led to independence for Namibia this year and to the pullout of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola. Bush and Gorbachev also discussed possible cooperation on endin civil wars in Afghanistan and Cambodia, where each supports different sides, but spokesmen said no formal agreements were reached. The need for cooperation is particularly acute in Ethiopia, where 4 million to 5 million people are in danger of hunger as a result of a prolonged civil war and successive droughts. The United States approached the Soviets with the idea of a joint airlift several months ago. To ease the hunger problem, U.S. food will be transported on Soviet aircraft ``to demonstrate our joint commitment to responding to this tragic humanitarian problem,'' the communique said. The Soviet Union, reeling under domestic economic woes, has significantly scaled back its economic and military aid to Ethiopia, prompting President Mengistu Haile Mariam to look elsewhere. In an effort to win approval from the West, Mengistu agreed recently to let relief shipments into the country after suspending them in a bid to punish rebels in northern Ethiopia. The two countries ``welcome the Ethiopian government's agreement to permit relief food to enter northern Ethiopia through the Port of Massawa under a U.N.-sponsored relief effort, and they believe that such operations would not compromise the unity and territorial integrity of Ethiopia,'' said the joint statement. The two sides also hailed Ethiopia's agreement to have U.N. representatives attend negotiations between the Ethiopian government and Eritrean rebels seeking independence in one of the continents longest civil wars. An attempt earlier this year by former President Jimmy Carter to mediate between Ethiopia and the Eritreans failed to yield concrete results.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Set Out For 260-Mile Wagon Train Trip
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 1,000 people hitched up horses and hopped onto wagons Saturday for the first leg of a 260-mile trek along an old settlers' trail to celebrate Wyoming's centennial. A fife and drum corps helped kick off the wagon train in Casper and participants traveled 12 miles before circling up and camping out for the night. Except for a shortage of portable toilets and a rider who was slightly injured when thrown from a horse, there were no problems, organizers said. ``Things went pretty smoothly for the first day. I'm really pleased and really proud of everybody,'' said Kayne Pyatt, trail boss for the 30-day trip on the Jim Bridger Trail. Wagons, including stage coaches and old-time canvas covered models, stretched nearly a mile on paved and gravel roads along the trail, which was used by settlers when Indian violence prevented their passage on the Oregon Trail. Residents along the way greeted the procession of wagons, horses and a handful of people walking the trail to commemorate the western migration of settlers. The 260-mile Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train is to wind up July 2 in Cody, just outside Yellowstone National Park northwest of Casper. State Attorney General Joe Meyer led the procession in a surrey. Other Wyoming dignitaries, including Gov. Mike Sullivan, plan to participate later. ``This is delightful,'' Meyer said. ``It's exciting.'' More than 70 wagons and nearly 1,000 people from across the United States are participating, organizers said. Some signed up for just part of the way, while others will go the distance. ``I thought it went excellent,'' said Val Geisler, the wagon train's head wrangler. ``It is working and the people are having a good time.'' Long lines at the sole portable toilet prompted promises from Pyatt to add some more.

DOC.HEAD: Red Brigades Terrorists Convicted in Senator's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A court has sentenced nine leftist Red Brigades terrorists to life in prison after convicting them of murdering a Christian Democrat senator. Roberto Ruffilli, a close friend and adviser to then Premier Ciriaco De Mita, was shot to death in his home on April 16, 1988. Ruffilli was a key architect of institutional reform plans. Three of the defendants were acquitted in the verdicts issued Friday. The leftist Red Brigades carried out scores of violent attacks in the 1970s and early 1980s aimed at toppling the Italian government. During that period, the Red Brigades kidnapped and killed Aldo Moro, a former premier and president of the Christian Democrat Party.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Supporter Wins Election on Reservation Where Two Died Over Gambling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Norman Tarbell ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Norman Tarbell comment, ADD that he is to take office July 1; picks up 6th graf, `Traditionalists such ...' SUBS 11th graf, `Harold Tarbell ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with number of people turned away, other quote, details; picks up penultimate graf, `Most of ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Mohawk Indian who views casino gambling as an economic boon to the reservation unseated the tribe's anti-gambling incumbent chief in an election Saturday. The election amounted to a referendum on gambling, an issue so divisive among Mohawks it led to bloodshed May 1, when two Indians were shot to death in a clash between pro- and anti-gambling factions. Since then, New York state and Canadian police have occupied the 28,000-acre reservation, which straddles the international border. Norman Tarbell received 637 votes to defeat his distant cousin, incumbent Harold Tarbell, who got 538 votes in his attempt to win a second, three-year term, according to acting tribal secretary Stacey Terrance. Twelve votes were ruled invalid, she said. Harold Tarbell said he would appeal, alleging voting improprieties. With Norman Tarbell's election, the three-man tribal council ruling the U.S. side of the St. Regis Indian Reservation will unanimously support casinos on Mohawk land. The other council chiefs are Lincoln White and L. David Jacobs. Norman Tarbell is to become junior chief on the council on July 1; at that time Jacobs becomes head chief and White second chief. Norman Tarbell said Saturday that his first priority as a chief would be ``to put our people back to work.'' Traditionalists such as Harold Tarbell claim the eight casinos on the U.S. side of the reservation breed drug-running, prostitution and other crime. White, Jacobs and Norman Tarbell say the casinos bring badly needed jobs to the reservation, where the unemployment rate is about 30 percent. About 3,400 Mohawks were eligible to vote in the election on the St. Regis Indian Reservation. Harold Tarbell said Saturday night he would contest the election on the grounds that Jacobs and White excluded U.S. Mohawks living on the Canadian side from voting. In past elections, Mohawks living there were allowed to vote. ``Well, I haven't quite lost yet, because there were so many improprieties ... we're going to have to sort that out in the next couple of months,'' Harold Tarbell said. He characterized the voting as ``chaos,'' and said, ``It made no sense to protest ... so we're going to have to appeal it.'' Jacobs and White adopted a list of eligible voters based on tribal rules that allow only Indians living on the U.S. side to vote. A state Supreme Court judge upheld the list Friday. Sixty-two people were turned away from the polls Saturday on grounds they weren't on the list, said Franklin County Attorney Brian Stewart, who served as an election official. Most, if not all those people, were supporters of Harold Tarbell. In addition to Stewart, three federal mediators were on hand, and Franklin County sheriff's deputies were stationed at the tribal headquarters, which was the only polling place. Harold Tarbell, who lives on the U.S. side, said he wasn't on the official voting list but was allowed to vote anyway. He alleged that the many people not on the list were also allowed to vote. Norman Tarbell said no challenge would overturn the election. ``A hundred votes is a hundred votes. They don't have anything to stand on even if they do challenge it,'' he said. Most of the U.S. Indians living on the Canadian side are gambling opponents and likely would have voted for Harold Tarbell. As many as 500 U.S. Indians living in Canada would have been eligible to vote, Harold Tarbell said. The casinos have been closed while tribal leaders negotiate with state and federal mediators to end the gambling war.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Rape, Murder of 12-Year-Old Girl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Prosecutors, meanwhile ...,' to CORRECT that prosecutors hope to persuade jury to recommend death for Powers, sted Formet.
DOC.TEXT: A man who already faces life sentences for three other rapes broke into a wide grin Saturday after a jury found him guilty in the kidnapping, rape and murder of a 12-year-old girl. Robert Power, 29, also was found guilty of robbing Orange County deputy sheriff Richard Welty of his gun and radio in the field where Angeli Bare's body was found, hogtied and bleeding the day of her death. The Lee County jurors took less than five hours to find Power guilty of first-degree murder in the Oct. 6, 1987, attack near Angeli's south Orange County home. Prosecutors said they would emphasize Power's prison record in seeking the death penalty. One of Power's attorneys, F. Wesley Blanker, said persuading the same jury next month to recommend a sentence of life in prison with no parole for 25 years will be unlikely. Angeli's stepfather, Gary ``Butch'' Bare, was relieved by the verdict. ``It's a big hurdle in the grieving process,'' Bare said. ``It gives me somebody I can point my finger at and say `you did it.' This was bad enough as it is, but it would be worse if the person who did it went free.'' Power, who already faces 10 consecutive life sentences in prison for rape convictions in Seminole and Osceola counties, blinked and then grinned immediately after the verdict was read. ``He doesn't look real upset,'' one juror said before the panel was escorted from the courtroom. Blankner explained his client's reaction: ``Mr. Power was prepared for the worst in this situation. We didn't kid him. We knew it would be tough to convince a jury otherwise.'' Circuit Judge Gary Formet set the sentencing phase of the trial for sometime next month. Power's attorneys hope that his prison record _ he has spent all but two years of his adult life in jail _ will help him. ``The jury will hear that he hasn't done well in the outside world,'' Blankner said. ``But he's demonstrated that he's done well in a controlled environment. He's been a model inmate.'' Blankner also said he will present evidence that Power was physically abused and sexually assaulted as a child. Prosecutors, meanwhile, have said they will use Power's previous convictions and details of Angeli's slaying to try to persuade the jury to recommend death for Powers. Power was convicted of raping two Kissimmee sisters, ages 12 and 16, and a Longwood woman, all within a month of Angeli's death. Formet barred prosecutors from using that evidence during the two-week trial, which was moved to Lee County because of publicity. Angeli was found half-naked, hogtied and gagged in the field, bleeding from both the rape and a fatal stab wound in her neck. She had been punched in the face and her glasses were broken. Welty identified Power from the witness stand as the man who stole his radio and gun. Radio parts, one bearing the same serial number as Welty's radio, were found in the house where Power was arrested eight days after the murder. Blankner and Power's other attorney, Joerg Jaeger, said they will appeal. If Power is sentenced to death, the Florida Supreme Court will automatically hear the appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Report: City Must Limit Toxic Discharges Into Harbor
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials say New York must limit toxic discharges from its sewage treatment plants to clean up the city's harbor, according to The New York Times. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is to announce next week the strategies the city must develop in limiting copper and mercury discharges from its 14 treatment plants, according to a report in Sunday's paper. The city must limit the discharges by June 1993 in order to meet federal water quality standards, the Times said. The limits also will apply to about 50 other municipal sewage treatment plants and industries in New York and New Jersey that discharge into New York harbor, the report said. The discharged metals, many of which originate from household pipes and industries such as metal finishing, build up in the tissue of the city's harbor shellfish, which have some of the highest levels of heavy-metal contamination in the nation, according to the Times. Sewage treatment plants cannot filter the metals, which go into the harbor in liquids or sludge, the report said. The federal agency's decision to require controls on toxic discharges was disclosed in a letter from Richard Caspe, a regional director of the federal agency, to Administrative Law Judge Andrew Pearlstein. Pearlstein is hearing a lawsuit by environmental groups against the state concerning the discharges.

DOC.HEAD: Antiques And Garden Tools, All For Sale At `Aunt Bee' Sale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf, `What didn't ...,' to UPDATE with results of afternoon auction; picks up 6th graf, `This is ...'
DOC.TEXT: You can buy a velvet Elvis portrait anywhere, but only this weekend could you get a great deal on Aunt Bee's rake. Just about anything at the late Frances Bavier's house went up for sale Saturday. The actress, who died in December at age 86, portrayed the matronly head of the Taylor household in the popular ``Andy Griffith Show,'' which is nearing its 30th anniversary and enjoying continued life in syndication. One of Ms. Bavier's last wishes was to leave the contents of her Siler City home to the University of North Carolina Center for Public Television endowment fund. And you could find it all during a morning sale open to the public, some of whom traveled from as far away as Minnesota and Florida for the buying and bidding. What didn't get snapped up before lunch then went up for an afternoon auction. That included the yellowed copies of Ms. Bavier's contracts and her guacamole-green Studebaker Daytona with 43,000 miles, rotting tires and a ceramic donkey on the dashboard. The center raised about $120,000, spokeswoman AlexSandra Lett said. The car was auctioned for $20,000 to Stanley Bingham and Brown Loflin, both of Denton. They plan to exhibit it at an annual tractor show. A sofa was auctioned for $1,400, she said. A Queen Anne dining table with six chairs went for $1,800. ``This is what she lived with and what she sat on and what she ate, held and touched,'' said Priscilla Bratcher, director of development and community relations for the center. Books, mostly novels, and lamps were most popular amid the end tables, chests of drawers and furniture. The rake went to Glennie Bell of nearby Garner, who said it was for her husband. The price: $45. ``He's a fan and he better not use it,'' she said. ``It'll go in a storage room right now, in a corner that he won't touch. Maybe we'll hang it up in the den later.'' Jackie Hawley of Four Oaks bought a tree trimmer for $20 because ``I didn't have one.'' Bud Kendrick and his wife, Penny, made the three-hour drive from Charlotte and walked out of the sale with a writing table, slightly water-stained but a priceless treasure by their standards. ``It's Aunt Bee. Everybody wants a little bit of Aunt Bee to take home with them,'' Kendrick said. ``She was on television so long and so much a part of your life and you watched her. You just want to take a little bit of that home.'' Mrs. Kendrick watches the show at home every day, and says she's plans to bone up on her Griffith history. ``There's a college course you can take now in Charlotte. I'm seriously considering that,'' she said, to which her husband replied: ``Oh, my God.'' Early in her retirement, Miss Bavier sought to escape identification with her television past. But in her later years, she became reclusive and increasingly referred to herself as Aunt Bee and continued to wear her hair in a bun, her lawyer and a close friend for many years, J. Samuel Williams, has said. One volunteer said the item which a lot of people avoided was the four-poster bed in which Ms. Bavier died. The bed eventually sold for $850.

DOC.HEAD: Burglar Breaks Into Westminster Abbey
DOC.TEXT: A thief broke a 13th century stained glass window and stole $2,200 from a collection box at Westminster Abbey, where Britain's monarchs have been crowned for more than 900 years, police said Saturday. The box was put out for donations to restore the abbey. The police said they believe the thief reached the window at night by climbing scaffolding for the building work outside St. George's Chapel. Scotland Yard police headquarters said the burglary took place Tuesday, but they would not say why news of it was initially withheld. No arrests were reported. Kings and queens since William I in 1066 have been crowned in the abbey, which was largely rebuilt from the 13th century onward. Many monarchs as well as illustrious writers, poets and scientists were entombed there.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Rescues Rock Star, Wife As Fire Engulfs Boat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with passengers identified as rock drummer Dennis Elliot and wife, CORRECTS name of freighter, ADDS quotes, details; no pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: The rock band Foreigner's drummer and his wife jumped into the Atlantic Ocean as fire engulfed their yacht Saturday, and were rescued after a Coast Guard jet spotted them and dropped a raft into the water. The 43-foot yacht Charisma III exploded and sank as Dennis Elliott and his wife, Iona, were picked up in good condition by the crew of a nearby freighter, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Terry Johns. The couple, who were alone on the yacht, said they noticed the fire in the engine room around 3 p.m. Saturday during a trip from the Bahamas to Fort Lauderdale, when they were about 45 miles east of the Florida coast. ``I got out a fire extinguisher ... but I was choking so badly _ we just had time to get out a mayday call,'' a bedraggled-looking Eliott said later. ``The heat in the boat got so bad that the windows shattered and the flames went up, so we knew we had to abandon the ship.'' A Coast Guard Falcon jet was already airborne when the call came in at 3:10 p.m. and was able to drop the raft to the couple 10 minutes later, said Petty Officer Terry Johns. The 600-foot Liberian cargo ship Stena Trailer also responded to Elliott's distress signal. As the freighter's crew helped them from the raft, the yacht, which had a full tank of diesel fuel, exploded and sank to the bottom, Johns said. The Elliots were later hoisted one by one into a Coast Guard helicopter hovering over the freighter, and taken Freeport, Bahamas, where another jet took them back to Opa Locka airport north of Miami. The couple, who were able to save nothing from the boat, left Opa Locka to spend the night at a Fort Lauderdale hotel before returning home to Sherman, Conn., Johns said.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaiian Lava Flow Destroys Church, Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `By Saturday ...,' to UPDATE with lava reaching ocean.
DOC.TEXT: Lava slithering from Kilauea Volcano ignited a church and a home in the rural beach community where 160 buildings have been consumed by waves of molten rock. The Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church burned late Friday and a home across the street caught fire early Saturday, said Civil Defense spokesman Lanny Nakano. The congregation had decided not to move their church during an earlier threat in May. The massive front of slowly advancing lava came within 10 feet of Walter Yamaguchi's abandoned Kalapana Store and Drive-Inn before turning toward the ocean, Nakano said. The creeping lava reached the ocean late Saturday morning. Twenty-one homes remain in the Kalapana area, but only a few are occupied. Since Kilauea eruptions resumed on Jan. 3, 1983, 160 buildings have been destroyed. The flow is being fed from lava welling at an estimated rate of 650,000 cubic yards a day from a vent in the volcano's east rift zone, about seven miles upslope from this decimated coastal community on the island of Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Resort Town Denies 4th of July Parade Permit
DOC.TEXT: This selective resort town has denied a permit for an Independence Day parade sought by the Ku Klux Klan. The request from Richard Ford, imperial wizard of the Fraternal White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, was rejected Friday by Police Chief Joe Terlizzese. ``He told me that this is a resort town. Nobody is interested in the KKK,'' said Ford, who estimated the parade would have 100 to 450 marchers. ``We do not have parades over here,'' said police officer Craig Gunkel, speaking for the chief. ``We've got narrow streets, no parking. There's really just no place to hold it.'' A town ordinance allows parades at the discretion of the chief and town manager. ``My definition of a parade is something that is town-serving: the high school band, entertainment,'' Gunkel said. ``This is an outside group trying to use our town.'' Ford, a retired television repairman from Lantana, said he picked Palm Beach because ``it's by the ocean. It would be a good place.'' He notified the American Civil Liberties Union of the permit rejection. ``A town or city cannot condition issuance of a parade permit on whether it is `town-serving,''' said ACLU attorney James Green. The courts have ruled people have ``the right to express their views no matter how onerous or hateful those ideas might be,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Makes Final Preparations for Gorbachev Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with itinerary finalized. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Red ribbons were tied to trees in front of the governor's mansion and neighbors mowed their lawns Saturday as Minnesotans made last-minute preparations for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's historic visit. Tom Knutson, part of a five-member crew installing a snow-fence barricade across the street from the mansion, said he didn't mind working overtime to prepare for Sunday's event. ``It's great; it's once-in-a-lifetime,'' said Knutson, 52. The 1,800 feet to 2,000 feet of fence will be used to confine reporters and photographers to an area across the street from the mansion, where Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, are to dine with Gov. Rudy Perpich and his wife, Lola. According to the itinerary, the Soviets are to arrive at 1:25 p.m. Sunday from the summit conference with President Bush in Washington. After landing at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, they are to travel by motorcade to the mansion, eat lunch and take a limousine tour of the Twin Cities. Orange- and white-striped highway barricades were in place along both sides of the route to the state Capitol, which is on the tour. Yellow rope to hold back the thousands of people hoping to get a glimpse of the visitors was waiting to be hoisted. At the mansion, red ribbons were tied to trees in front and ``No Parking'' signs were everywhere. A yellow-and-black portable highway sign saying ``Welcome'' in Russian and English hung over Interstate 94 between St. Paul and Minneapolis, where Gorbachev is to meet with 145 business and agricultural leaders while Mrs. Gorbachev visits a Minneapolis family. The entire group will tour a dairy farm in Farmington about 20 miles south of Minneapolis and Control Data Corp. in suburban Bloomington. The Soviets are to depart for San Francisco at 8 p.m., according to the itinerary.

DOC.HEAD: ``Good Morning America'' Wins May Sweeps
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' winner of the morning ratings races for 20 consecutive weeks, easily won the May ratings sweeps, A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates showed Friday. ABC's show averaged a 4.6 rating, with NBC's ``Today'' getting a 3.3, and ``CBS This Morning'' a distant third with a 2.5 average. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ``Good Morning America'' also won the February sweeps. The sweeps, which occur four times year, are periods of intense audience measurements in the nation's local television markets. The results help local stations set their ad rates until the next sweeps period.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Detainees Rioted For Attention, Sheriff Says
DOC.TEXT: Cuban detainees in the Avoyelles Parish jail rioted to get publicity about their status and the likelihood that they will be sent back to Cuba, the sheriff said Friday. ``They have newspapers, TV and telephones,'' Sheriff Bill Belt said. ``Sources in the jail told us that with all the media attention on overcrowding, it gave them an opportunity to make news to further their cause.'' A federal judge has ordered Louisiana sheriffs not to take in any more out-of-state prisoners, which bring the jails more money, because of overcrowding. Thursday's 20-minute riot occurred in a dormitory housing 72 of 211 inmates held for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Federal court papers showed that, as of last week, the jail also held 57 inmates for the city of Washington, D.C., 11 state prisoners, 22 inmates awaiting trial, five parish inmates and three city prisoners. Belt said two guards and four prisoners suffered minor injuries during the melee, and some guards and all 72 prisoners in the dormitory were treated for inhalation of smoke and tear gas. The inmates smashed a cinderblock wall with metal footlockers, set fires in trash cans and threw chunks of concrete at guards before authorities used tear gas to regain control, deputies said. Last week, U.S. District Judge Frank J. Polozola gave Belt and other sheriffs one month to return prisoners they are housing for the city of Washington. He also ordered them not to take any more INS detainees. The judge criticized sheriffs for putting profit ahead of the state's interests. The INS pays parishes $45 a day per prisoner and Washington $40 a day, compared with Louisiana's $18.25 a day for each state inmate in parish jails. Belt said the money for holding out-of-state inmates has helped boost his budget tenfold since 1979. Belt coordinates placement of Washington prisoners in Louisiana jails. Court records show that in addition to the 57 in Avoyelles, Tangipahoa and Lafayette parishes hold 20 each and East Feliciana Parish has four. The INS says seven Louisiana jails hold a total of about 500 illegal aliens. The dormitory where Thursday's riot took place was the site of a June 1988 skirmish in which nine deputies and 14 Cubans were hurt. Afterward, some inmates went on a hunger strike that lasted more than a week. Bergeron said the detainees involved in Thursday's incident came to this country in the ``freedom flotilla'' boatlift from the Cuban port of Mariel in 1980. Mariel Cubans were sent to various parish jails in Louisiana after November 1987 riots in the Federal Detention Center at Oakdale. In eight days of rioting, while 28 employees were held hostage, much of the $17 million complex was burned down. It was rebuilt. The Cubans are waiting for INS hearings because crimes have put their resident status in jeopardy.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communist Protesters Demonstrate at U.S., Soviet Embassies
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 400 anti-Communist demonstrators shouting ``Do Not Sell Out Our Country!'' protested Friday night outside the U.S. and Soviet embassies. The march was timed to coincide with the superpower meeting of President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Washington, said Sorin Pogaceanu, a member of the People's Alliance, which helped organize the protest. The protesters also chanted ``Yalta Equals Malta,'' a reference to the 1945 Yalta conference _ where the World War II superpowers put Romania in the Communist bloc _ and the December 1989 Malta summit. According to rumors in Bucharest, Bush and Gorbachev decided new spheres of influence at the Malta conference. The protesters are demanding that ex-Communist Party officials such as Ion Iliescu, who overwhelmingly won election as president May 20, be banned from office for 10 years. They claim the elections were fraudulent. Many of the demonstrators have taken part in a 41-day-old protest that has blocked University Square, where some of the heaviest fighting took place in December's revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Pogaceanu, a 23-year-old worker, said Friday's demonstration was organized ``to alert public opinion against selling the country again. We want democracy. We want freedom.'' The demonstrators marched from University Square to the U.S. Embassy, where they stood in silence for five minutes in memory of the heroes of the uprising. The crowd marched to the Soviet Embassy for a similar tribute. They shouted ``Please do not sell our country!'' and ``The man who spent five years as a Russian can't think like Bush!'' _ a reference to Iliescu, who went to a university in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Arsenal Uncovered at Kennel
DOC.TEXT: The attack-trained Rottweilers boarding at the Loving Care Kennels supplied the bark. The bite came from the owner's arsenal that included an automatic machine gun and a handgun with a silencer, police said Friday. Kennel owner Biagio ``Gino'' Grimaldi, 48, may be the first to be prosecuted under the new state law banning assault weapons, said Morris County Prosecutor Michael Murphy. Gov. Jim Florio signed the bill into law Wednesday. It was billed as the nation's strictest law to control assault weapons. Investigators said they found the weapons and a small quantity of drugs in the course of an arson investigation Wednesday. Grimaldi was trying to flush 4 ounces of cocaine down a toilet when he swatted officers with a 7-foot floor lamp before police subdued him, Murphy said. Besides the Uzi machine gun, which was found inside a violin case, police confiscated a .22-caliber handgun ``with a sophisticated silencer, a favorite of people who are engaged in the business of murder for hire,'' Murphy said. Police also found shotguns, rifles, handguns, brass knuckles, blackjacks, crossbows, throwing knives, switchblade knives, ammunition, bomb components and nunchuks, a martial arts weapon, Murphy said. ``You could run a small militia out of there,'' Murphy said. State police went to Grimaldi's kennel while investigating the torching Monday of a car parked near an auto repair shop in Hackettstown. Warren County Prosecutor Richard Hare said Grimaldi knew the car's owner but declined to discuss a possible motive for the bombing. Bail was set at $850,000 for the Morris County charges, which included possession of cocaine, possession of a fully automatic weapon, assault against a police officer and other weapons charges. Grimaldi was charged with aggravated arson in Warren County. Bail was set at $5,000. Grimaldi's wife, Theresa, 51, was charged with drug possession and interfering with an arrest.

DOC.HEAD: 8 Named for Economics-Business Fellowships
DOC.TEXT: Eight journalists were named Friday as recipients of the Knight-Bagehot Fellowships in Economics and Business Journalism, the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced. The fellowships, founded in 1975, provide formal business and economics training to experienced journalists. Each recipient spends an academic year at Columbia's schools of business, law, and international and public affairs. The winners are Steve Askin, a Zimbabwe-based journalist; Max A. Cacas of National Public Radio; Howard Gold, associate editor of the Miami Review; Yoshikazu Mikami, Tokyo correspondent for Agence France-Presse; Susan Scherreik, financial reporter for Dow Jones Capital Markets Report; Pamela Smith Sharif, copy editor for The New York Times; Mary E. Speck, a Nicaragua-based writer; and Robin Updike, business reporter for The Seattle Times.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Seek Speed-Up in Housing Sales
DOC.TEXT: About 70 sign-carrying, chanting protesters picketed the offices of the federal S&L bailout agency Friday, demanding that it speed up the sale of houses to poor people. The agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., plans eventually to sell to the poor about 10,000 houses repossessed by failed S&Ls. However, so far, the agency is only offering about 1,000 properties in a pilot program. The protesters, from New York, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. chapters of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (ACORN), briefly entered the offices of a Bush administration board overseeing the corporation before retreating to the sidewalk in front of the building. They chanted ``We want housing,'' carried signs with messages such as ``RTC: Rob The Community'' and hammered together a small ``house'' of 2-by-4s on the sidewalk. ``They are slowing the process. We feel they're not trying to live up to the mandate of Congress,'' said ACORN President Maude Hurd. ``They're dragging their feet.'' In last year's S&L bill, Congress ordered the corporation to give poor people and non-profit groups a 90-day option to buy low-cost homes before the properties are sold to others. ACORN is demanding a meeting with oversight board chairman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Board spokeswoman Diane Casey said she was trying to arrange a meeting with two members of the five-member oversight panel but said, ``They're not going to get a meeting on demand with the secretary of the Treasury.''

DOC.HEAD: Domino's Pizza, Baseball Team Owner to Help Build Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: The owner of the Domino's Pizza Inc. will help build a new cathedral in Managua to replace the one destroyed in a 1972 earthquake, Managua's mayor announced Friday. Domino's owner Tom Monahan, who also owns the Detroit Tigers baseball club, will be vice president on the committee formed Friday to raise funds toward building the cathedral, Mayor Arnoldo Aleman said. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, a woman of strong religious convictions, will preside over the committee. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Managua, is honorary committee president. There was no word on the expected cost of the construction. Aleman said the land on which the building will be erected has been donated. Building a cathedral for Managua was one of Mrs. Chamorro's promises during the campaign that ended with her election victory Feb. 25. Despite hostility toward the Roman Catholic Church during the 10 years of Sandinista rule, Nicaraguans remain overwhelmingly religious and church celebrations drawing huge crowds. A powerful earthquake on Dec. 23, 1972, damaged much of Managua, including the cathedral, whose roof caved in and walls cracked, rendering it useless. Opponents of then-President Anastasio Somoza alleged he stole much of the international aid money to rebuild the capital, and the issue eroded his popularity. He was toppled by the Sandinistas in a broad-based 1979 uprising. Last year, Monahan said he was going to give up some of his responsibility at the Ann Arbor, Mich.-based fast-food chain to devote more time to Catholic charities.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Deficiencies Cause Shutdown of Power Plant Block
DOC.TEXT: Officials said Friday that they shut down part of a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant in northern East Germany because of ``grave'' safety problems. Environmental Minister Karl-Hermann Steinberg made the announcement at a news conference in East Berlin, criticizing management at the Greifswald plant near the Baltic Sea. He said the plant management had permitted operation of a power-producing block at the plant even though a leak had been discovered in what he called its ``cleaning system.'' The block was ordered ``shut down because of grave safety deficiencies,'' the East German official said. Steinberg, who was accompanied by West German Envoronmental Minister Klaus Toepfer, did not give details on safety at the plant, but past news reports have said the Soviet-designed operation was sloppily managed and poorly constructed. The West German magazine Der Spiegel reported in January that a nuclear accident had narrowly been averted at Greifswald in 1976, when fire destroyed some electrical cables, disabling all but one of 12 water-cooling pumps in one of the plant's four power-producing blocks. East German officials later announced that two of the blocks were shut down for safety reasons. On Friday, Steinberg said a third block reactor was also being shut down now, while the fourth, which has been upgraded, will operate until December. Original plans called for the plant to have eight separate blocks. Construction on the fifth block is nearing completion and it is to go into operation this year, Steinberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Volatility Being Required in '92
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency said Friday it will require refineries to lower the volatility of gasoline again in 1992 to reduce smog-causing evaporation. The agency said it was not imposing the new requirements for this summer because oil companies need more time to retool refineries and provide adequate supplies of fuel. The compounds in gasoline vapor are a principal raw material for the chemical reactions in the atmosphere that produce ozone, the major constituent of smog. The greater the volatility of gasoline, the more vapors are released to the atmosphere from fuel tanks, fuel systems and refueling, especially in the summer. The EPA last year began limiting summer gasoline volatility to 9.0 pounds per square inch to 10.5 psi, according to the standard Reid Vapor Pressure Test, depending on the region of the country. Starting in 1992, summer volatility will be limited to 7.8 psi to 9.0 psi.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Begins Tests Using Battleship Gun
DOC.TEXT: The Naval Surface Warfare Center began tests with a 16-inch battleship gun Friday to determine whether an accident might have caused the April 1989 explosion aboard the USS Iowa that killed 47 sailors. Last week, a test at the center along the Potomac River determined that propellant bags for the big guns can ignite when subjected to unusually high pressure. But tests inside a gun are needed to determine whether that could have happened on the Iowa. The tests, using a gun on land, are based on new information from Sandia National Laboratories of Albuquerque, N.M., which studied possible causes of the Iowa explosion for the Senate Armed Services Committee. The Sandia labs reported they failed to find evidence to support the Navy's official explanation that the fatal explosion was probably the work of a disgruntled, suicidal gunner's mate using a detonator. The labs managed to come up with a possible accidental cause, which the Navy had ruled out. After a test at the surface warfare center last Thursday initially confirmed the Sandia labs' findings, the Navy reopened its investigation of the blast and suspended all live 16-inch gun firings on battleships. In last week's test, experimenters dropped a weighted stack of propellant bags onto a steel plate. Seventeen such tests were done with no result, but on the 18th test the bags ignited. Representatives of the Sandia labs came to Virginia to participate in the tests here, said Lt. Dave Wray, a Navy spokesman. Tests using the 16-inch gun will be conducted without crew, using mechanized gadgetry to load bags into the gun and fire, Wray said.

DOC.HEAD: Firestone Not Pulling Out of Liberia Despite Uprising
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans continue to operate the world's largest rubber plantation in Liberia, despite a revolution that threatens to topple that nation's government, a Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. spokesman said Friday. ``We talk to them on a daily basis, and they are the best people to judge if they are in danger,'' said spokesman Trevor Hoskins from the company's corporate headquarters in Akron. Spouses and children of all non-Liberian employees have been moved out of the country over the last several weeks, he said. More than 1,000 people have died in five months of fighting and rebel troops from the National Patriotic Front of Liberia hemmed in President Samuel Doe on Friday. Doe asked the United States to help end the civil war in the West African nation. Doe has said he will hold democratic elections in 1991 but has not offered to resign. The rebels accuse his administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Hoskins said 63 spouses and children of non-Liberian employees have been evacuated from the 120,000-acre plantation. Bridgestone-Firestone employs about 8,500 Liberians and 23 non-Liberian management employees, 10 of which are U.S. citizens. The other managers come from Britain, Denmark, the Philippines, Malaysia, India and Portugal, Hoskins said. Hoskins said Bridgestone is the only major rubber manufacturer operating a plantation in Liberia.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Carpenters Wins $42 million Lottery Jackpot
LaserPhoto CX7
DOC.TEXT: A family of carpenters hung up their hammers for good Friday after claiming a $42 million Illinois Lotto jackpot. Winners Edward and Dorothy Sherwin formed the Sherwin Family Partnership to help share the wealth with the next two generations. ``When we bought the tickets, we always said we'd share the winnings with the family,'' said Sherwin, 70, a retired carpenter from suburban Lombard. ``It's a family thing.'' Sherwin said he handled the news of his winnings calmly. He said he recalled saying, ``I don't believe it.'' He then told his wife, Dorothy, who asked, ``Did you check the numbers?'' The numbers checked out, and ``Then, we finished our dinner,'' he said. They were joined at a news conference with their five children, who brought their spouses and 16 grandchildren. The family members will split $2.1 million _ minus $483,000 in state and federal taxes _ in payments each year for 20 years. Sherwin said he hoped the new riches wouldn't change his life too much. ``All I ever asked was to be left alone,'' he said. ``Now, all I want is for the family to stay the way we were and not split apart.'' Only grandson Greg Sherwin, a 20-year-old student at DePaul University, could think of any downside to the family's sudden wealth. ``There goes financial aid, I guess,'' he said jokingly and promised never to gripe again about tuition.

DOC.HEAD: France Pulling Troops from Gabon as Situation Eases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf with number of troops not specified
DOC.TEXT: France said Friday it will withdraw the troops it sent to Gabon to protect French civilians during a week of anti-government rioting. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said in a radio interview that the situation in the West African country, a former French territory, was now stable enough for French expatriates to return to their homes there. Thousands were evacuated during the unrest. In Gabon, the president of the National Assembly, Augustin Boumah, announced his resignation Friday, three days after fleeing from his home and disappearing for 24 hours. Boumah told a news conference he fled because he saw truckloads of soldiers outside his home and thought a coup was in progress. Authorities later said the soldiers were searching for Boumah's nephew, but the assembly president told reporters he felt humiliated by the military's ``attack on my dignity.'' Rioting broke out in Gabon on May 23 after opposition leader Joseph Rendjambe was found dead in a hotel room. His supporters called it murder, but an autopsy held jointly by Gabonese and French doctors indicated Rendjambe died of natural causes. The oil center of Port Gentil experienced the worst riots. Dumas said French military aircraft will fly 25 tons of food there as a donation. Dumas said he spoke with President Omar Bongo of Gabon by telephone Thursday night and Bongo ``assured me that the democratic processes which he has begun to put in place will be continued.'' The minister said negotiations begun Wednesday between Bongo and leaders of the opposition Gabon Progress Party stemmed from a French diplomatic initiative. His ministry did not specify in its announcement last month how many reinforcements France was sending to bolster its 500-member military force in Gabon, nor did Friday's announcement give any specific figure.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Talks on Barry Plea Go On as Cocaine Trial Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf: ``Later, however,'' with later statement that resignation irrelevant
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's attorney on Friday said ``I don't rule out'' a possible plea bargain over drug and perjury charges, and sources close to the case said discussions have included terms of the mayor's possible resignation. Barry, 54, is scheduled to go on trial Monday on 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. He has pleaded innocent to all charges. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy and U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens have held several discussions on a possible plea bargain, according to sources close to the case who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mundy, in court for a pre-trial hearing, was asked Friday whether he was ruling out a plea bargain. ``I don't rule out anything,'' he said. He added, ``All our efforts ... will be devoted'' toward a ``full-fledged, full-blown trial.'' Stephens said ``we are prepared to go to trial,'' but refused to comment on the plea bargain issue. Later, however, Stephens' spokeswoman, Judy Smith, issued a one-sentence statement in his name: ``Contrary to some media reports, Mr. Barry's resignation is irrelevant to the prosecution of this case.'' Barry made no comment. He met with his cabinet over lunch during the day. ``If he pleads, there would have to be a resignation,'' said one source familiar with negotiations between Mundy and Stephens. ``There are a variety of combinations out there, but that is a constant.'' Sources familiar with the case said prosecutors have been informed the mayor will not agree to any arrangement that requires him to plead guilty to a felony. Pleading guilty to a felony would bar Barry from finishing his term or running for elected office again. Federal sentencing guidelines also require that Barry would spend at least six months in a halfway house if he accepted a felony plea. Barry has not publicly revealed his political plans, but has held a number of campaign-style appearances around the city since returning in March from seven weeks of treatment for substance abuse. He has been mayor of the nation's capital city since 1979. Among matters still to be discussed are whether a videotape made of the mayor's Jan. 18 arrest would be sealed, and whether a plea agreement would preclude prosecutors from charging Barry with additional crimes in the future, according to the sources. According to court filings, the videotape shows Barry smoking crack cocaine provided to him by for a woman friend cooperating with an FBI sting operation. Stephens has said the probe that produced the 14-count indictment against Barry is continuing. At the public pre-trial hearing, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson set the ground rules for a series of questions potential jurors will be asked when the case opens on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Army Fans Out Across Pakistan's Troubled Sind Province
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of soldiers fanned out across southern Sind Province on Friday with orders to seize anyone involved in a wave of ethnic violence that has killed at least 349 people, the government said. Officials said snipers killed at least seven people during a two-hour break in the curfew to let residents attend Friday prayers at neighborhood mosques. Moslem clerics asked greater Karachi's 9 million residents to set aside prejudices and mistrust feeding the violence. Officials say at least 169 people have been killed since Sunday in Karachi, the provincial capital, including 30 shot Thursday night in a sniper attack on a passenger bus and five who died in an attack on a train. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto called out the army this week to help restore order in Karachi and Hyderabad, the province's second pargest city with more than 3 million people. The government on Friday deployed more soldiers into the interior of the province to arrest and disarm those linked to the violence, including members of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party and members of the rival Mohajir Qami Movement, a smaller party representing Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. ``The army has been assigned the task of apprehending terrorists, a list of which has been prepared jointly by the army and the civil administration,'' the government announced Friday. Native Sindhis accuse the better-educated Mohajirs of taking the best jobs and most valuable land. The Mohajirs want to be officially recognized along with the Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindhis as Pakistan's fifth nationality. Animosities flared into violence on May 15 and exploded last Sunday when security forces in Hyderabad fired on a crowd defying a curfew to demand food, water and electricity. At least 180 people died, setting off reprisal shootings in Karachi, about 150 miles south.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Clash Between Law Officers, Peasants
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A clash between machete-wielding peasants and sheriff's officers left the sheriff and 10 other people dead in the remote Artibonite Valley, a radio station reported Friday. The melee occurred Thursday in the hamlet of Perodin, in a fertile, hilly region of west-central Haiti about 55 miles north of Port-au-Prince, the capital. Capt. Maxi Maxime, the regional military commander, confirmed in an interview with Haiti Inter that the clash occurred but disclosed no further details. Independent Radio Haiti Inter said officers shot seven peasants to death, and peasants with machetes hacked to death Sheriff Selien Thelo and three of his deputies. The 19-member Council of State, which governs with President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, recently called for reform of the traditionally repressive rural police system.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International: Niger Nomads Arrested and Killed
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Friday that more than 400 members of a nomadic ethnic group have been arrested since April in Niger and at least 40 of them have been killed. Many of the ethnic Tuaregs who were detained may have been tortured, said the human rights group said in a statement. It said those still in detention were arrested because of their ethnic origins. The Tuaregs are members of a Berber group of nomadic herders who for centuries have traveled Africa's Sahara Desert in what is now Algeria, Mali, Niger and Libya. Many have settled in camps around the sub-Saharan village of Agadez, where at least 30 Tuaregs were arrested April 11, Amnesty said. They were moved to government detention centers in the villages of Tillabery or Dirkou, and some reportedly were tortured, the London-based group said. An additional 380 Tuaregs were arrested later and detained in Tahoua army barracks where torture is believed to occur routinely, the statement said. No other details of the arrests were provided by the group. It said at least 40 of those detained were killed by their captors last month. The government has said ethnic Tuaregs backed by Libya attacked government forces last month in the oasis of Tchintabaraden and the town of Gal. Relations between Niger and Libya have sometimes been strained, most recently in the mid-1980s when Niger allowed the United States to build a secret airstrip near the Libyan border. Under a new agreement, many Tuaregs have returned to Niger from refugee camps in Algeria and Libya. Amnesty said some have been disappointed by the government's failure to provide food and shelter.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels, Guatemala Political Parties Move to End Warfare
DOC.TEXT: The rebel Guatamalan National Revolutionary Union reached agreement Friday with nine political parties in that Central American nation on steps to end 28 years of bloody guerrilla war. The agreement is expected to serve as a framework for future negotiations among the guerrillas, the government of President Vinicio Cerezo and senior military officiers. The government estimates that from 30,000 to 60,000 people have died in the conflict that was set off by rebel army officers in 1962. The Revolutionary Union says 100,000 people died and 50,000 more are missing. After five days of talks in a hotel in El Escorial, 25 miles north of Madrid, the rebels and politicians issued a joint statement saying the Revolutionary Union will join the nine national parties in an assembly next year to revise Guatemala's constitution. In return, the political parties _ including Cerezo's Christian Democrats _ accepted the rebel demand that the paramilitary Civil Self-Defense Patrols be disbanded and Guatemala's armed forces come under increased political control. The guerrillas promised not to disrupt general elections set for November, but a rebel spokesman said this would not mean a general cease-fire. A rebel spokesman said this week that before negotiations begin with the government and military officers, the guerrillas probably will open talks with representatives of Guatemalan trade unions, business people and the Roman Catholic Church. The negotiations form part of a process begun after the 1987 Esquipulas II Central American peace accords. The area's five national presidents agreed that regional conflicts should be ended through democratic reforms and political negotiations between governments and rebel movements.

DOC.HEAD: Pierre Cardin Signs on for New Restaurant in Kazakhstan
DOC.TEXT: While Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev were fashioning summit statements in Washington, Pierre Cardin returned from a Soviet visit to report progress on the gastronomic front. The couturier said he signed a contract involving another summit _ a new restaurant to be built on a mountaintop in the south-central Soviet republic of Kazakhstan. ``We'll be right on top of everything,'' Cardin said Thursday. His restaurant will be built in the republic's capital, Alma Ata _ a city surrounded by 13,000-foot peaks. Cardin, who also owns several restaurants, set up 32 factories in the Soviet Union two years ago to manufacture his Paris designs under a franchise agreement. While in Kazakhstan, Cardin also signed a license contract with the republic's president to produce fur jackets and wool coats. The patterns will be made in Paris, and the clothes manufactured in Cardin's Soviet factories.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Forest Conservation Project to be Launched in Guyana
DOC.TEXT: The government says it will set aside 900,000 acres of rain forest to study ecologically safe methods of using the virtually untouched tropical reserve. The project will be launched Tuesday and is a joint effort with the Commonwealth, an association of Britain and the governments of its former colonies. Guyana offered the land in the Potaro District in central Guyana at last year's Commonwealth Heads of Government Conference in Malaysia as the nearly 50 heads of state who attended looked for ways of slowing the effects of global warming. The district is in the Essequibo region, an area that makes up two-thirds of Guyana and has been disputed with neighboring Venezuela, which has claimed jurisdiction over the territory since the 1960s. Venezuela claims it was cheated of the Essequibo region in a treaty signed in 1899 between Britain, the United States and Russia that established the borders between the territories. The dispute is currently before U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Winston King, chairman of the Guyana Natural Resources Agency, said May 17 the land belongs to Guyana and that Venezuela only has to be informed about the plans for the project. About 400,000 acres of the total area to be set aside have been identified for a ``wilderness preserve'' to allow scientists worldwide to study the environment and develop ways to show how conservation, commercial and community forestry can co-exist. The independent newspaper the Stabroek News reported Wednesday that the Commonwealth scientists are eager to participate in the project because it offers them the chance to be among the first to find solutions to the global warming. M.S. Swaminathan, an Indian scientist who leads the Commonwealth group that will coordinate the project, said it will be the biggest ecological project of its kind. The four-phase project will involve the setting up of an Amazonian Rain Forest Research, Training and Communication Center and the Rain Forest Wilderness Resort, Swaminathan said. The United Nations, the World Bank and other agencies will be approached for at least $50 million needed to finance the project. King said legislation will be prepared to make the area off-limits to unauthorized persons and to give project administrators authority over it. He said, however, that from aerial and ground inspections the area is never permanently inhabitated and it remains in its virtually untouched form except for a portion of the Georgetown railroad that passes through it.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 263,000 Cases Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: More than 9,000 new AIDS cases were registered worldwide in May, mostly due to updated reporting from the United States, the World Health Organization said Friday. The total number of reported victims rose to 263,051, with 156 countries listing cases, the U.N. agency's latest monthly update said. The United States reported 6,538 new cases, raising its toll to 132,436 cases. AIDS cases in the United States account for half of the world total. France, the hardest hit country in Europe, reported an increase of 835 cases last month for a total of 9,718.

DOC.HEAD: Hirayanagi, Former Kyodo News Service Executive, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Tsuneo Hirayanagi, former executive director of the Kyodo News Service, died Friday of pneumonia at a Tokyo hospital, the news agency said. He was 81. The news agency said on Saturday that Hirayanagi, who also was owner of the shipping newspaper Kaiun Times, earlier served as Kyodo's economic editor, director of its general affairs department and manager of the news agency's Fukuoka bureau in southern Japan.

DOC.HEAD: DNA Repository to Provide Needed Material for Alzeimer's Researchers
DOC.TEXT: A new cell bank will collect genetic material from victims of Alzheimer's disease and distribute it to researchers seeking the ailment's causes, the Indiana University Medical Center announced Friday. The director of the Alzheimer's clinic at the medical center said the repository will spur research needed to trace the genetic and environmental causes of the fourth leading cause of death among the elderly. ``This is terribly important not just to establishing the genetic patterns of the disease, but to find out the biological mechanisms,'' said Hugh Hendrie, chairman of the department of psychiatry at the school. Alzheimer's disease is a degenerative disorder of the human central nervous system that usually begins late in life. Victims gradually lose memory and intellectual functions, and many of them must be institutionalized. Death usually occurs five to 10 years after symptoms first appear. There is no known treatment. People in the United States and Canada who have two or more living family members who suffer from the disease were urged to call a toll-free number, 1-800-526-2839, to determine if their family fits the profile the Alzheimer's Genetic Repository needs for blood donations. Families with a greater prevalence of the disease are more valuable. The repository will then provide white blood cells and DNA material to researchers at 15 research centers funded by National Institute of Aging in the United States as well as other scientists worldwide, said P. Michael Conneally, the director of the repository. He said it will be the first such repository in the country devoted to research on a single disease. There are three types of Alzheimer's disease. Under type 1, which is inherited, symptoms first occur between ages 30 and 50. Under type 2, which may or may not be inherited, the onset of symptoms occurs at age 55 or older. Fewer than 10 percent of victims suffer from types 1 and 2. The most common form of the disease appears after age 80, and is believed to be non-hereditary. The first genetic material will be available in six months to a year from now, and will be provided free of charge to qualified researchers. The repository is being funded through a $500,000 grant from the National Institute on Aging, part of the National Institutes of Health. The grant is renewable for five more years, Conneally said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Undergoing Mental Evaluation After Threatening Calls: Police
DOC.TEXT: A man who allegedly mentioned Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev while making telephone threats against police officers will undergo psychiatric tests, police said Friday.
