Assistant Chief of Police Jim Moline said the evaluation should be completed by Monday and the results given to the Stearns County attorney's office, which will decide whether to charge David Allen Dalbec, 31. He was being held in the county jail Friday. Moline said Gorbachev, who is scheduled to visit the Twin Cities Sunday, was mentioned in the man's phone calls, ``but the main threats were directed at St. Cloud police officers.'' ``The context in which he mentioned (Gorbachev) was threatening,'' Moline said, but he refused to be more specific. St. Cloud is about 60 miles northwest of Minneapolis. Police Chief Dennis O'Keefe said Thursday that the man made several calls to police Tuesday and was arrested the next day.

Even some students who had protested first lady Barbara Bush's selection as Wellesley College's commencement speaker praised her address, which ended with an ironic comment on first spousehood. Mrs. Bush appeared with Raisa Gorbachev at Friday's ceremony and later credited the Soviet first lady with the warm reception they received, calling her ``my secret weapon.'' Mrs. Bush stressed the importance of family life in her speech to the graduating women. But she received the loudest cheers when she closed saying, ``Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the President's spouse. I wish him well!'' One of the 575 seniors had painted on her mortar board ``Barbara Bush for President 1992.'' Another wore a picture of President and Mrs. Bush, with the first lady dressed in a suit and power tie, the president wearing a dress.

President Samuel Doe appealed for international help to end a rebel invasion and tried to appease the rebels by promising not to seek re-election. A rebel spokesman said they dropped their demand that Doe surrender and stand trial. At a news conference Friday, the embattled Doe said he had survived at least 35 coup attempts since he took power 10 years ago and would be happy to leave ``the burden of leading a country'' to someone else. ``I wish to announce here today my firm decision not to stand for the 1991 general elections,'' Doe said. One diplomat described Doe's promise as ``too little, too late.''

State boards that license and discipline physicians are becoming stronger, but many still lack the staff, money and legal authority to protect the public from malpractice, according to a draft of a new government report. ``Case backlogs remain a serious problem, ... significant staff shortages continue to impede the boards' disciplinary efforts,'' while limitations on boards' authority prevent thorough investigations, said the draft report by the inspector general of the Health and Human Services Department. The report is to be released next week. A copy of the draft was obtained by The Associated Press. The report noted that despite the constraints they face, ``medical boards have made significant progress in improving their disciplinary capacity.'' Yet there is no data with which to gauge their performance, it said.

Prisoners in other states spend their days stamping out license plates. Inmates in a Wyoming program do their time in the saddle _ or trying to stay in the saddle _ as they break wild horses. Gary Starbuck, superintendent of the Wyoming Honor Farm, said the 2-year-old horse-breaking program molds inmates into more productive citizens than do prison cells. ``Some say they've got it too easy. It's a country club. They want to see them do hard time,'' Starbuck said as he kept an eye on the bronco-busting recently at the sprawling, tree-studded corrections ranch. ``But what you end up with is someone bitter, probably harder on drugs than when he got there. That's been the problem with corrections for 200 years. It's punishment-oriented,'' he said.

President Samuel Doe tried to appease advancing rebels Friday by promising not to seek re-election next year, and he pleaded with the United States and other allies to help end the revolt. A U.S.-based spokesman for the rebels said they had dropped their demand that Doe surrender and stand trial for alleged corruption and atrocities. The spokesman, Tom Woewiyu, said if Doe left Liberia, the insurgents would be willing to work with the existing regime to set up an interim government. He said his comments were approved by Charles Taylor, leader of the rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia that was marching toward Monrovia. Doe, threatened by rebels approaching from two fronts, told reporters Friday: ``I wish to announce here today my firm decision not to stand for the 1991 general elections.'' The 6-month-old incursion had reached within 35 miles of the capital, Monrovia. More than 1,000 people have been killed in the six months of fighting, most of them civilians slain by government troops. The U.S. Navy stationed ships off the coast to evacuate Americans if necessary. U.S. Embassy officials said about 2,000 U.S. citizens, including scores of missionaries and many people of Liberian origin, remain in the country.

Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev gave the graduating women of Wellesley College some first-lady advice Friday and then rejoiced in their newfound friendship. ``I simply feel very at home and comfortable with Mrs. Gorbachev and I have enormous respect for her,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters as the pair toured Boston after sharing the commencement platform. Said Mrs. Gorbachev: ``I particularly rejoice at the fact that our conversations are extremely open, sincere and friendly. And despite the fact that we might have differences, that does not change the tone.'' At Wellesley's graduation ceremonies, where Mrs. Bush disarmed critics who had argued that she was not a suitable role model for women in the '90s. ``I never dreamed, it would be this much fun,'' the American first lady said. The crowd cheered, ``Barbara, Barbara, Barbara'' as Mrs. Bush spoke unabashedly about her homemaker's life, while urging the graduates to pursue professional careers if that was their goal. Mrs. Bush, who dropped out of college to marry George Bush as World War II raged a continent away, wore a black academic robe with a purple cowl. Mrs. Gorbachev, a philosophy Ph.D and former university lecturer, wore a plaid gray suit and pink blouse. More conspicuous were the graduates who wore purple armbands, signaling their lingering belief that Mrs. Bush's life has epitomized the victory of fealty to family over feminist emergence.

Last year it was hand-held video games, watchable Walkmans and interactive compact discs. This year, it's digital audio tape, scaled-down camcorders and movie-theater sound for the home. Every year, millions of dollars in new electronics technology goes on display at the Consumer Electronics Show, but what does it mean for someone who bought last year's innovation and now faces bewildering new choices? ``Products will continue to be put out with new features and new bells and whistles,'' acknowledged Marvin Lurie, spokesman for the Association of Retail Dealers of America, based in the Chicago suburb of Lombard. ``The only way to get it sorted out is to go to a qualified dealer who can explain the benefits,'' Lurie said Friday. He said his group represents about 20 percent of U.S. consumer electronics retailers. Many of those retailers will be among the estimated 55,000 visitors to the annual show, beginning Saturday at McCormick Place. Some 1,400 manufacturers will be showing tens of thousands of products for four days in an area equivalent to the size of 17 football fields.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv 06
For Release Wednesday AMs, June 6, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Reflections From South Africa's Most Popular Music Group
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Shabalala sits in an office at Warner Bros. Records, alternately looking out the window and back at his questioner. He is contemplating how Ladysmith Black Mambazo became an overnight sensation after only 30 years in the music business. ``Yes, we are still amazed, even now,'' he says in melodious South African-accented English. The soft-spoken but gregarious Shabalala, who looks much younger than his 49 years, is the founder, lead singer, composer and spiritual guide of perhaps the most popular singing group to ever come out of South Africa. ``It has been wonderful, it has been gratifying, to be doing God's gift,'' he said. After all, his group has been touring and recording almost constantly since its 1986 appearance on Paul Simon's Grammy-winning ``Graceland'' album. And after two hit records, a Grammy of their own and concerts in Europe, the United States and Japan, there is much for Shabalala and the nine other members of Ladysmith Black Mambazo to smile about. But it wasn't always so. On this recent day, as the group prepared for its fourth U.S. concert tour, Shabalala and fellow singer Albert Mazibuko reminisce about another time, when the group could only be heard on South Africa's Radio Zulu; when it could only play in front of black audiences; when it was South Africa's best-kept musical secret. That was a lifetime before appearances on ``Saturday Night Live'' and ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' and the adulation of audiences of all colors. It was a time of crisscrossing South Africa for the joy of performing, of singing all night on Saturday and all day on Sunday in places such as Durban or Soweto, then driving all night to get back to work in their hometown of Ladysmith. The 42-year-old Mazibuko smiled as he remembered how those all-night song festivals once cost him his job with a construction company. ``We would always come to work very late on Mondays because we had been out singing all night,'' he said. ``One Monday we arrived very, very late. But since then I've been able to make my living singing, so it worked out.'' But even if it hadn't, just the singing, the opportunity to blend 10 voices as though they were an orchestra of instruments, and to sing better than anybody in the township, always made it worth it, said Shabalala. ``It took me 10 years to develop the group,'' he recalled. ``All along we were singing in the townships, in the halls, all night long, with maybe 20 other groups. And when you won the gold medal, you knew you were the biggest, the best group there _ and Black Mambazo won many gold medals.'' Then came the records. The group recorded 27 on South African labels, selling millions of copies, although the music was only heard on Radio Zulu, a black station. The songs, almost always performed a cappella and often about day-to-day life in black South Africa, are heard around the world now and are praised as being uncommonly beautiful. The praise has a familiar ring to it. ``During the Graceland tour (the group's first in America), people wrote that we were a joyous voice from Africa,'' Shabalala recalled. ``I thought when my people in Soweto used to say things like that it was because they understood the language. But even people who don't understand, they say the same thing.'' For years it wasn't the language barrier, but apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial separation, that kept Black Mambazo from the rest of the world. Simon discovered the group through a South African friend in the mid-1980s. As captivated as everyone else, he tried to call Shabalala, who was on a tour of the townships at the time. ``When I came home my wife said there's a white guy from America who keeps calling,'' Shabalala said, chuckling at the memory. The two met and decided to record together, but first Shabalala had to convince the others in Black Mambazo that this white outsider was really all right. He'd never even been that trusting of whites himself. ``But I was trusting of him right from the beginning,'' he said. ``I don't know why, except that he was soft-spoken, he was very polite and he looked me right in the eye.'' And so ``Graceland'' gave Black Mambazo to the world. Its own Grammy-winning record, ``Shaka Zula,'' followed, as did ``Journey of Dreams'' and the soon-to-be-released ``Two Worlds One Heart.'' Along with a new worldwide audience has come acceptance among whites in South Africa. ``They even promote us to white audiences now,'' Shabalala said. ``When we sing in the townships now, sometimes people ask me what is this (singing in front of white people)? I tell them it's freedom.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, June 6

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler's Leadership Succession Vaguer Than Politburo Guessing Game
DOC.TEXT: The aging chairman had said he would retire eventually, but never specified a date or certain successor. His likely replacement abruptly resigned, leaving the future leader's identity even murkier. That may sound like a Politburo political intrigue that could only haunt the inner sanctums of the Kremlin or Beijing's Great Hall of the People. But it happened in a den of capitalism this past week, Chrysler Corp.'s headquarters in Highland Park, Mich. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald's unexpected departure from Chrysler to head an employee buyout of airline giant UAL Corp. came as a surprise not only to company outsiders but also evidently to Chairman Lee A. Iacocca. Iacocca was vacationing at his Italian villa retreat when Greenwald personally delivered the news. They flew back together for the official announcement. Greenwald said he was pursuing a new challenge rather than fleeing uncertainty and frustration in an industry that is under severe competitive pressure. He also denied suggestions of internal dissension at the top. But management experts said Greenwald's resignation had the effect of raising basic questions about whether Chrysler's own management team had long-term faith in its future. He was the third senior executive to quit in a month. ``If someone at that high level who is in line to be the CEO prefers another CEO's job in a different kind of industry, it makes you wonder why he made that jump,'' said Richard M. Cyert, president of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. ``That's a worrisome thing. I'd worry very much as a Chrysler stockholder. As an American I worry about it.'' Greenwald, 54, had been considered the leading candidate to replace Iacocca after the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive officer's contract expires in October 1991. Iacocca, who helped save Chrysler from bankruptcy a decade ago and is trying to stem the No. 3 automaker's latest decline, had dropped hints he might retire but left it ambiguous. So questions have persisted about who might succeed him and when. The uncertainty was reinforced by Chrysler's response to the Greenwald departure. It expanded the duties of two other senior-level managers, Robert A. Lutz and Robert S. Miller Jr., to fill the void. They both evidently are now the leading candidates to lead Chrysler after Iacocca but that remains unclear. Some outside management experts said Chrysler's scrambled reaction was a signal that the company had no contingency arrangement to handle an unexpected event like the Greenwald resignation. ``That's not surprising,'' said Gilbert E. Dwyer, president of the Dwyer Consulting Group, a New York-based management consulting and executive recuitment firm. ``Once you've made it clear to an individual that he's going to be the next CEO, you really don't expect he's going to change his mind.'' Gerald C. Myers, a management expert and former chairman of now-defunct American Motors Corp. acquired by Chrysler three years ago, declined to comment specifically about the company because of his personal relationship with its executives. But he said that in general, management succession is one of the most critical problems any company can face. ``There's a need to as early as possible designate the time of succession, the people who will be involved and those who won't,'' said Myers, who wrote ``When It Hits the Fan,'' a book about management crises. ``The infighting, the unhappiness, the ulcers, the bad media, all these things boil out if it's not clear,'' he said. In other business and economic news this past week: _Contradictory evidence emerged over the state of the economy. A widely followed monthly survey of purchasing managers suggested the nation's manufacturing improved in May. But government figures showed private job growth stalled in May, and construction spending and factory orders fell in April, indicating persistent sluggishness. The markets rallied on the bad news because it implied interest rates will decline, making stocks and bonds more valuable. _Two leading U.S. exporters signed major deals with Communist superpowers. Boeing Co. sold jetliners to China in an arrangement worth at least $2 billion and possibly $4 billion. International Business Machines Corp., using the Soviet-U.S. summit as a backdrop, announced it would provide 13,000 personal computers to Soviet schools for an undisclosed amount. _Coca-Cola Co. put the lid on ``MagiCans,'' its biggest-ever advertising promotion. The campaign featured Coke cans that contained money or prize certificates, but they were plagued by mechanical problems. By some estimates, the company may be left with 500,000 MagiCans it can't use.

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Funds Rev Up Market Rally
DOC.TEXT: As they tally their profits from the stock market's upsurge to record highs over the past five weeks, many stock-market investors acknowledge a debt of gratitude to mutual funds. Funds that invest in stocks have brimmed over lately with new money from investors, virtually forcing them to step up their buying in the marketplace. An awareness of that development seems to have increased other traders' enthusiasm for stocks at a time when many uncertainties persist about the outlook for the economy. Indeed, to some observers, the resurgent popularity of stock funds hints at a positive change in the attitude of the public toward investing in the market. ``Individual investors again form a growing constituency for equities,'' says Greg Smith, strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities. The mutual fund industry has been booming for years. Its total assets, around $100 billion as the 1980s began, soared to the $1 trillion mark by last winter. Much of that growth, however, occurred in funds that put money to work in places other than stocks _ money-market investments, for example, or Treasury bonds or new vehicles on the financial scene like mortgage-backed securities. Stock funds were generally thought to have reached and passed their peak as a stock market force during the ``go-go'' years of the 1960s, when some managers of high-risk funds temporarily achieved the status of cult heroes. Today, most analysts agree, it's still far too soon to tell whether anything like a replay of that era is in store. But for the past few months market analysts have been paying more and more attention to an influx of money into stock funds _ especially since it began during a period of sluggish market performance, before stock prices took off this spring. Through the first four months of the year, investors put $7.8 billion more into stock funds than they took out, surpassing net sales of $5.8 billion for all of 1989. ``The public's subscription to equity mutual funds may not be a lasting phenomenon,'' said Michael Sherman at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``If it is, however, it is certainly coming at an odd time. Apart from all the fundamental factors affecting stock prices, the mentality of this new buyer may affect market behavior for the foreseeable future.'' Excitement over the funds' new clout helped propel stock prices to new highs in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 80.05 to 2,900.97. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 4.32 to 198.03; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 8.54 to 462.14, and the American Stock exchange market value index was up 3.99 at 363.83. Volume on the Big Board averaged 172.62 million shares a day, against 163.47 million the week before. A good many observers speculate that investors have turned to stock funds partly because their ardor for several types of competing investments has cooled. For example, credit worries have taken a little of the edge off investors' keen appetite for money-market funds. As the housing market has cooled in many areas of the country, analysts have questioned whether real estate will work the same kind of wealth-building wonders in the 1990s that it did in the '70s and '80s. ``Equities are looking better by comparison,'' says Smith. ``Proof of my hypothesis about the change in valuation benchmarks will come in the form of continued net positive inflows to equity mutual funds through the summer. ``And with lower interest rates, we could have a lot of fun in the equity market in the summer of 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Inland Empire Plans Push on Recycled Paper
DOC.TEXT: Inland Empire Paper Co. plans to purchase equipment by the end of next year that will enable it to produce half of its paper from recycled newspapers, a company official says. The move reflects market demand for recycled newsprint from the 100-ton capacity plant at Millwood, east of Spokane, said Clyde B. Anderson, Inland Empire president and general manager. The equipment, which would remove ink from old newspapers so that they can be recycled more easily, is expected to be in place by the end of 1991, he said Thursday. Anderson declined to give the specific cost of the equipment, but said the equipment will cost about $150,000 per ton of daily capacity. That would be about $15 million at the 100-ton-a-day plant. The decision to purchase the de-inking equipment stemmed in part from requests from the company's largest customers, The Seattle Times and two San Francisco newspapers, to use more recycled paper, Anderson said. Inland Empire is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Cowles Publishing Co., which publishes The Spokesman-Review and Spokane Chronicle newspapers. In addition to the newsprint mill, the company owns and manages more than 100,000 acres of forest land in Eastern Washington and northern Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Proposes Fines Against Illinois Firm
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday proposed fines of more than $610,000 for an Illinois railroad car manufacturer that allegedly violated workplace safety laws. Thrall Car Manufacturing Co. was accused of 141 violations of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's noise, welding fume and respirator regulations. Craig Dowden, a spokesman at Thrall, based in Chicago Heights, Ill., said most of the alleged violations involved testing requirements that have been implemented. ``Thrall Car has a history of concern for the safety of its employees and will be discussing these alleged violations with OSHA,'' Dowden said. The alleged violations involved a Chicago Heights plant that employs 500 workers, the agency said. An investigation began in December 1989 after employees complained of excessive exposure to chemicals at the plant. The firm, with another two plants in Illinois and two in Georgia, employs a total of 2,400 workers. The company will have a chance to argue against the fines before they become final.

DOC.HEAD: Panasonic Announces First Rerecordable Optical Disc Using New Technology
DOC.TEXT: Panasonic announced Friday the first rerecordable optical storage disc for computers that uses a new technology designed to make it work faster. Optical storage discs hold much more information than the more common magnetic discs used for computer data storage. But most can only be recorded once. Rewritable optical discs are a relatively new technology. They allow the discs to be used many times. Most optical discs are based on a technology called magneto-optical. They store the ones and zeros of computer data as magnetized or unmagnetized sections of the disc. To read one of these discs, light from a laser is bounced off the disc while it is spinning. The magnetic orientation of the different spots of the disc causes the light, which is polarized, to rotate slightly. This rotation is then read by the machine as either a one or a zero. The technology used by Panasonic, which is part of Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., is called phase change. Instead of changing the magnetic orientation of the disc, it uses a laser to change the nature of the disc's material into a crystalline form, which is highly reflective, or to leave in it a non-crystalline form, which does not reflect light. The differences in reflection are read by the laser as ones or zeros. The advantage of the phase-change system is that a disc can be rerecorded in one pass of the laser. By comparison, to record over a magneto-optical disc, the laser first must erase the original data in a separate operation before it can record new data. Optical disc storage is used primarily with personal computers. It is particularly useful for storge of images, as opposed to words or numbers, since images are composed of vastly more data, said Jay Bretzmann, an analyst at International Data Corp., a high-technology research firm. Panasonic said its new storage device will be available this fall at the suggested list price of $5,000. Rewritable optical discs are expected to cost about $250, the company said.
